ARTICLE II. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Furnishing false information to city employee or official, § 50-39. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-26. - Official information not to be utilized for personal profit. 
    No officer or employee of the city shall unfairly utilize information acquired by reason of his relationship with the city to make any arrangement, contract or investment for the purpose of obtaining or attempting to obtain a direct or indirect personal profit. 
(Code 1976, § 2-1) 
Cross reference- Appointment and powers and duties of building official, § 18-31. 
State Law reference- Standards of conduct and ethics, MCL 15.341 et seq., MSA 4.1700(71) et seq. 
Sec. 2-27. - Exercising official power or influence for personal profit. 
    No officer or employee of the city shall unfairly exercise or attempt to so exercise his power or influence as an officer or employee of the city in order to affect the operations or dealings of the city for the purpose of acquiring a direct or indirect personal profit. 
(Code 1976, § 2-2) 
Sec. 2-28. - Notification to city commission of personal real estate transactions. 
    Each officer and employee of the city shall notify the city commission, in writing, of any dealings or transactions in which he engages while he is an officer or employee of the city relating to real estate located in the city. Such notice shall be filed within ten days after the completion of such dealing or transaction, stating the nature of the real property, the interest in the property which was acquired or conveyed, and with whom such dealings were conducted. 
(Code 1976, § 2-3) 
Sec. 2-29. - Violation of section 2-26, 2-27 or 2-28 grounds for removal. 
    If, after a hearing, the city commission determines that any officer or employee of the city has knowingly violated any provision of section 2-26, 2-27, or 2-28, such a violation shall constitute misconduct, within the meaning of section 7.7 of the Charter, which would warrant removal from office of such officer or employee. 
(Code 1976, § 2-4) 
Secs. 2-30-2-40. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CITY MANAGER 

Sec. 2-41. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Department heads means the assistant city manager, accountant, building official, assessor, personnel director, public works superintendent, police chief, deputy fire chief, income tax admini- strator, planning director, and any other appointed office or position so designated by resolution of the city commission. 
    Employees means all employees of the city other than department heads. 
(Code 1976, § 2-6(a)) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 2-42. - Creation and appointment. 
    There is hereby created the office of city manager of the city. The city manager shall be an officer of the city and shall have the power and perform the duties set forth in this division. The city commission shall appoint the city manager by majority vote of all the members then serving. 
(Code 1976, § 2-6(b)) 
Sec. 2-43. - Qualifications. 
    The city manager shall be chosen by the city commission on the basis of his executive and administrative qualifications in the profession of public management. At the time of his appointment, he need not be a resident of the city or state, but during his tenure of office, he shall reside in the city; provided, however, that in case a nonresident is appointed, the city commission may in its sole discretion authorize a reasonable period of time to comply with this requirement. 
(Code 1976, § 2-6(c)) 
Sec. 2-44. - Tenure. 
    The manager shall be appointed for a term specified by resolution of the city commission at the time he is hired or from time to time thereafter. If no term is specified, the appointment shall be for an indefinite term. The city commission shall have the authority to enter into a contract with the city manager. The city manager shall be removable at any time by the pleasure of the city commission upon a vote for removal by at least a majority of members of the city commission. 
(Code 1976, § 2-6(d)) 
Sec. 2-45. - Powers and duties. 
    The city manager shall be the chief administrative officer and head of the administrative agencies of the city. He shall be responsible to the city commission and, except as otherwise provided in the Charter, shall have power and be required to: 
(1)  Appoint and remove department heads, subject to the approval of the city commission; 
(2)  Appoint and remove employees of the city; 
(3)  Prepare and submit the budget annually to the city commission for approval in accordance with section 2-81, and upon approval of the budget by the city commission, administer the budget annually; 
(4)  Keep the city commission informed of the current financial condition and future needs of the city as requested by the city commission; 
(5)  Prepare and submit to or for the city commission reports annually or more frequently if requested by the city commission, on all affairs and departments of the city; 
(6)  Delegate to other officers and/or employees of the city any duties conferred upon him by this section and hold them responsible for their faithful discharge; 
(7)  Attend meetings of the city commission, unless excused by the city commission, and any other meetings as directed by the city commission; 
(8)  Implement and enforce all resolutions, policies and decisions of the city commission and all collective bargaining agreements entered into by the city commission; 
(9)  Communicate with the department heads of the city concerning decisions, policies and resolutions of the city commission, and any other matters pertaining to the performance of their duties and functions; 
(10)  Arrange for and attend a meeting at least every two months with the department heads and the city commission, or a committee thereof, as determined by the city commission, to discuss the affairs of the city; 
(11)  Purchase materials, supplies and equipment for all departments of the city;provided that all purchases exceeding $1,000.00 shall be subject to approval of the city commission; 
(12)  In conjunction with the mayor and other members of the city commission, represent the city at intergovernmental meetings and activities; 
(13)  Submit weekly a written record of absences, including vacation days, sick days, and personal days, to the personnel director; and 
(14)  Perform such other duties as may be legally required by the city commission. 
(Code 1976, § 2-6(e)) 
Sec. 2-46. - Absence or disability. 
    In the absence or disability of the city manager, the assistant city manager shall perform the duties of the city manager during such absence or disability; provided, however, that in the event of an absence or disability of more than two weeks, the city commission may, by resolution, appoint a person as interim city manager who shall perform the duties of the city manager until he shall return. 
(Code 1976, § 2-6(f)) 
Secs. 2-47-2-55. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - COMPENSATION COMMISSION[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to create a local officers' compensation commission, MCL 117.5c. 

Sec. 2-56. - Created; purpose. 
    In accordance with the provisions of Act No. 8 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1972 (MCL 117.5), the city commission hereby creates a local officers' compensation commission, which shall determine the salaries of all local elected officials. 
(Code 1976, § 2-36) 
Sec. 2-57. - Composition. 
    The commission shall consist of seven members who are registered electors of the city and who are appointed by the mayor and confirmed by a majority of the members of the city commission who are elected and serving. 
(Code 1976, § 2-37; Ord. No. 04-520, § 1, 10-25-04) 
Sec. 2-58. - Terms of members; vacancies. 
(a)  To effectuate the change from a five-member commission to a seven-member commission as required by Act No. 8 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1972 (MCL 117.5c), as amended, due to an increase in the city's population, the terms of the five members presently serving on the commission are hereby terminated and a new seven-member commission shall be appointed pursuant to section 2-57 and subsection (b) within 30 days of the effective date of the ordinance amending section 2-57 to establish a seven-member commission. 
(b)  The members first appointed to the compensation commission following the effective date of the ordinance amending section 2-57 to establish a seven-member commission shall be appointed one each for respective terms of one, two, three, four, five, six, and seven years provided that each of such initial terms shall end on September 30 of the respective year following appointment. 
(c)  Filling of vacancies. 
(1)  As vacancies occur in the original terms of the first members of the compensation commission, a successor shall be appointed before October 1 for a full term of seven years, and after the original appointments, each member of the compensation commission shall be appointed for a term of seven years except as provided in subsection (b)(2). 
(2)  If any vacancy shall occur in the membership of the compensation commission, such vacancy shall be filled for the remainder of the unexpired term by appointment of the mayor and confirmation by a majority of the members elected and serving on the city commission. 
(Code 1976, §§ 2-38, 2-39; Ord. No. 04-520, § 2, 10-25-04) 
Sec. 2-59. - Noneligibility of government employees. 
    No member or employee of the legislative, judicial or executive branch of any level of government or members of the immediate family of such member or employee shall be eligible to be a member of the compensation commission. 
(Code 1976, § 2-40) 
Sec. 2-60. - Election of chairman and secretary; quorum; compensation of members. 
(a)  The compensation commission shall elect a chairman and a secretary from among the members of the compensation commission in each year for terms expiring at midnight on the following September 30. 
(b)  A majority of the members of the compensation commission shall constitute a quorum for conducting the business of the commission. The compensation commission shall take no action or make determinations without a concurrence of a majority of the members appointed and serving on the compensation commission. 
(c)  The members of the compensation commission shall receive no compensation but shall be entitled to their actual and necessary expenses incurred in the performance of their duties. 
(Code 1976, § 2-41) 
Sec. 2-61. - Determinations of commission. 
(a)  The compensation commission shall determine the salaries of all elected officials of the city. The compensation commission shall meet for not more than 15 session days in every odd year and the compensation commission shall make its determination within 45 calendar days on which the compensation commission meets and a quorum of members is present. The determinations of the compensation commission shall be immediately filed with the city clerk. 
(b)  The determinations of the compensation commission shall be effective 30 days following their filing with the city clerk unless rejected by the city commission by a resolution adopted by two-thirds of the members of the city commission elected to and serving on such legislative body. In case of rejection by the city commission, the existing salary shall prevail. Any expense allowance or reimbursement paid to elected officials in addition to salary shall be for expenses incurred in the course of city business and accounted for to the city. 
(Code 1976, § 2-42) 
Secs. 2-62-2-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - FINANCE[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Ordinances promising or guaranteeing payment of money to city or authorizing issuance of bonds not affected by code or ordinance adopting code, § 1-5(1); appropriation ordinances and ordinances providing for levee of taxes and for annual budgets not affected by code or ordinance adopting code, § 1-5(2); fiscal year, adoption of budget for downtown development authority, § 58-68; fiscal year, budget for downtown redevelopment management board, § 58-96; disposition of surplus funds from special assessments, § 66-23. 
State Law reference- Municipal finance act, MCL 131.1 et seq. 

Sec. 2-81. - Budget procedure. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided by resolution of the city commission, the budget shall be prepared and submitted in accordance with the procedure in this section. 
(b)  In accordance with section 9.2 of the Charter, each department head shall submit to the city clerk an itemized estimate of the expenditures for the next fiscal year for the department or activities under his control. The city clerk shall forward these estimates to the budget committee and the city manager. The city commission shall then conduct a special meeting at which all department heads shall review their itemized estimates of expenditures as originally submitted to the city clerk. Following the special meeting, the budget committee and the city manager shall review the budget recommendations of the city commission. The city manager shall, in conjunction with the budget committee, prepare the complete itemized budget proposal for the next fiscal year in compliance with section 9.3 of the Charter and submit it to the city commission. The budget shall then be reviewed and approved by the city commission in accordance with the procedure set forth in sections 9.4 and 9.5 of the Charter. 
(Code 1976, § 2-6(g)) 
Sec. 2-82. - Recovery of expenses related to utility line failure or railroad fire. 
(a)  Purpose. This section is adopted to provide authority and a mechanism for the reimbursement of costs for certain fire and emergency services rendered by the city. 
(b)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings provided in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Assessable costs means charges and fees incurred by the city including, without limitation, the: per-hour charges for city vehicles established by resolution of the city commission; costs of personnel, supplies and equipment of the city utilized in connection with the incident; costs charged to the city for the services of a hazmat unit including, without limitation, personnel, supplies and equipment; and any costs charged to the city for services of a third party, and administration, billing and collection costs, including attorneys' fees. 
    Hazardous condition means an occurrence resulting in a risk to the physical welfare of persons or property in the immediate area of the situation (such as downed utility lines or gas leaks not in an occupied structure), requiring a fire department or emergency services response. 
    Person means a natural person, corporation, partnership or any other entity with legal capacity. 
    Railroad means any person, its respective lessees, trustees, or receivers, or other legal entity operating in this state either as a common carrier for hire or for private use as a carrier of persons or property upon cars operated upon stationary rails and includes any person, lessee, trustee, or receiver or other legal entity owning railroad tracks. 
    Railroad fire means a burning rail car or contents, or burning vegetation (e.g., grass, brush) adjacent to the railroad rails, track, or roadbed originating from railroads/trains passing over the rails, track or roadbed after the fire department or other city department is on scene for one hour. 
    Utility means all persons, organizations, municipal or other authority that provides gas, electric, water, steam, sewer, energy, telecommunications, cable television or other services of a similar nature. 
    Utility line failure means downed power lines; gas pipeline breaks (including ruptures and punctures); the disabling of any transmission or service line, cable, conduit, pipeline, wire or the like used to provide, collect or transport electricity, natural gas, communication or electronic signals, water, steam, or sanitary or storm sewage; or other mishaps occurring in connection with the activities of utilities or their suppliers after the fire department or other city department is on scene for one hour. 
(c)  Responsible parties. Persons owning, maintaining or operating a railroad or utility are responsible for and shall pay the assessable costs incurred by the city in responding to a hazardous condition occasioned by a railroad fire or utility line failure. 
(d)  Billing and collection. Following the conclusion of a railroad fire or utility line failure, the fire chief shall prepare and transmit an invoice to the responsible party or responsible parties for payment. The invoice shall demand full payment within 30 days of the date of the mailing of the bill. Any additional expenses that become known to the fire chief following transmittal of the bill to a responsible party shall be billed in the same manner on a subsequent bill. For any amounts due that remain unpaid after 30 days, the city shall impose a late charge of one percent per month or fraction thereof. Failure to pay the invoice within 30 days of the date of mailing shall constitute a violation of this Code. 
(e)  Other remedies. The recovery of assessable costs imposed under this section shall not relieve or limit the liability of any responsible party under any other local ordinance, state or federal law, rule or regulation. The remedies provided for in this section shall apply in all circumstances except where, pursuant to section 2-83, billing has already occurred. 
(f)  Appeal procedure. A person who receives a bill under this section may request a meeting with the fire chief or his designee to appeal all or part of the assessable costs. The person must request a meeting in writing within 14 calendar days of the date of the billing. The fire chief or his designee may affirm, modify or waive the assessable costs if he finds that: 
(1)  An error was made with respect to the nature of the incident; 
(2)  An error was made in calculating the assessable costs; or, 
(3)  The person to which the bill was sent is not liable under the terms of this section. 
The fire chief or his designee shall mail his determination regarding the appeal within 14 days of the scheduled meeting, which determination shall identify the basis for the decision. 
If, after receiving the fire chief or his designee's determination, the person is not satisfied, it may request an opportunity to appear before the city manager to seek relief from the assessable costs charged. Such an appeal must be made in writing within 14 calendar days of the mailing of the fire chief or his designee's determination and must identify why the billing should be modified or overturned. The city manager shall consider the grounds for relief stated herein as well as the following factors: 
(1)  The degree to which the imposition of assessable costs presents a unique situation unlikely to be repeated; and 
(2)  Whether granting the appeal would do harm to the intent and purpose of this section. 
Failure to file a timely written request of appeal constitutes a waiver of the right to relief and further constitutes an agreement to pay the costs involved. The city manager is authorized to affirm, modify or overturn the fire chief or his designee's determination with respect to the imposition of assessable costs in the event of an appeal. 
(g)  Enforcement. If any responsible party fails to reimburse the city for the costs described in this section, the city may bring an action in a court of competent jurisdiction, and may take any other lawful action, to collect such costs. In addition, if a responsible party who fails to reimburse the city for the costs described in this section is an owner or taxpayer of the property on which a railroad fire or utility line failure occurred, the city may add such costs to the tax roll as to such property and to levy and collect such costs in the same manner as provided for the levy and collection of real property taxes against such property. The recovery of costs does not limit or modify the liability of any responsible party under local ordinance, or state or federal law, rule or regulation. 
(Ord. No. 09-570, § 1, 3-23-09) 
Sec. 2-83. - Recovery of expenses related to hazardous materials. 
(a)  Purpose. This section is adopted to provide authority and a mechanism for the reimbursement of fire and emergency service costs incurred by the city in response to a suspected or actual hazardous materials release. 
(b)  Definitions . The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings provided in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Assessable costs means charges and fees incurred by the city including, without limitation, the: per hour charges for city vehicles established by resolution of the city commission, costs of personnel, supplies and equipment of the city utilized in connection with the incident, costs charged to the city for the services of a HazMat unit including, without limitation, personnel, supplies and equipment, and any costs charged to the city for services of a third party, and administration, billing and collection costs, including attorneys' fees. 
    Hazardous materials means materials which pose a substantial present or potential hazard to human life, health and safety, including, but not limited to, hazardous substances as defined in 42 USC section 9601(14), as amended, or other substances that have been classified by the state or federal government or any of their departments or agencies to be hazardous or toxic. 
    HazMat unit means any vehicle provided by a third-party equipped with apparatus and operated by third-party personnel to provide emergency service at the request of the city in response to a suspected or actual release or other similar occurrence involving hazardous materials. 
    Release means any actual or threatened leaking, spilling, pumping, pouring, emitting, emptying, discharging, injecting, leaching, dumping, or disposing into the environment (including air, soil, ground water and surface water). 
    Responsible party means any person, firm, corporation, association, partnership, commercial entity, consortium, joint venture, government entity or any other legal entity that causes or is responsible for a release of a hazardous material, either actual or threatened, or is an owner, tenant, occupant or party in control of property onto which or from which hazardous materials release. 
(c)  Duty to remove . In the event of a release of any hazardous materials, it is the duty of all responsible parties to remove such hazardous materials immediately and to undertake and complete a total cleanup of the area in such a manner as to ensure that the hazardous materials are fully removed and the area is fully restored to its condition prior to the release of hazardous materials, or to conditions or standards established by the state department of environmental quality pursuant to applicable law or regulation. If the responsible party or parties fail to comply with this section, the city shall have the right to enter onto the property immediately and remove and conduct a cleanup of all such hazardous materials by city employees or by third parties. 
(d)  Responsible parties; reimbursement of city. When the city fire department or other city department responds to a call for assistance which involves hazardous materials, the responsible parties shall be obligated, jointly and severally, to reimburse the city, its agents, contractors and employees for all assessable costs incurred by the city. In addition, responsible parties who fail to comply with subsection 2-83(c) shall be obligated, jointly and severally, to reimburse the city, its agents, contractors and employees for all assessable costs incurred by the city in connection with the removal and cleanup of hazardous materials and the restoration of the property pursuant to subsection 2-83(c). 
(e)  Discretion of city. The decision to request the services of the HazMat unit or the services of any third party in connection with an incident involving hazardous materials shall be solely in the discretion of the fire chief or the commanding officer at the scene of the incident. 
(f)  Billing and collection. Following the conclusion of a hazardous materials incident, the fire chief shall prepare and transmit an invoice to the responsible party or responsible parties for payment. The invoice shall demand full payment within 30 days of the date of the mailing of the bill. Any additional expenses that become known to the fire chief following transmittal of the bill to a responsible party shall be billed in the same manner on a subsequent bill. For any amounts due that remain unpaid after 30 days, the city shall impose a late charge of one percent per month or fraction thereof. Failure to pay the invoice within 30 days of the date of mailing shall constitute a violation of this Code. 
(g)  Appeal procedure. A person who receives a bill under this section may request a meeting with the fire chief or his designee to appeal all or part of the assessable costs. The person must request a meeting in writing within 14 calendar days of the date of the billing. The fire chief or his designee may modify or waive the assessable costs if he finds that: (1) an error was made with respect to the nature of the incident; (2) an error was made in calculating the assessable costs; (3) the person(s) is not liable because the release was caused solely by a third party; or, (4) the person to which the bill was sent is not liable under the terms of this section. The fire chief or his designee shall mail his determination regarding the appeal (i.e., to affirm the initial billing or modify or waive the assessable costs) within 14 days of the scheduled meeting, which determination shall identify the basis for the decision. 
    If, after receiving the fire chief or his designee's determination, the person is not satisfied, it may request an opportunity to appear before the city manager to seek relief from the assessable costs charged. Such an appeal must be made in writing within 14 calendar days of the mailing of the fire chief or his designee's determination and must identify why the billing should be modified or overturned. The city manager shall consider the grounds for relief stated herein as well as the following factors: (1) the degree to which the imposition of assessable costs presents a unique situation unlikely to be repeated and (2) whether granting the appeal would do harm to the intent and purpose of this section. 
    Failure to file a timely written request of appeal constitutes a waiver of the right to relief and further constitutes an agreement to pay the costs involved. The city manager is authorized to affirm, modify or overturn the fire chief or his designee's determination with respect to the imposition of assessable costs in the event of an appeal. 
(h)  Enforcement. If any responsible party fails to reimburse the city for the costs described in this section, the city may bring an action in a court of competent jurisdiction, and may take any other lawful action, to collect such costs. In addition, if a responsible party who fails to reimburse the city for the costs described in this section is an owner or taxpayer of the property on which the release of hazardous materials occurred, the city may add such costs to the tax roll as to such property and to levy and collect such costs in the same manner as provided for the levy and collection of real property taxes against such property. The recovery of costs does not limit or modify the liability of any responsible party under local ordinance, or state or federal law, rule or regulation. 
(Ord. No. 09-570, § 2, 3-23-09; Ord. No. 13-616, § 1, 6-10-13 ) 
Sec. 2-84. - Issuance of permits, approvals or contracts to persons indebted to the city. 
    The city shall not review or act on a request for the approvals of plans, plats, permits, contracts or similar matters if the applicant is in default of real or personal property taxes due to the city or if the applicant is otherwise financially indebted to the city. Pending appeals filed in good faith in a court or tribunal of competent jurisdiction shall not prohibit the city from acting as requested. 
( Ord. No. 13-615, § 1, 6-10-13 ) 
Chapter 6 - ALCOHOLIC LIQUORS[1] 
  

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Unlawful to frequent or operate establishment where intoxicating liquor is illegally sold, § 50-25. 
State Law reference- Liquor control act, MCL 436.1 et seq. 

Sec. 6-1. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the terms "alcoholic liquor," "beer," "wine," "spirits" and all other terms which are used in this chapter and which are defined in the Michigan Liquor Control Code of 1998, Act No. 58 of the Public Acts of 1998, as amended shall have the meanings ascribed to them in such act. 
(Code 1976, § 4-1; Ord. No. 13-613, § 1, 4-22-13 ) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 6-2. - Consumption of liquor in public place; exception. 
(a)  Except as provided in subsection (b), it shall be unlawful for any person to drink any alcoholic liquor in any public street, city park, or other such public place in the city. 
(b)  Subsection (a) shall not prohibit the sale, possession, or consumption of beer and wine sold by a city-approved nonprofit organization within City Central Park during the annual Walker City Festival on dates designated by the city commission and pursuant to and in compliance with a special license issued to the nonprofit organization by the Michigan Liquor Control Commission for the sale of beer and wine for on-premises consumption. The sale, possession, or consumption of beer and wine permitted under this subsection shall be limited to the licensed premises within City Central Park under the special license. 
(Code 1976, § 10-40.1; Ord. No. 04-508, § 1, 4-12-04; Ord. No. 05-527, § 1, 3-28-05) 
Sec. 6-3. - Public intoxication; endangering life, property or creating a disturbance. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to be intoxicated in a public place and either to endanger directly the safety of another person or property or to act in a manner that causes a public disturbance. 
(Code 1976, § 10-40) 
State Law reference- Intoxicated person defined as a disorderly person, MCL 750.167(1)(e). 
Sec. 6-4. - License requirements for on-premises consumption. 
(a)  No person shall sell any alcoholic liquor for consumption on the premises in any establishment in the city without first obtaining a license as required by all applicable local, state and federal laws and regulations. 
(b)  Applications for the approval of an on-premises license as required by law shall be made to the city clerk in writing, signed by the applicant (if an individual) or by a duly authorized agent thereof (if a partnership or corporation), verified by oath or affidavit, and shall contain, at a minimum, the following statements and information: 
(1)  The name, age and address of the applicant in the case of an individual; or, in the case of a partnership, the persons entitled to share in the profits thereof; or, in the case of a corporation, the objects for which organized, the names and addresses of the officers and directors, and the names and addresses of all stockholders. 
(2)  The citizenship of the applicant, his place of birth, and, if a naturalized citizen, the time and place of his naturalization. 
(3)  The nature of the applicant's principal business. 
(4)  The length of time the applicant has been in business of that character or, in the case of a corporation, the date when its charter was issued. 
(5)  The location and description of the premises or place of business which is to be operated under the license. 
(6)  A statement whether the applicant has made application for a similar or other license on premises other than described in the application, and the disposition of the other application. 
(7)  A statement that the applicant has never been convicted of a felony and is not disqualified to receive a license by reason of any matter or requirement contained in this ordinance or the laws and regulations of the State of Michigan. 
(8)  A statement that neither the applicant nor the establishment at which the license will be used will violate any local, state or federal laws and regulations in the conduct of its business. 
(9)  The application shall be accompanied by building and similar plans showing the entire structure and premises and the specific areas where the license is to be utilized. The plans shall demonstrate adequate off-street parking, lighting, refuse disposal facilities, and where appropriate, adequate plans for screening and noise control. The plan shall further identify in a manner consistent with the provisions of this chapter the establishment's dining table capacity, counter space for the dispensing and sale of spirits, and the square footage for associated dining table capacity, seating capacity, and kitchen and food storage facility areas. 
(10)  The applicant shall provide as a part of the application all information which is required by the Michigan Liquor Control Commission for an application to the state for the license and, in addition, any other information deemed necessary by the city commission to adequately review the application as provided by this chapter and authorized by law. 
(c)  The city clerk, after receiving an application under this section and any associated fee as established from time to time by resolution of the city commission, shall refer the application to the director of the department of public safety and the director of the community development department for each department's review and recommendation to the city commission. After receiving reports from such offices, the city clerk shall present the application to the city commission for its review and possible approval or disapproval. If approved, the city clerk shall furnish a resolution of approval to the applicant, which he or she shall forward to the Michigan Liquor Control Commission. 
(d)  The city commission may not approve an application for an on-premises license, and may object to the renewal or request revocation of any existing license for, where the applicant or licensee has engaged in, or has permitted to occur on or involving the licensed premises, any one or more of the following: 
(1)  Previous revocation or nonrenewal of a license held by the licensee or applicant for cause. 
(2)  Violation of any of the restrictions on licenses set forth in this chapter. 
(3)  Maintenance or permitting the existence of a nuisance of any kind upon the premises. 
(4)  Fraudulent information provided upon an original application or application for renewal to any governmental entity. 
(5)  The consumption of spirits, if licensed to sell only beer or wine, or both beer and wine. 
(6)  Dancing or live entertainment open to the public, with or without an admission charge, without a valid permit. 
(7)  Disorderly conduct or action which disturbs the peace and good order of the neighborhood. 
(8)  Incidents of prostitution, solicitation for prostitution, or larceny on the premises. 
(9)  Gambling activity on the premises. 
(10)  Any unlawful possession, sale, or use of controlled substances or alcoholic beverages on the premises. 
(11)  Use of interior lighting which is insufficient to enable a person with average vision to clearly see all unobstructed areas within the premises. 
(12)  The violation of any provision of the city code, or any violation of Michigan or federal law which is designed to protect the public health, safety or welfare, or any rule or regulation adopted pursuant to any such Michigan or federal law has occurred. 
(13)  Nonpayment of any federal, State of Michigan, or local tax or special assessment. 
(14)  Failure by the licensee, or the licensee's agent or employee to fully cooperate with any federal, state, county or city official, including city firefighters and police officers acting in the line of duty. 
(15)  Where the application is submitted by a partnership in which not all of the members of the partnership qualify to receive a license as provided by this chapter and any other applicable laws and regulations. 
(16)  Where the application is submitted by a corporation, partnership in which not all of the officers, managers or directors thereof, would be eligible to receive a license for any reason. 
(17)  Where the applicant does not own the premises for which a license is sought or who does not have a lease for the premises (or who will not own the premises or have an option to lease the premises) for the full period for which the license is issued; or a person, corporation or partnership that, as determined by the city commission, does not have sufficient financial assets to carry on or maintain the business. 
(18)  A person whose license is in escrow if the city commission finds that the owner of the escrowed license is in violation of any local, state or federal law or regulation, or if the license is held in escrow for more than one year. 
(19)  Any law enforcement official or member of the city commission. 
(20)  Any premises where it is determined by the city commission that the premises do not, or will not reasonably soon after commencement of operations, have adequate off-street parking, lighting, refuse disposal facilities, screening, noise or nuisance control. 
(21)  Any premises where the city commission determines that the proposed location is inappropriate, considering factors including, without limitation, the desirability of establishing a location in developed, commercial areas, in preference to isolated, undeveloped areas; the impact on adjacent residents and property owners; traffic safety; accessibility to the site from abutting roads to accommodate the commercial activity; distance from public or private schools for minors; proximity of an inconsistent zoning classification; and accessibility from primary roads or state highways. 
(22)  Any premises where any real or personal property taxes, special assessments, sewer charges or water charges, or any other obligations due and payable to the city are delinquent and remain unpaid. 
(e)  Notwithstanding the foregoing, in determining whether to approve an application for a license, the city commission may review and consider any factors it deems relevant and appropriate to protect the public health, safety and welfare. 
(f)  Following approval of an application for a license by the city commission, the applicant shall provide to the city clerk a complete copy of the final application filed with the state. If the applicant fails to file an application for a license with the state within 180 days of the date of issuance of approval by the city commission as provided by this section, the approval granted by the city commission for the license shall automatically lapse and be of no further force or effect. 
(g)  If the licensee (or any successors in interest) fails to maintain full compliance with the requirements of this chapter or other applicable laws, the city commission may recommend that the license not be renewed or request revocation of the license at its sole discretion. 
(h)  Notwithstanding any provision of this chapter, the city commission is under no obligation to approve any available license within the city at any time. No applicant shall have a right to the issuance of a license and the city commission reserves its rights to exercise discretion to determine which applications, if any, to approve as it deems to be in the best interests of the city. Further, no applicant has the right to have its application processed and the city commission reserves its right to take no action with respect to any application for approval filed with the city. The city commission may maintain a list of all applicants and review the list when, in its discretion, it determines that the issuance of a license is in the best interests of the city at large and for needs, benefit, and convenience of its citizens. 
(i)  This chapter shall not operate to limit any power or authority vested in the city commission under applicable laws, regulations and constitutions, and shall be vested authority and not in derogation of that authority. 
(Code 1976, § 4-2(a)-(d); Ord. No. 94-431, § 1, 3-22-94; Ord. No. 13-613, § 2, 4-22-13 ) 
Sec. 6-5. - Procedure and criteria for nonrenewal or revocation. 
(a)  Procedure. Before filing an objection to the renewal of or a request for revocation of an on-premises license with the Michigan Liquor Control Commission, the city commission shall serve the license holder with notice of a hearing on the matter to be held by the city commission. The notice shall be served by first class mail, mailed not less than ten days prior to the hearing, and shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The nature of the action under consideration by the city commission (i.e., objection to renewal or request for revocation). 
(2)  The reasons for the proposed review. 
(3)  The date, time and place of the hearing. 
(4)  A statement that the licensee may present evidence and testimony and confront adverse witnesses, if any, and has the right to be represented. 
    Within a reasonable time following the hearing, the city commission shall provide the license holder and the Michigan Liquor Control Commission with a written statement of its findings and determination. 
(b)  Criteria for nonrenewal or revocation. The city commission may recommend nonrenewal or revocation of an on-premises license if it determines, based upon a preponderance of the evidence presented at the hearing, that any of the following circumstances apply: 
(1)  The licensee has violated any provision of this chapter; 
(2)  Any of the criteria described in section 6-4(d) apply to the licensee or to the premises; or 
(3)  The licensee has not engaged in, or has discontinued or terminated, the sale of beer and wine or spirits under the license at the premises for 12 or more consecutive months. 
(Code 1976, § 4-2(e); Ord. No. 94-431, § 2, 3-22-94; Ord. No. 13-613, § 3, 4-22-13 ) 
Sec. 6-5A. - Nudity prohibited. 
(a)  A licensee shall not allow in or upon the licensed premises any person in a state of nudity. 
(b)  A licensee shall not hire, employ, or procure a person to appear in or upon the licensed premises in a state of nudity. 
(c)  No person shall appear in or upon premises licensed for the sale of alcoholic liquor in a state of nudity. 
(d)  A licensee shall not allow in or upon the licensed premises the showing of films, television, slides, or other electronic reproductions which depict scenes wherein any person appears in a state of nudity. This prohibition does not apply to any public broadcast television transmission from a federally licensed station. 
(e)  For purposes of this section, "nudity" means a state of undress to so as to expose to the view of another person the following body parts without any covering or with less than a fully opaque covering: 
(1)  The whole or part of the pubic region; 
(2)  The whole or part of the anus; 
(3)  The whole or part of the buttocks; 
(4)  The whole or part of the genitals; or 
(5)  Any portion of the female breast below the top of the areola. A woman's breast feeding of a baby does not constitute nudity irrespective of whether or not the nipple is covered during or incidental to the feeding. 
(f)  For purposes of this section, "licensee" means a person or entity having a license to sell alcoholic liquor and the owners, officers, agents, and employees of such person or entity. 
(g)  A violation of any provision of this section is a misdemeanor punishable by a fine not to exceed $500.00 (plus costs of prosecution) or by imprisonment not to exceed 90 days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. Each day on which a violation continues constitutes a separate offense. In addition to any remedies available at law, the city may bring an action for an injunction or other process against a person to restrain, prevent, or abate any violation of this section. A violation of this section shall also constitute a basis for the city commission to recommend nonrenewal or revocation of a liquor license or permit pursuant to section 6-5 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 97-507, § 2, 12-22-97) 
Sec. 6-6. - City license for sale for on-premises consumption. 
    No person shall engage in the business of selling alcoholic liquor for consumption on the premises in any establishment in the city without first obtaining a business license and paying any applicable fee in accordance with chapter 22, article I. Licenses required by this section are not transferable. 
(Code 1976, § 4-3; Ord. No. 09-568, § 1, 3-9-09) 
Sec. 6-7. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 13-613, § 4, adopted April 22, 2013 , repealed § 6-7, which pertained to recommendation of city commission as to issuance of state license for specially designated merchants and distributors and derived from the Code of 1976, § 4-4. 
Sec. 6-8. - Restriction on hours and days of sale. 
(a)  December 24, December 25. No alcoholic liquor shall be sold at retail between the hours of 11:59 p.m. on December 24 and 12:00 noon on December 25. 
(b)  State regulations. Wherever closing hours established by the state liquor control commission or by the statutes of the state are more restrictive than provided in this section, the closing hours shall be as provided by such regulations or state statutes. 
(Code 1976, § 4-8; Ord. No. 09-568, § 2, 3-9-09; Ord. No. 11-594, § 1, 2-28-11) 
Sec. 6-9. - Requirements for establishments selling spirits for on-premises consumption; waiver. 
(a)  In addition to other requirements of this chapter, all establishments with a class C or class B license issued by the state, in which spirits are sold for consumption on the premises, shall have a dining table capacity for 125 or more persons and, if additional counter space is provided for the dispensing and sale of spirits, such counter space shall accommodate not more than 20 percent of the seating capacity of the entire dining room. 
(b)  No establishment shall be considered to have the dining table capacity and seating capacity required by subsection (a) unless the square footage of the dining area shall provide for not less than 15 square feet of space per patron and unless such establishment shall have combined kitchen and food storage facilities having a square footage equal to at least 65 percent of the square footage of the dining table area. 
(c)  Subsections (a) and (b) may be waived by the city commission for an establishment seeking the issuance or transfer of a class C license only if the city commission determines in its discretion that the waiver is in the best interests of the city and the public, the city commission determines in its discretion that the standards in section 6-4 are satisfied, and the establishment satisfies all of the following criteria, as determined by the city commission: 
(1)  The establishment has a dining table capacity of not less than 100 persons based on 15 square feet of space per patron as provided in subsection (b); 
(2)  The establishment has combined kitchen and food storage facilities having a square footage equal to not less than 50 percent of the square footage of the dining table area; 
(3)  The gross receipts of the establishment from the sale of food and other goods and services excluding beer, wine, spirits, or other alcoholic liquor are reasonably expected to exceed 60 percent of the total monthly gross receipts of such establishment; and 
(4)  The establishment does not have a "drive thru" or "drive up" window for the sale of food, beverages, or other items to customers in vehicles. 
(5)  The establishment has operated as a bona fide restaurant within the city for at least one year prior to the application for a waiver without a class C or other license to sell alcoholic liquor. 
(6)  The seating available at a bar or similar counter space for the dispensing of alcoholic beverages shall be limited to no more than ten patrons. 
    Nothing in this subsection shall be construed to limit the city commission's discretion under section 6-4 of this article or any discretion of the city commission in reviewing the waiver, it being the intent of this subsection to reserve the city commission's discretion to the fullest extent of the law. The city commission shall consider an application for a waiver for the issuance of a new license as provided in this section. Before approving any transfer of a class C license of an establishment with a waiver under this subsection, the city commission shall review the application for transfer by applying the standards and criteria for the waiver in this section except that subsection (6) shall not apply to a transfer to a new owner at the same location. 
(d)  A person who wishes to obtain a waiver pursuant to subsection (c) shall file an application, in duplicate, with the city clerk requesting the approval of the city commission for such waiver. Such application shall be accompanied by financial statements from similar establishments operated by the applicant for their last full fiscal year preceding the application or other pertinent financial information showing that the establishment will derive at least 60 percent of its total monthly gross receipts from the sale of food and other goods and services excluding beer, wine, spirits, and other alcoholic liquor. An establishment obtaining a waiver and a class C license under subsection (c) shall at all times thereafter derive at least 60 percent of its total monthly gross receipts from the sale of food and other goods and services excluding the sale of beer, wine, spirits, or other alcoholic liquor. The establishment shall also submit to the city clerk on April 1 of each year an annual report showing monthly gross receipts in the form required by the clerk and such additional information as the city clerk shall require to determine whether or not the establishment is complying with the monthly gross receipt requirement of this subsection. The establishment shall also maintain accurate records of receipts and disbursements at all times in such a manner that receipts from the sale of food and beverages other than beer, wine, spirits, or other alcoholic liquor can be readily distinguished from receipts from the sale of beer, wine, spirits, or other alcoholic liquor. The establishment shall make such records available for inspection upon request by the city manager and his or her designee at any time during normal business hours. The city commission may revoke the waiver and seek revocation or nonrenewal of the license, pursuant to section 6-4 and section 6-5, if the establishment fails to continue to comply with the criteria for the waiver in subsection (c), fails to file its annual report or other required information pursuant to this subjection, fails to comply with any other provision of this subsection, or fails to comply with any other provision of this chapter. In addition, the city may seek all other remedies available at law or equity. Each day that a violation occurs shall be deemed a separate violation and shall be punishable as a misdemeanor pursuant to section 1-11 of the City Code in addition to other legal or equitable remedies available to the city. 
(Code 1976, § 4-5; Ord. No. 96-489, § 1, 9-23-96; Ord. No. 06-544, § 1, 3-27-06; Ord. No. 12-606, § 1, 4-28-12) 
Sec. 6-10. - Ventilation requirements for sales premises. 
    Adequate ventilation shall be provided in every establishment licensed for the sale of alcoholic liquor for consumption on the premises, with the use of fans, windows, transoms, ducts or other suitable means where there shall be sufficient air change to remove any objectionable odors. All air conditioning or hot air heating systems shall be provided with a makeup air supply duct which will supply a minimum of ten percent fresh air from outside to any area in which customers are served. If exhaust fans are used, there shall be adequate fresh air supplied to maintain a positive pressure in the licensed establishment. 
(Code 1976, § 4-6; Ord. No. 13-613, § 5, 4-22-13 ) 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18. 
Sec. 6-11. - Lighting requirements for sales premises. 
    Adequate natural or artificial lighting shall be provided in all parts of an establishment where alcoholic liquor is sold for consumption on the premises. Each licensee shall be responsible for proper lighting of his premises and at no time shall he permit or allow the standard of light to be reduced below three footcandles at table height in the darkest part of each room in the establishment. 
(Code 1976, § 4-7) 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18. 
Sec. 6-12. - Employment of minors in sales establishments; proof of age document. 
(a)  No person shall be employed to serve or handle any alcoholic liquor in any establishment where such liquor is sold for consumption on the premises, unless such person shall have attained the age of 18 years. 
(b)  All licensees must have in their possession a birth certificate or other official document showing the place and date of birth of each employee, which shall be available for inspection by police officers at all times. 
(Code 1976, § 4-13) 
Sec. 6-13. - Employees on sales premises prohibited from drinking or fraternizing with customers or soliciting the purchase of alcoholic beverages. 
(a)  No person having the management, ownership or control of any premises wherein any alcoholic liquor is sold for consumption on the premises shall permit any person employed in such business to drink alcoholic liquor with or visit or fraternize with any of the patrons of such place of business. 
(b)  No person having the management, ownership or control of any premises referred to in subsection (a) shall permit any female person to be present or remain upon such premises who shall solicit any customer or patron of such place to purchase any alcoholic or nonalcoholic beverage for himself, herself or any other person therein. This subsection shall not apply to any female waitress, manager or licensee regularly employed on the premises who accepts or serves an order to any customer or patron in the regular course of her employment. 
(Code 1976, § 4-16) 
Sec. 6-14. - Dancing on sales premises. 
    No dancing by patrons shall be permitted on any premises for which a license has been issued for the sale of any alcoholic liquor, unless expressly authorized by ordinance. This section shall not be construed to prohibit professional entertainment or floorshows. 
(Code 1976, § 4-14) 
Sec. 6-15. - Disorderly conduct on sales premises. 
    No person having the management, ownership or control of any premises in the city where any alcoholic liquor is sold for consumption on the premises shall permit any boisterous conduct, or, in any manner, the disturbance of the peace and good order of the neighborhood; nor shall any person frequenting such premises make or assist in making any noise, disturbance or improper diversion, by which the peace and good order of the neighborhood is disturbed. 
(Code 1976, § 4-15) 
Sec. 6-16. - Sale or delivery to intoxicated or disorderly persons. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, give, furnish or deliver any alcoholic liquor to any drunken or intoxicated person, to any disorderly person or to any habitual drunkard. 
(Code 1976, § 4-9) 
Sec. 6-17. - Sale or delivery to persons under 21 years of age. 
(a)  Alcoholic liquor shall not be sold or furnished to a person unless the person has attained 21 years of age. Subject to subsection (d), a person who knowingly sells or furnishes alcoholic liquor to a person who is less than 21 years of age, or who fails to make diligent inquiry as to whether the person is less than 21 years of age, is guilty of a misdemeanor, and in addition to other penalties may be ordered to perform community service. 
(b)  Reserved. 
(c)  If a violation occurs in an establishment that is licensed by the liquor control commission ("commission") for consumption of alcoholic liquor on the licensed premises, a person who is a licensee or the clerk, agent or employee of a licensee shall not be charged with a violation of subsection (a) unless the licensee or the clerk, agent or employee of the licensee knew or should have reasonably known with the exercise of due diligence that a person less than 21 years of age possessed or consumed alcoholic liquor on the licensed premises and the licensee or clerk, agent or employee of the licensee failed to take immediate corrective action. 
(d)  A licensee shall not be charged with a violation of subsection (a) unless enforcement action under section 6-19 is taken against the person less than 21 years of age who purchased or attempted to purchase, consumed or attempted to consume, or possessed or attempted to possess alcoholic liquor and, if applicable, enforcement action is taken under this section against the person 21 years of age or older who sold or furnished the alcoholic liquor to the person who is less than 21 years of age. However, this subsection does not apply under any of the following circumstances: 
(1)  The person against whom enforcement action is taken under section 6-19 or the person 21 years of age or older who sold or furnished alcoholic liquor to the person less than 21 years of age is not alive or is not present in this state at the time the licensee is charged. 
(2)  The violation of subsection (a) is the result of an undercover operation in which the person less than 21 years of age purchased or received alcoholic liquor under the direction of the person's employer and with the prior approval of the city attorney or local prosecutor's office as part of an employer-sponsored internal enforcement action. 
(3)  The violation of subsection (a) is the result of an undercover operation in which the person less than 21 years of age purchased or received alcoholic liquor under the direction of the city police department, state police, the commission or a local police agency as part of an enforcement action. However, any initial or contemporaneous purchase or receipt of alcoholic liquor by the person less than 21 years of age shall have been under the direction of the city police department, state police, the commission or the local police agency and shall have been part of the undercover operation. 
(e)  If a person less than 21 years of age participates in an undercover operation in which the person less than 21 years of age is to purchase or receive alcoholic liquor under the supervision of a law enforcement agency, his or her parents or legal guardian shall consent to the participation if that person is less than 18 years of age. 
(f)  In an action for the violation of this section, proof that the defendant or the defendant's agent or employee demanded and was shown, before furnishing alcoholic liquor to a person less than 21 years of age, a motor vehicle operator's or chauffeur's license or a registration certificate issued by the federal selective service, or other bona fide documentary evidence of the age and identity of that person, shall be a defense to an action brought under this section. 
(g)  Reserved. 
(h)  As used in this section: 
    Corrective action means action taken by a licensee or a clerk, agent or employee of a licensee designed to prevent a person less than 21 years of age from further possessing or consuming alcoholic liquor on the licensed premises. Corrective action includes, but is not limited to, contacting a law enforcement agency and ejecting the person less than 21 years of age and any other person suspected of aiding and abetting the person less than 21 years of age. 
    Diligent inquiry means a diligent good faith effort to determine the age of a person, which includes at least an examination of an official Michigan operator's or chauffeur's license, an official Michigan personal identification card, or any other bona fide picture identification which establishes the identity and age of the person. 
(Code 1976, § 4-10; Ord. No. 95-471, § 2, 10-24-95) 
Sec. 6-18. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 97-494, § 11, adopted March 24, 1997, repealed § 6-18. Formerly, such section pertained to possession and transportation of alcoholic liquor by persons under 21 in a motor vehicle and derived from § 4-11 of the 1976 Code; Ord. No. 95-471, § 3, 10-24-95. 
Sec. 6-19. - Purchase, consumption, possession of alcoholic liquors or attempts of the same by persons under 21 years of age; fines and sanctions; exemptions. 
(a)  A minor shall not purchase or attempt to purchase alcoholic liquor, consume or attempt to consume alcoholic liquor, possess or attempt to possess alcoholic liquor, or have any bodily alcohol content, except as provided in this section. A minor who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction or guilty of a misdemeanor punishable as follows: 
(1)  For the first violation, the minor is responsible for a civil infraction and shall be fined not more than $100.00. The court may order a person under this subsection to participate in substance abuse services, perform community service, and/or to undergo substance abuse screening and assessment at his or her own expense as described in subsection (d). A minor may be found responsible or admit responsibility only once under this subsection or a federal or state law or local ordinance substantially corresponding to this subsection. 
(2)  If the violation occurs after one prior judgment, the minor is guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable by imprisonment for not more than 30 days if the court finds that the minor violated an order of probation, failed to successfully complete any treatment, screening, or community service ordered by the court, or failed to pay any fine for that conviction or juvenile adjudication, or by a fine of not more than $200.00, or both. The court may order a person under this subsection to participate in substance abuse services, perform community service, and/or to undergo substance abuse screening and assessment at his or her own expense as described in subsection (d). 
(3)  If the violation occurs after two or more prior judgments, the minor is guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable by imprisonment for not more than 60 days if the court finds that the minor violated an order of probation, failed to successfully complete any treatment, screening, or community service ordered by the court, or failed to pay any fine for that conviction or juvenile adjudication, or by a fine of not more than $500.00, or both. The court may order a person under this subsection to participate in substance abuse services, perform community service, and/or to undergo substance abuse screening and assessment at his or her own expense as described in subsection (d). 
(b)  An individual who furnishes fraudulent identification to a minor or, notwithstanding subsection (a), a minor who uses fraudulent identification to purchase alcoholic liquor, is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by imprisonment for not more than 93 days or a fine of not more than $100.00, or both. 
(c)  If an individual who pleads guilty to a misdemeanor violation of subsection (a)(2) or offers a plea of admission in a juvenile delinquency proceeding for a misdemeanor violation of subsection (a)(2), the court may take any action authorized in Section 703(3) of the Michigan Liquor Control Code of 1998, MCL 436.1703(3), as amended, including but not limited to deferring further proceedings, placing the individual on probation, discharging the individual, dismissing the proceedings, or entering an adjudication of guilt. A misdemeanor violation of subsection (a) successfully deferred, discharged, and dismissed under this subsection is considered a prior judgment for the purposes of subsection (a)(3). 
(d)  The court may order an individual found responsible for or convicted of violating subsection (a) to undergo screening and assessment by a person or agency as designated by the department-designated community mental health entity as defined in section 100a of the Mental Health Code, 1974 PA 258, MCL 330.1100a, to determine whether the individual is likely to benefit from rehabilitative services, including alcohol or drug education and alcohol or drug treatment programs. The court may order an individual subject to a misdemeanor conviction or juvenile adjudication of, or placed on probation regarding, a violation of subsection (a) to submit to a random or regular preliminary chemical breath analysis. The parent, guardian, or custodian of a minor who is less than 18 years of age and not emancipated under 1968 PA 293, MCL 722.1 to 722.6, may request a random or regular preliminary chemical breath analysis as part of the probation. 
(e)  The secretary of state shall suspend the operator's or chauffeur's license of an individual convicted of a second or subsequent violation of subsection (a) or of violating subsection (b) as provided in section 319 of the Michigan Vehicle Code, 1949 PA 300, being MCL 257.319, as amended. 
(f)  A peace officer who has reasonable cause to believe a minor has consumed alcoholic liquor or has any bodily alcohol content may request that the minor submit to a preliminary chemical breath analysis. If a minor does not consent to a preliminary chemical breath analysis, the analysis shall not be administered without a court order, but a peace officer may seek to obtain a court order. The results of a preliminary chemical breath analysis or other acceptable blood alcohol test are admissible in a civil infraction proceeding or criminal prosecution to determine if the minor has consumed or possessed alcoholic liquor or had any bodily alcohol content. 
(g)  This section does not prohibit a minor from possessing alcoholic liquor during regular working hours and in the course of his or her employment if employed by a person licensed by the Michigan Liquor Control Code of 1998, by the Michigan Liquor Control Commission, or by an agent of the Michigan Liquor Control Commission, if the alcoholic liquor is not possessed for his or her personal consumption. 
(h)  The following individuals are not considered to be in violation of subsection (a): 
(1)  A minor who (or who accompanies a person who) has consumed alcoholic liquor and who voluntarily presents himself or herself to a health facility or agency for treatment or for observation including, but not limited to, medical examination and treatment for any condition arising from a violation of sections 520b to 520g of the Michigan Penal Code, 1931 PA 328, MCL 750.520b to 750.520g, committed against the person. 
(2)  A minor who initiates contact with a peace officer or emergency medical services personnel for the purpose of obtaining medical assistance for a legitimate health care concern. 
(3)  A minor who is enrolled in a course offered by an accredited postsecondary educational institution and who consumes alcoholic liquor in an academic building of the institution under the supervision of a faculty member, if the purpose of the consumption is solely educational and is a requirement of the course. 
(4)  A minor who consumes sacramental wine in connection with religious services at a church, synagogue, or temple. 
(5)  A minor who participates in either or both of the following: 
a.  An undercover operation in which the minor purchases or receives alcoholic liquor under the direction of the person's employer and with the prior approval of the local prosecutor's office as part of an employer-sponsored internal enforcement action. 
b.  An undercover operation in which the minor purchases or receives alcoholic liquor under the direction of the state police, the commission, or a local police agency as part of an enforcement action unless the initial or contemporaneous purchase or receipt of alcoholic liquor by the minor was not under the direction of the police department, the state police, the Michigan Liquor Control Commission, or a local police agency and was not part of the undercover operation. 
(i)  Nothing in this section shall limit the civil or criminal liability of a vendor or the vendor's clerk, servant, agent, or employee for a violation of the Michigan Liquor Control Code of 1998. 
(j)  As used in this section: 
(1)  "Any bodily alcohol content" means either of the following: 
a.  An alcohol content of 0.02 grams or more per 100 milliliters of blood, per 210 liters of breath, or per 67 milliliters of urine. 
b.  Any presence of alcohol within a person's body resulting from the consumption of alcoholic liquor, other than consumption of alcoholic liquor as a part of a generally recognized religious service or ceremony. 
(2)  "Emergency medical services personnel" means that term as defined in section 20904 of the Public Health Code, 1978 PA 368, MCL 333.20904. 
(3)  "Health facility or agency" means that term as defined in section 20106 of the Public Health Code, 1978 PA 368, MCL 333.20106. 
(4)  "Minor" means a person less than 21 years of age. 
(5)  "Prior judgment" means that term as defined in section 703(18)(d) of Michigan Liquor Control Code of 1998, MCL 436.1703(18)(d), as amended. 
(Code 1976, § 4-12; Ord. No. 95-471, § 4, 10-24-95; Ord. No. 97-494, § 2, 3-24-97; Ord. No. 14-622, § 1, 7-28-14 ; Ord. No. 18-640 , § 2, 2-12-18) 
Sec. 6-20. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 18-640 , § 3, adopted Feb. 12, 2018, repealed § 6-20, which pertained to enforcement of section 6-18 and 6-19 and derived from Ord. No. 95-471, § 5, adopted Oct. 24, 1995. 
Chapter 10 - AMUSEMENTS AND ENTERTAINMENTS[1]
