(a)  No person shall purchase or receive, by sale, barter or exchange or otherwise, an article under a license issued pursuant to this article from any person between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. or as otherwise prohibited by law. Further, no person shall purchase or receive such an article from any person who is at the time intoxicated or visibly under the influence of alcohol or narcotics, from any person known by the dealer to be a thief or an associate of thieves or a prior recipient of stolen property, from any person the licensee or employee has reason to suspect of being such or from any minor under the age of eighteen years without written consent of the parent or guardian of such minor. 
(b)  No person shall purchase or receive, by sale, barter or exchange or otherwise, any article or item that the person knows to be stolen, reasonably should have been known to be stolen, or suspects as having been stolen except as specifically authorized by law enforcement authorities. 
(Ord. No. 09-576, § 1, 10-12-09) 
Sec. 22-177. - Thumbprints and identification of customers. 
(a)  Whenever a licensee or employee of licensee under this article purchases or receives any article or valuable thing as described in section 22-170, the licensee shall first take, on a form approved by the police department, in addition to the requirements of section 22-175, a legible print of the thumb of the right hand of the person from whom such article was received. If such person has no right thumb, the licensee shall take the legible print of the thumb of the left hand or a finger, which shall be so identified in writing by the licensee. 
(b)  The seller must provide the secondhand dealer with personal identification at the time of the transaction, in the form of a valid operator's license or a federal or state identification card which includes a photograph that positively matches the seller. The licensee shall obtain and maintain a copy of the identification. 
(Ord. No. 09-576, § 1, 10-12-09) 
Sec. 22-178. - Computerized reporting of transactions. 
(a)  Within 48 hours, at his/her own expense, every licensee under this article shall promptly complete and transmit, by electronic means, to the city's chief law enforcement official or his/her designee's computerized system(s), the data identifying all transactions in which the licensee received used goods by pawn, trade, or purchase. A transaction reported by electronic transmission under this subsection shall not be reported on paper forms unless the city's chief law enforcement official or his/her designee so requests. 
(b)  Each transaction report and record shall include the description of the article, serial number, make, model number, size, color, purchase/loan price, ticket number, dealer name and location, employee conducting transaction, place of storage/stock location, and customer information including operator's license number or other federal or state identification number, customer's name (last, first, middle), customer address, customer date of birth, physical description (height, weight, hair color, race, gender), appropriate fingerprint and any other information required by the local law enforcement agency. 
(Ord. No. 09-576, § 1, 10-12-09; Ord. No. 11-599, § 4, 7-11-11) 
Sec. 22-179. - License revocation. 
    If a licensee under this article or any of his or her agents, servants or employees is found criminally guilty of violating any of the provisions of this ordinance/chapter and/or any applicable state law, the chief of police may request that the city clerk revoke the license of the violator and the city clerk may, after providing notice to the licensee, revoke the license. The violator, following such revocation, shall not be permitted to carry on such business in the city for a period of one year. 
(Ord. No. 09-576, § 1, 10-12-09) 
Sec. 22-180. - Appeals. 
    Any person aggrieved by the action of the city clerk in the revocation of a license as a secondhand dealer, may appeal to the city commission or its designee by filing a written appeal with the city clerk within 14 days after notice of the action complained of has been mailed to such person's last known address. The appeal shall contain a written statement setting forth fully the grounds for the appeal. The city commission shall set a time and place for a hearing on such appeal and notice of such hearing shall be given to the appellant. The decision and order of the city commission on such appeal shall be final and conclusive. 
(Ord. No. 09-576, § 1, 10-12-09) 
Sec. 22-181. - Penalty 
    Violations of this article shall be a misdemeanor, punishable by imprisonment for up to 90 days, a fine, not to exceed $500.00, and costs of prosecution. 
(Ord. No. 09-576, § 1, 10-12-09) 
Secs. 22-182-22-199. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - MARIHUANA ESTABLISHMENTS AND FACILITIES 

Sec. 22-200. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    IHRA means the Industrial Hemp Research Act, 2014 PA 547, MCL 286.841 et seq. 
    Marihuana establishment means that term as defined in the MRTMA. 
    Marihuana facility means that term as defined in the MMFLA. 
    MMFLA means the Medical Marihuana Facilities Licensing Act, 2016 PA 281, as amended. 
    MMMA means the Michigan Medical Marihuana Act, 2008 IL 1, as amended. 
    MRTMA means the Michigan Regulation and Taxation of Marihuana Act, 2018 IL 1, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 18-644 , § 1, 11-12-18) 
Sec. 22-201. - Marihuana establishments and facilities prohibited. 
(a)  Pursuant to Section 6 of the MRTMA, marihuana establishments are prohibited within the boundaries of the city. 
(b)  Marihuana facilities are prohibited within the boundaries of the city. 
(Ord. No. 18-644 , § 1, 11-12-18) 
Sec. 22-202. - Rights unaffected by article. 
(a)  Except as specifically provided in section 22-201, this article shall not affect the rights or privileges of any individual or other person preserved under the MRTMA. 
(b)  This article does not affect the rights or privileges of a marihuana facility outside of the city to engage in activities within the city that it is permitted to engage in under the MMFLA within a municipality that has not authorized marihuana facilities to operate within its boundaries. 
(c)  This article does not affect the rights or privileges of registered qualifying patients or registered primary caregivers under the MMMA or the MMFLA. 
(d)  This article does not affect the rights or privileges of any individual or other person under the IHRA. 
(e)  This article does not affect the rights or privileges of any individual or other person under any other federal or state law, rule or regulation related to the medical use of marihuana. 
(Ord. No. 18-644 , § 1, 11-12-18) 
Chapter 23 - CABLE TV RATE REGULATION 
  

Sec. 23-1. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, [the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section.] All other words and phrases used in this chapter shall have the same meaning as defined in the Act and FCC rules. 
    Act means the Communications Act of 1934, as amended (and specifically as amended by the Cable Television Consumer Protection and Competition Act of 1992, Pub. L. 102-385), as may be amended from time to time. 
    Associated equipment means all equipment and services subject to regulation pursuant to 47 CFR § 76.923. 
    Basic cable service means "basic service" as defined in the FCC rules, and any other cable television service which is subject to rate regulation by the city pursuant to the Act and the FCC rules. 
    FCC means the Federal Communications Commission. 
    FCC rules means all rules of the FCC promulgated from time to time pursuant to the Act. 
    Increase in rates means an increase in rates or a decrease in programming or customer services. 
(Ord. No. 93-424, § 1, 9-15-93) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction, § 1-2. 
Sec. 23-2. - Purpose; interpretation. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to: (1) adopt regulations consistent with the Act and the FCC rules with respect to basic cable service rate regulation; and (2) prescribe procedures to provide a reasonable opportunity for consideration of the views of interested parties in connection with basic cable service rate regulation by the city. This chapter shall be implemented and interpreted consistent with the Act and FCC rules. 
(Ord. No. 92-18, § 1, 1-20-92) 
Sec. 23-3. - Rate regulations promulgated by FCC. 
    In connection with the regulation of rates for basic cable service and associated equipment, the city shall follow all FCC rules. 
(Ord. No. 92-18, § 1, 1-20-92) 
Sec. 23-4. - Filing; additional information; burden of proof. 
(a)  A cable operator shall submit its schedule of rates for the basic service tier and associated equipment or a proposed increase in such rates in accordance with the Act and the FCC rules. The cable operator shall include as part of its submission such information as is necessary to show that its schedule of rates or its proposed increase in rates complies with the Act and the FCC rules. The cable operator shall file ten copies of the schedule or proposed increase with the city clerk. For purposes of this chapter, the filing of the cable operator shall be deemed to have been made when at least ten copies have been received by the city clerk. The city council may, by resolution or otherwise, adopt rules and regulations prescribing the information, data and calculations which must be included as part of the cable operator's filing of the schedule of rates or a proposed increase. 
(b)  In addition to information and data required by rules and regulations of the city pursuant to subsection (a) above, a cable operator shall provide all information requested by the city manager in connection with the city's review and regulation of existing rates for the basic service tier and associated equipment or a proposed increase in these rates. The city manager may establish deadlines for submission of the requested information and the cable operator shall comply with such deadlines. 
(c)  A cable operator has the burden of providing that its schedule of rates for the basic service tier and associated equipment or a proposed increase in such rates complies with the Act and the FCC rules including, without limitation, 47 USC § 543 and 47 CFR §§ 76.922 and 76.923. 
(Ord. No. 92-18, § 1, 1-20-92) 
Sec. 23-5. - Proprietary information. 
(a)  If this chapter, any rules or regulations adopted by the city pursuant to section 23-4(a), or any request for information pursuant to section 23-4(b) requires the production of proprietary information, the cable operator shall produce the information. However, at the time the allegedly proprietary information is submitted, a cable operator may request that specific, identified portions of its response be treated as confidential and withheld from public disclosure. The request must state the reason why the information should be treated as proprietary and the facts that support those reasons. The request for confidentiality will be granted if the city determined that the preponderance of the evidence shows that nondisclosure is consistent with the provisions of the Freedom of Information Act, 5 U.S.C. § 552. The city shall place in a public file for inspection any decision that results in information being withheld. If the cable operator requests confidentiality and the request is denied, (1) where the cable operator is proposing a rate increase, it may withdraw the proposal, in which case the allegedly proprietary information will be returned to it; or (2) the cable operator may seek review within five working days of the denial in any appropriate forum. Release of the information will be stayed pending review. 
(b)  Any interested party may file a request to inspect material withheld as proprietary with the city. The city shall weight the policy considerations favoring nondisclosure against the reasons cited for permitting inspection in light of the facts of the particular case. It will then promptly notify the requesting entity and the cable operator that submitted the information as to the disposition of the request. It may grant, deny or condition a request. The requesting party or the cable operator may seek review of the decision by filing an appeal with any appropriate forum. Disclosure will be stayed pending resolution of an appeal. 
(c)  The procedures set forth in this section shall be construed as analogous to and consistent with the rules of the FCC regarding requests for confidentiality including, without limitation, 47 CFR § 0.459. 
(Ord. No. 92-18, § 1, 1-20-92) 
Sec. 23-6. - Public notice; initial review of rates. 
    Upon the filing of ten copies of the schedule of rates or the proposed increase in rates pursuant to section 23-4(a) above, the city clerk shall publish a public notice in a newspaper of general circulation in the city which shall state that: (1) the filing has been received by the city clerk and (except those parts which may be withheld as proprietary) is available for public inspection and copying; and (2) interested parties are encouraged to submit written comments on the filing to the city clerk not later than seven days after the public notice is published. The city clerk shall give notice to the cable operator of the date, time, and place of the meeting at which the city council shall first consider the schedule of rates or the proposed increase. This notice shall be mailed by first-class mail at least three days before the meeting. In addition, if a written staff or consultant's report on the schedule of rates or the proposed increase is prepared for consideration of the city council, then the city clerk shall mail a copy of the report by first-class mail to the cable operator at least three days before the meeting at which the city council shall first consider the schedule of rates or the proposed increase. 
(Ord. No. 92-18, § 1, 1-20-92) 
Sec. 23-7. - Tolling order. 
    After a cable operator has filed its existing schedule of rates or a proposed increase in these rates, the existing schedule of rates will remain in effect or the proposed increase in rates will become effective after 30 days from the date of filing under section 23-4(a) above unless the city council (or other properly authorized body or official) tolls the 30-day deadline pursuant to 47 CFR § 76.933 by issuing a brief written order, by resolution or otherwise, within 30 days of the date of filing. The city council may toll the 30-day deadline for an additional 90 days in cases not involving cost-of-service showings and for an additional 150 days in cases involving cost-of-service showings. 
(Ord. No. 92-18, § 1, 1-20-92) 
Sec. 23-8. - Public notice; hearing on basic cable service rates following tolling of 30-day deadline. 
    If a written order has been issued pursuant to section 23-7 and 47 CFR § 76.933 to toll the effective date of existing rages for the basic service tier and associated equipment or a proposed increase in these rates, the cable operator shall submit to the city and additional information required or requested pursuant to section 23-4 of this chapter. In addition, the city council shall hold a public hearing to consider the comments of interested parties within the additional 90-day or 150-day period, as the case may be. the city clerk shall publish a public notice of the public hearing in a newspaper of general circulation within the city which shall state: (1) the date, time, and place at which the hearing shall be held; (2) interested parties may appeal in person, by agent, or by letter at such hearing to submit comments on or objections to the existing rates or the proposed increase in rates; and (3) copies of the schedule of rates or the proposed increase in rates and related information (except those parts which may be withheld as proprietary) are available for inspection or copying from the office of the clerk. The public notice shall be published not less than 15 days before the hearing. In addition, the city clerk shall mail by first-class mail a copy of the public notice to the cable operator not less than 15 days before the hearing. 
(Ord. No. 92-18, § 1, 1-20-92) 
Sec. 23-9. - Staff or consultant report; written response. 
    Following the public hearing, the city manager shall cause a report to be prepared for the city council which shall (based on the filing of the cable operator, the comments or objections of interested parties, information requested from the cable operator and its response, staff or consultant's review, and other appropriate information) include a recommendation for the decision of the city council pursuant to section 23-10. The city clerk shall mail a copy of the report to the cable operator by first-class mail not less than 20 days before the city council acts under section 23-10. The cable operator may file a written response to the report with the city clerk. If at least ten copies of the response are filed by the cable operator with the city clerk within ten days after the report is mailed to the cable operator, the city clerk shall forward it to the city council. 
(Ord. No. 92-18, § 1, 1-20-92) 
Sec. 23-10. - Rate decisions and orders. 
    The city council shall issue a written order, by resolution or otherwise, which in whole or in part, approves the existing rates for basic cable service and associated equipment or a proposed increase in such rates, denies the existing rates or proposed increase, orders a rate reduction, prescribes a reasonable rate, allows the existing rates or proposed increase to become effective subject to refund, or orders other appropriate relief, in accordance with the FCC rules. If the city council issues an order allowing the existing rates or proposed increase to become effective subject to refund, it shall also direct the cable operator to maintain an accounting pursuant to 47 CFR § 76.933. The order specified in this section shall be issued within 90 days of the tolling order under section 23-7 in all cases not involving a cost-of-service showing. The order shall be issued within 150 days after the tolling order under section 23-7 in all cases involving a cost-of-service showing. 
(Ord. No. 92-18, § 1, 1-20-92) 
Sec. 23-11. - Refunds; notice. 
    The city council may order a refund to subscribers as provided in 47 CFR § 76.942. Before the city council orders any refund to subscribers, the city clerk shall give at least seven days' written notice to the cable operator by first-class mail of the date, time, and place at which the city council shall consider issuing a refund order and shall provide an opportunity for the cable operator to comment. The cable operator may appear in person, by agent, or by letter at such time for the purpose of submitting comments to the city council. 
(Ord. No. 92-18, § 1, 1-20-92) 
Sec. 23-12. - Written decisions; public notice. 
    Any order of the city council pursuant to section 23-10 or section 23-11 shall be in writing, shall be effective upon adoption by the city council, and shall be deemed released to the public upon adoption. The clerk shall public a public notice of any such written order in a newspaper of general circulation within the city which shall: (1) summarize the written decision; and (2) state that copies of the text of the written decision are available for inspection or copying from the office of the clerk. In addition, the city clerk shall mail a copy of the text of the written decision to the cable operator by first-class mail. 
(Ord. No. 92-18, § 1, 1-20-92) 
Sec. 23-13. - Rules and regulations. 
    In addition to rules promulgated pursuant to section 23-4, the city council may, by resolution or otherwise, adopt rules and regulations for basic cable service rate regulation proceedings (including, without limitation, the conduct of hearings), consistent with the Act and the FCC rules. 
(Ord. No. 92-18, § 1, 1-20-92) 
Sec. 23-14. - Failure to give notice. 
    The failure of the city clerk to give the notices or to mail copies of reports as required by this chapter shall not invalidate the decisions or proceedings of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 92-18, § 1, 1-20-92) 
Sec. 23-15. - Additional hearings. 
    In addition to the requirements of this chapter, the city council may hold additional public hearings upon such reasonable notice as the city council, in its sole discretion, shall prescribe. 
(Ord. No. 92-18, § 1, 1-20-92) 
Sec. 23-16. - Additional powers. 
    The city shall possess all powers conferred by the Act, the FCC rules, the cable operator's franchise, and all other applicable law. The powers exercised pursuant to the Act, the FCC rules, and this chapter shall be in addition to powers conferred by law or otherwise. The city may take any action not prohibited by the Act and the FCC rules to protect the public interest in connection with basic cable service rate regulation. 
(Ord. No. 92-18, § 1, 1-20-92) 
Sec. 23-17. - Failure to comply; remedies. 
    The city may pursue any and all legal and equitable remedies against the cable operator (including, without limitation, all remedies provided under a cable operator's consent agreement with the city) for failure to comply with the Act, the FCC rules, any orders or determinations of the city pursuant to this chapter, any requirements of this chapter, or any rules or regulations promulgated hereunder. Subject to applicable law, failure to comply with the Act, the FCC rules, any orders or determinations of the city pursuant to this chapter, any requirements of this chapter, or any rules and regulations promulgated hereunder, shall also be sufficient grounds for revocation or denial of renewal of a cable operator's consent agreement. 
(Ord. No. 92-18, § 1, 1-20-92) 
Sec. 23-18. - Conflicting provisions. 
    In the event of any conflict between this chapter and the provisions of any prior ordinance or any franchise, permit, consent agreement or other agreement with a cable operator, then the provisions of this chapter shall control. 
(Ord. No. 92-18, § 1, 1-20-92) 
Chapter 24 - MULTICHANNEL VIDEO PROVIDERS 

Sec. 24-1. - Consent agreement required. 
    All multichannel video providers shall obtain a consent agreement from the city prior to providing service to any resident, business or person within the city, and shall have a consent agreement in full force in effect at all times while such service is being provided. 
(Ord. No. 98-524, § 1, 7-13-98) 
Sec. 24-2. - Multichannel video provider defined. 
    Multichannel video provider means a person or entity who meets one or more of the following tests: 
(1)  The provider is a cable operator, as such term is defined in the Federal Cable Act, being Title VI of the Federal Communications Act of 1934, 47 U.S.C. Sections 521 and following, or is otherwise required to obtain a "franchise," as such term is defined in such Act. 
(2)  The provider is an operator of an open video system, as such term is defined in Title VI of the Federal Communications Act of 1934 and implementing regulations. 
(3)  Any person or entity who provides multichannel video service to a resident, business or person within the city, where such service is transmitted in whole or in part via wires or lines that are in or cross any public rights of way within the city. The preceding sentence shall apply whether the provider owns, leases or otherwise obtains the right to use such wires or lines, including wires or lines of a telecommunications provider used pursuant to tariff or otherwise for such purpose. Multichannel video service means multiple channels of video programming where the individual video channels are generally considered comparable to programming provided by a television broadcast station or by a direct to home satellite service. 
(4)  A person or entity providing multichannel video service who is otherwise required to obtain a franchise or consent agreement under applicable law. 
(Ord. No. 98-524, § 1, 7-13-98) 
Sec. 24-3. - Authorized city official. 
    The city manager or his or her designee is hereby designated as the authorized city official to issue municipal civil infraction citations (directing alleged violators to appear in court) or municipal civil infraction violation notices (directing alleged violators to appear at the municipal chapter violations bureau) for violations under this chapter as provided by this Code. 
(Ord. No. 98-524, § 1, 7-13-98) 
Sec. 24-4. - Municipal civil infraction. 
    A person who violates any provision of this chapter is responsible for a municipal civil infraction, subject to payment of a civil fine of not less that $1,000.00 and not more than $5,000.00, plus costs and other sanctions, for each infraction. Each day that a violation continues shall be a separate infraction. Repeat offenses under this chapter shall be subject to increased fines as follows: 
First repeat offense Not less than $2,000 and not more than $10,000 Second and subsequent repeat offense Not less than $5,000 and not more than $20,000.  
(Ord. No. 98-524, § 1, 7-13-98) 
Chapter 26 - COURT[1] 
  

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- The basic ordinance from which this chapter is derived is Ordinance No. 8-99, adopted July 1, 1968. The preamble of such ordinance reads as follows: 
"WHEREAS, the City of Walker presently has a Justice of the Peace Court; and 
"WHEREAS, the office of Justice of the Peace will be abolished as of January 1, 1969; and 
"WHEREAS, Act 154 of the Public Acts of 1968 of the State of Michigan contemplates the replacement of the Justice of the Peace Court with a District Court; and 
"WHEREAS, under the provisions of said Act 154, the Cities of Walker, Grandville, Kentwood and Wyoming constitute the Sixty-Second Judicial District of the District Court thereby established, which District is a District of the Third Class; and 
"WHEREAS, pursuant to said Act 154, the District Court shall not function and District Judges shall not be elected in said Sixty-Second Judicial District due to the action taken by the City of Wyoming whereby it elected to retain its Municipal Court System and to not participate in the District Court System established by said Act 154; and 
"WHEREAS, action must be taken by the Walker City Commission in order to maintain a court system to serve the needs of residents of the City of Walker, and to provide for the public health, safety and welfare, and the City Commission finds and determines that the establishment of a Municipal Court for the City of Walker pursuant to Act 5 of the Public Acts of 1956, as amended, of the State of Michigan is the most feasible way of so doing." 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; law enforcement, ch. 46; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 50; traffic and vehicles, ch. 82. 

Sec. 26-1. - Title. 
    This chapter shall be known as and may be cited as the City of Walker Municipal Court Ordinance. 
(Code 1976, § 12-1) 
Sec. 26-2. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to create, establish and provide for a municipal court in the city. 
(Code 1976, § 12-2) 
Sec. 26-3. - State law adopted and court established. 
(a)  The provisions of the state uniform municipal court act, as amended, being Act No. 5 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1956 (MCL 730.501 et seq., MSA 27.3937(1) et seq.), are hereby adopted by reference, and pursuant thereto and in accordance with the laws of the state, a municipal court for the city is hereby created and established. 
(b)  Copies of the uniform municipal court act adopted by this section shall be kept in the office of the city clerk and shall be available for inspection and public use during regular business hours of the clerk's office. 
(Code 1976, § 12-3) 
Sec. 26-4. - When operation commences. 
    The municipal court shall commence to function and operate as a municipal court in accordance with the uniform municipal court act, as amended, being Act No. 5 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1956 (MCL 730.501 et seq., MSA 27.3937(1) et seq.), on January 1, 1969. 
(Code 1976, § 12-4) 
Sec. 26-5. - Qualifications, election, jurisdiction, powers and duties of judge. 
(a)  The qualifications, time and manner of election, jurisdiction, powers and duties of the judge of the municipal court, and the practice and procedure in such municipal court shall be governed by the uniform municipal court act, as amended, being Act No. 5 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1956 (MCL 730.501 et seq., MSA 27.3937(1) et seq.), except as may be otherwise provided by applicable laws of the state. 
(b)  The first municipal court judge shall be appointed by the city commission in accordance with the provisions of the Charter. He shall be appointed for a term commencing on January 1, 1969, and ending on the Monday following the regular municipal election in April 1971. Thereafter, he shall be elected for a term of four years in accordance with the provisions of the Charter and applicable laws of the state. 
(Code 1976, § 12-5) 
Sec. 26-6. - Judge's salary. 
    The judge of the municipal court shall be paid a salary in lieu of fees. Such salary shall be as established by the city commission. The judge's salary shall not be decreased during his term of office. 
(Code 1976, § 12-6) 
Sec. 26-7. - Judge's bonds. 
    Unless otherwise provided by law, the municipal judge shall give bonds to the city in the amount of $5,000.00 and to the county in the amount of $1,000.00, with sufficient sureties to be approved by the city commission, conditioned upon the faithful performance of the duties of municipal judge and for payment to the city and to the county of all monies collected or received by such judge which, by the provisions of the general laws of the state, he shall be required to pay into the treasury of the city or county. The cost of such bonds shall be paid by the city. 
(Code 1976, § 12-7) 
Sec. 26-8. - Clerk. 
    The municipal court clerk, if any, shall be appointed by the city commission, and his salary and other conditions of employment shall be as provided by the city commission. 
(Code 1976, § 12-8) 
Sec. 26-9. - Business hours. 
    Business hours of the municipal court shall be established by the judge of the court, subject to the approval of the city commission. 
(Code 1976, § 12-9) 
Sec. 26-10. - Costs and fees. 
    Pursuant to the provisions of Act No. 297 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1974 (MCL 600.223 et seq., MSA 27A.223 et seq.), all costs and fees for the municipal court in both civil and criminal matters shall be governed by and shall be allowed in accordance with statutes and supreme court rules applicable to the district courts of the state, except where such provisions conflict with the provisions of statutes or supreme court rules specifically applicable to municipal courts in the state. 
(Code 1976, § 12-10) 
Sec. 26-11. - Jury trials. 
(a)  The provisions of Act No. 288 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1929 (MCL 730.251 et seq., MSA 27.3911 et seq.), as amended, are hereby adopted by reference. Complete copies of such act, as amended, shall be available at the office of the clerk of the municipal court for inspection by and distribution to the public during regular business hours of the court. 
(b)  In accordance with the provisions of Act No. 288 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1929 (MCL 730.251 et seq., MSA 27.3911 et seq.), terms for the trial of jury cases in the municipal court are hereby established. Each such term shall be two months in duration. Such terms shall commence on the first Monday of January, March, May, July, September, and November, respectively, except when such Monday falls on a holiday, in which case the respective term will begin on the succeeding day. Jury cases may be set for trial by the clerk of the municipal court in accordance with rules established by the municipal judge upon one or more certain days of each month or as soon thereafter as such trial can be reached. 
(c)  Jurors for the trial of jury cases in the municipal court shall be selected in accordance with the provisions of Act No. 288 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1929 (MCL 730.251 et seq., MSA 27.3911 et seq.). 
(Code 1976, § 12-11) 
Chapter 30 - ELECTIONS[1] 
  

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; selling of alcoholic liquor at retail on city or state primary or general election days prohibited, § 6-8(c). 
State Law reference- Michigan election laws, MCL 168.1 et seq., MSA 6.1001 et seq. 

Sec. 30-1. - Primary election. 
    Notwithstanding section 11.5 of the Charter, and pursuant to the authority of MCL 168.644b, MSA 6.1644(2) and MCL 168.644-l, MSA 6.1644(12), a nonpartisan city primary election shall be held on the Tuesday following the second Monday in September in every odd-numbered year beginning in 1991. In accordance with MCL 168.644f, MSA 6.1644(6), nominating petitions for elected city officers shall be filed by 4:00 p.m. on the 12th Tuesday prior to the date of the primary election. 
(Code 1976, § 51/2-1) 
Sec. 30-2. - General election. 
    Notwithstanding section 11.3 of the Charter, and pursuant to the authority of MCL 168.644a, MSA 6.1644(1) and MCL 168.644-l, MSA 6.1644(12), a nonpartisan city general election to be known as the "odd-year general election" shall be held on the Tuesday succeeding the first Monday in November in every odd-numbered year beginning in 1991. 
(Code 1976, § 51/2-2) 
Sec. 30-3. - Terms of elected officials. 
    City officials elected at the odd-year general election as provided in section 30-2 shall take office, pursuant to MCL 168.644h, MSA 6.1644(8), and section 2.2 of the Charter, at 8:00 p.m. on the Monday following the date of the election at which he was elected. Except as provided in section 30-4, the length of the terms of office for each elected city office shall be governed by the Charter. 
(Code 1976, § 51/2-3) 
Sec. 30-4. - Extension of existing terms. 
    Pursuant to MCL 168.644g, MSA 6.1644(7): 
(1)  The mayor, the clerk, and the three commissioners from each ward whose terms were scheduled to expire in April 1991, shall continue in office until a successor takes office following the November 1991, odd-year general election in accordance with sections 30-2 and 30-3; 
(2)  The treasurer and the three commissioners from each ward whose terms were scheduled to expire in April 1993 shall continue in office until a successor takes office following the November 1993, odd-year general election in accordance with sections 30-2 and 30-3. 
(Code 1976, § 51/2-4) 
Sec. 30-5. - Rescission of prior resolution. 
    This chapter shall rescind a resolution of the city commission dated January 12, 1971, by which the city opted not to hold elections in the fall of odd-numbered years as provided in MCL 168.644a et seq., MSA 6.1644 et seq. 
(Code 1976, § 51/2-5)

(a)  Whatever annoys, injures or endangers the safety, health, comfort or repose of the public; offends public decency; interferes with or obstructs or renders dangerous any street or highway; or in any way renders the public insecure in life or property, is hereby declared to be a public nuisance.

ARTICLE III. - AIR POLLUTION 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 34-51. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Air contaminant means dust, fumes, gases, mists, odors, smoke, vapor or any combination thereof. 
    Air pollution means the presence in the outdoor atmosphere of air contaminants in quantities, of characteristics and under conditions and circumstances and of a duration which are injurious to human life or property or which unreasonably interfere with the enjoyment of life and property, and which are unreasonably detrimental to plant and animal life in this city, and excludes all aspects of employer-employee relationships as to health and safety hazards. 
    Appeal board or board means the air pollution appeal board created by this article. 
    Bridgewall means any wall at the rear of the grate or stoker that acts as a deflector or radiant heat reflector for the furnace gases and as a stop to the fuel bed or a rear wall to the ash pit. 
    Certificate of operation means a certificate issued by the director authorizing the use of any process, fuel-burning, refuse-burning or control equipment for the period indicated after it has been found that it can be operated in compliance with the provisions of this article. 
    Chimney means any conduit, duct, vent, exhaust structure or opening of any kind whatsoever capable of and used for the emission of smoke, soot, cinders, noxious acids, gases, fly ash or industrial dust. 
    Clean wood means natural wood that has not been painted, varnished, or coated with a similar material; has not been pressure treated with preservatives; and does not contain glues as in plywood or other composite wood products. 
    Combustion equipment means any furnace, incinerator, refuse-burning equipment, boiler apparatus, fuel-burning equipment, device, mechanism, stack or structure used in the process of burning fuel or combustible material. 
    Director means that person appointed by the city commission to serve as director under this article, or the director's duly authorized representative. 
    Fire chief means the fire chief of the City of Walker or his or her designees. 
    Fly ash means any gas or airborne particles larger than one micron (approximately .00004 inch) and consisting essentially of fused ash or unburned combustible material. 
    Fuel means any liquid, gaseous or solid substance used for combustion. 
    Fuel-burning equipment means any equipment, device or contrivance used for combustion of fuel. 
    Incinerator means a device specifically designed for the destruction, by burning, of garbage or other combustible refuse or waste material. 
    Industrial dust means any gas or airborne particles larger than one micron emanating from a manufacturing process or material storage or handling. 
    Open burning means a fire from which the products of combustion are emitted directly into the open air without passing through a stack or chimney. 
    Outer air means all space outside of buildings, stacks or exterior ducts. 
    Particulate matter means the material, except uncombined water, that exists in a finely divided form as a liquid or solid at standard conditions. 
    Process equipment means any equipment, device or contrivance for changing any materials whatever or for storage or handling of any materials, and all appurtenances thereto, including ducts, stacks and the like, the use of which may cause any discharge of an air contaminant into the outdoor atmosphere, but not including that equipment specifically defined as "fuel-burning equipment" or "refuse-burning equipment" in this section. 
    Process weight means the total weight of all materials introduced into a source operation, including solid fuels, but excluding liquids and gases used solely as fuels, and excluding air introduced for purposes of combustion. 
    Process weight rate means a rate established as follows: 
(1)  For continuous or long-run steady-state source operations, the total process weight for the entire period of continuous operation or for a typical portion thereof, divided by the number of hours of such period or portion thereof; 
(2)  For cyclical or batch source operations, the total process weight for a period that covers a complete operation or an integral number of cycles, divided by the hours of actual process operation during such a period; 
(3)  When the nature of any process or operation or the design of any equipment is such as to permit more than one interpretation of this definition, the interpretation that results in the minimum value for allowable emission applies. 
    Refuse-burning equipment means any equipment, device or contrivance used for the destruction of garbage, rubbish or other wastes by burning, and all appurtenances thereto. 
    Repair means any work which requires heating or power equipment to be wholly or partially dismantled and which results in the restoration of the heating or power equipment to its original state. 
    Salvage operation means any operation conducted, in whole or in part, for the salvaging or reclaiming of any product or material. 
    Smoke means the visible finely divided material that escapes from a substance during combustion, except such other materials as are covered by this section. 
    Smoke chart means the Ringelmann smoke chart for the purpose of providing the standard of comparison for grading the density of smoke, as such Ringelmann smoke chart is published and used by the federal bureau of mines. 
    Smoke indicator means any device, electrically or mechanically operated, fixed or movable, consisting of photoelectric devices, mirrors or a series of mirrors which will allow firefighters or other persons operating boilers or other fuel burning equipment to determine the density and color of smoke or the ingredients of smoke, noxious fumes, acids, oxides, industrial dust or other air contaminants being expelled into the atmosphere. 
    Source operation means the last operation preceding the emission of an air contaminant, which operation results in the separation of the air contaminant from the process material or in the conversion of the process materials into air contaminants, as in the case of combustion fuel, and is not an air pollution abatement operation. 
    Source sample means a sample of the emission from an air contamination source, collected for analysis from within a stack or an effluent stream. 
    Standard conditions means a gas temperature of 60 degrees Fahrenheit and a gas pressure of 14.7 pounds per square inch absolute. 
(Code 1976, § 3-1; Ord. No. 06-549, § 1, 11-27-06) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 34-52. - Article to be liberally construed. 
    It is the legislative intent of the city, in adopting this article, that all provisions and sections of this article be liberally construed to protect and preserve the peace, health, safety and welfare of the inhabitants of the city. 
(Code 1976, § 3-2) 
Sec. 34-53. - Article not applicable to motor vehicles. 
    Nothing in this article shall apply to motor vehicles. 
(Code 1976, § 3-3) 
Sec. 34-54. - Creation of noxious or offensive odors. 
    No person shall permit matter to putrefy or decay, or be burned so as to cause, nor shall he in any other manner cause or occasion noxious or offensive odors, fumes or gases in any place within the city in such manner as to imperil the health or safety of any person or so as to disturb unnecessarily and without reasonable cause the comfort of any person within the city. Any violation of this section is hereby declared to be a public nuisance. 
(Code 1976, § 10-7) 
Sec. 34-55. - Open burning-Prohibited; exceptions. 
(a)  General provisions. No person shall cause or permit open burning to occur upon any premises owned or occupied by him or under his control, except open burning described in subsection (b) below for which a permit is not required and open burning described in subsection (c) below for which a permit is required. 
(b)  Permit not required. The following categories of open burning shall not require a permit: 
(1)  Burning of charcoal, natural gas, propane gas, or clean wood for the sole purpose of cooking food within a portable grill or other similar device that is designed exclusively for cooking and that has a metal lid, cover, or similar mechanism capable of completely enclosing and confining the fire. Open burning under this subsection shall comply with subsection 34-56(b) except subsections (3), (8), (9) and (10). 
(2)  The use of salamanders in connection with building and construction operations, when done in accordance with accepted safety standards. Open burning under this subsection shall comply with subsection 34-56(b) except subsections (3) through (11). 
(3)  Roofers, tinners, plumbers or other mechanics using open fire in the regular course of their trade, when done in accordance with accepted safety standards. Open burning under this subsection shall comply with subsection 34-56(b) except subsections (3) through (11). 
(4)  The use of outdoor fireplaces (as hereinafter defined), which are purchased by homeowners for use outside of a dwelling or residence, provided such outdoor fireplaces are used for preparation of food or for recreation, are used on noncombustible surfaces including, but not limited to, brick, flagstone, or concrete, and are kept away from any flammable liquids and other combustible materials. Outdoor fireplaces shall be used only for the burning of clean wood or other solid fuel and shall not be used for the burning of waste materials or other materials including, but not limited to, garbage, rubbish, trash, grass clippings, leaves, and paper. Owners, operators and users of outdoor fireplaces shall use such fireplaces in accordance with the manufacturer's recommendations for safe use. An "outdoor fireplace" as used in this article is defined as a portable, commercially-produced device that is designed, manufactured, and purchased for the sole purpose of burning wood or solid fuel similar to an indoor fireplace. An outdoor fireplace does not include a barrel of any kind, or any other device, material or object, which is not designed, manufactured, or purchased exclusively for the burning of wood or solid fuel similar to an indoor fireplace. Open burning under this subsection shall comply with subsection 34-56(b) except subsections (3), (8), (9) and (10). 
(5)  The use of fire rings as defined herein by homeowners for use outside of a dwelling or residence subject to the following requirements: 
a.  The fire ring is used only for preparation of food or for recreation. 
b.  The fire ring is used only for the burning of clean wood or other solid fuel and is not used for the burning of any waste materials or other materials including, but not limited to, garbage, rubbish, trash, grass clippings, leaves, and paper. 
c.  The fire ring shall not be closer than 25 feet to any building or overhead wires and not closer than ten feet to adjoining lot lines. 
d.  The fire ring is used in compliance with subsection 34-56(b), except subsections (3), (8), (9), and (10). 
e.  The fire ring does not exceed four feet in diameter and has a noncombustible barrier at least six inches in width surrounding the fire ring. 
For purposes of this subsection, a "fire ring" means a defined area on the surface of the ground designed for open burning and fully surrounded by a noncombustible barrier consisting of stone, brick, concrete, or similar noncombustible material. Open burning under this subsection shall comply with subsection 34-56(b) except subsections (3), (8), (9) and (10). 
(6)  Open burning or fires set or attended by firefighting personnel for training in firefighting techniques, fire containment, and the use of firefighting equipment. Such open burning shall be authorized by the city fire department and shall be conducted in accordance with the rules and regulations set forth by the city fire department and applicable fire prevention codes and standards. Open burning under this subsection shall not be required to comply with subsection 34-56(b). 
(7)  Open burning or frees set for purposes of training in the use of fire extinguishers by the city fire department, or an established fire protection company with the prior approval of the city fire department. Such open burning shall be conducted in accordance with applicable fire prevention codes and standards. Open burning under this subsection shall not be required to comply with subsection 34-56. 
If the fire chief determines that any open burning or certain types of open burning for which a permit is not required under this subsection is unsafe due to dry weather, wind conditions or other unfavorable conditions, or the impact on air quality or the health of nearby residents, or the open burning causes a foul odor or smoke emissions reasonably offensive to the occupants of nearby property, or the open burning creates a visibility hazard on street, roads, or railways, the fire chief may order the open burning to be extinguished or may impose reasonable conditions on the open burning. Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, no open burning shall be conducted in violation of the fire chief's order. 
(c)  Permit required. 
(1)  All open burning permitted under this subsection shall require a permit by the fire chief and prior written or oral approval of the fire chief for a specific date as provided herein. A written permit issued by the fire chief shall be valid only for the calendar year in which it is issued. A written permit issued pursuant to this section shall not relieve the permittee from complying with all other applicable statutes, ordinances, rules, and regulations. In addition, no open burning shall be permitted without the prior oral or written approval of the fire chief for a specific date. The fire chief's approval may be withheld or withdrawn if the open burning would be unsafe due to the particular circumstances of a request, including, but not limited to, dry weather, wind conditions, or other unfavorable conditions, or the impact on air quality or the health of nearby residents, or the open burning causes a foul odor or causes smoke emissions reasonably offensive to occupants of nearby property, or the open burning creates a visibility hazard on streets, roads, or railways. The fire chief may impose reasonable conditions on the prior approval, including, but not limited to, limitations on the size, duration, time of day, location, and manner of burning. The requirement of prior approval of the fire chief for a specific date as provided by this section shall be in addition to the requirement of a written permit. All open burning permitted under this subsection shall comply with subsection 34-56(b) except as expressly provided otherwise in this article. 
(2)  The following categories of open burning shall require a permit and prior approval of the fire chief under subsection (1) above: 
a.  Agricultural property. Except as permitted under subsection (b), no person shall cause or permit open burning upon any premises actively used for primarily agricultural purposes owned or occupied by him or under his control, except the following: 
(i)  Open burning for agricultural purposes conducted between October 15 and May 15. Notwithstanding section 11522 of Act No. 451 of the Public Acts of 1994, as amended (MCL 324.11522), the open burning of grass clippings and leaves is permitted by this subsection. All agricultural open burning shall comply with all applicable state laws, rules, and regulations and the issuance of a permit and prior approval of the fire chief under this article shall not relieve the permittee from the obligation to so comply. Between November 16 and April 14, the open burning permitted under this subsection is permitted on any day except Sunday as provided in subsection (b)(9). Between April 15 and May 15 and between October 15 and November 15, the open burning permitted under this subsection shall not be conducted on Tuesday, Thursday, Friday, and Sunday, as provided in subsection 34-56(b)(9). Open burning under this subsection shall comply with subsection 34-56(b). 
(ii)  Open burning of logs, brush, charcoal, and similar materials that are used in preparing food or for recreation. Open burning under this subsection shall comply with subsection 34-56(b). 
(iii)  Open burning for a special event for which a permit is issued pursuant to subsection (c)(2)c. 
b.  Residential property. Except as provided under subsection (b), no person shall cause or permit open burning upon any premises that is owned or occupied by him or under his control, if the property is used for residential purposes, except the following: 
(i)  Until May 15, 2007, and notwithstanding section 11522 of Act No. 451 of the Public Acts of 1994, as amended (MCL 324.11522), open burning of grass clippings and leaves conducted between April 15 and May 15 or between October 15 and November 15. Open burning under this subsection shall comply with subsection 34-56(b). Commencing on May 16, 2007, and at all times thereafter, open burning of grass clippings and leaves are prohibited on property used for residential purposes. 
(ii)  Open burning for a special event for which a permit is issued pursuant to subsection (c)(2)c. 
c.  Special events. Open burning may be permitted for special events on developed or vacant property under the following additional conditions and subject to the following requirements: 
(i)  For purposes of this section, the term "special event" means an event of limited duration sponsored by, under the direction of, and participated in by the members of a nonprofit organization, association, or group, such as scouting groups, church groups, civic booster groups, and educational groups, where the event is recreational and organized in connection with, or to celebrate, recognize, or memorialize a day, event, or occurrence of special significance to the organization, association, or group. 
(ii)  Open burning in connection with a special event shall comply with all applicable requirements of this section, and the requirements of subsection 34-56(b), except subsections (8), (9), and (10). 
(iii)  Open burning in connection with a special event shall be confined to a discrete area and shall be in the form of a campfire or bonfire. 
(iv)  Open burning in connection with a special event shall be for symbolic, celebratory, and recreational purposes to provide a focal point for the special event, or for purposes of food preparation, and shall not be for the purpose of disposing of refuse, garbage, or other waste materials of any kind. The open burning shall burn only clean wood. 
(v)  Fire-extinguishing equipment shall be readily available at the site of any open burning in connection with a special event. 
(vi)  Open burning in connection with a special event shall be completely extinguished without smoldering at the conclusion of the event. 
(vii)  As provided by subsection (c)(1), the fire chief may impose reasonable conditions on the required prior approval and may withhold or withdraw approval of a request for burning in connection with a special event if the open burning would be unsafe under the circumstances. 
d.  Prescribed bums [burns]. Fires set for forest, prairie, and wildlife habitat management are allowed only if conducted in accordance with part 515 of the Natural Resources and Environmental Protection Act (MCL 324.51501 et seq.). Open burning under this subsection shall comply with subsection 34-56(b), except subsections (3), (5), (8), (9), and (11). 
e.  Beekeeping. Open burning of beekeeping equipment and products, including frames, hive bodies, hive covers, combs, wax, and honey is permitted if necessary to prevent disease. Open burning under this subsection shall comply with subsection 34-56(b), except subsections (3), (5), (8), (9), and (11). 
(d)  [Prohibited burning.] Notwithstanding any other provision of this section and section 34-56, the following is prohibited: 
(1)  Open burning of trees, logs, brush, and stumps cleared for the purposes of land development. 
(2)  Open burning of buildings or structures for purposes of demolishing such buildings or structures except as permitted for fire training pursuant to subsection (b)(6). 
(3)  Open burning of demolition waste or debris and any other materials from the demolition of buildings or structures. 
(4)  Open burning on premises that are used or zoned for commercial, office, or industrial purposes, except as permitted by subsections (b)(2) or (b)(3). 
(5)  Open burning on vacant property, except premises actively used for primarily agricultural purposes as permitted in this article and except special events as permitted in subsection (c)(2)c. 
(Code 1976, § 3-7; Ord. No. 95-459, § 1, 3-14-95; Ord. No. 97-496, § 1, 7-28-97; Ord. No. 99-535, § 1, 4-12-99; Ord. No. 03-503, § 3, 8-25-03; Ord. No. 06-549, § 3, 11-27-06) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, ch. 38. 
Sec. 34-56. - Same-Permitted areas, time. 
(a)  All open burning for which a permit is required under subsection 34-55(c) shall comply with subsection (b) below, except as otherwise provided in this article. Open burning for which a permit is not required under subsection 34-55(b) shall be required to comply with subsection (b) below to the extent required under subsection 34-55(b). 
(b)  Subject to subsection (a) and this article, the following regulations shall apply to open burning: 
(1)  Open burning shall be supervised and kept under control by an adult who shall be present at the site of the fire at all times and until the fire is completely extinguished without smoldering. 
(2)  Fire extinguishing equipment shall be readily available at the site of any residential open burning. 
(3)  Open burning shall not be permitted less than 50 feet from any building or overhead wires. 
(4)  Open burning shall not be permitted upon any public street, curb, gutter, or sidewalk. 
(5)  Open burning shall not be permitted in ditches or drainage courses other than the burning of natural vegetation growing therein. 
(6)  No open burning of any garbage, rubbish, or other solid waste shall be permitted, provided, however, that this subsection shall not be construed to prohibit the open burning of grass clippings and leaves to the extent that it is permitted pursuant to section 34-55. 
(7)  No open burning shall be permitted in trash barrels, or other containers for burning, except outdoor fireplaces and fire rings, pursuant to subsections 34-55(b)(4) or (b)(5). 
(8)  No open burning for which a permit is required under this article shall be permitted on property used for residential purposes on Tuesday, Thursday, Friday, or Sunday. 
(9)  Open burning for which a permit is required under this article on property primarily used for agricultural purposes may be conducted in compliance with section 34-55 and this section on any day except Sunday during the period between November 16 and April 14. No open burning for which a permit is required under this article shall be permitted on property primarily used for agricultural purposes on Tuesday, Thursday, Friday, or Sunday during the period between April 15 and May 15 and between October 15 and November 15. 
(10)  No open burning shall be permitted between one hour after sunset and one hour before sunrise. All open burning during daylight hours shall be completely extinguished without smoldering not later than one hour after sunset. 
(11)  Materials to be burned must be dry and readily combustible so that any emission of air contaminants complies with sections 34-58 through 34-60. 
(Code 1976, § 3-7.1; Ord. No. 97-496, §§ 2, 3, 7-28-97; Ord. No. 97-506, § 1, 11-10-97; Ord. No. 99-535, § 2, 4-12-99; Ord. No. 03-503, § 1, 8-25-03; Ord. No. 06-549, § 3, 11-27-06) 
Sec. 34-57. - Same-General regulations. 
(a)  A person who violates any provision of sections 34-54 through 34-56 is responsible for a municipal civil infraction, subject to payment of a civil fine of not less than $50.00, plus costs and other sanctions, for each infraction. 
(b)  Repeat offenses shall be subject to increased fines as provided by subsection 1-11(c)(2) of this Code, except that as used in this section "repeat offense" means a second (or any subsequent) municipal civil infraction violation of the same requirement or provision (i) committed by a person within any 15-day period; and (ii) for which the person admits responsibility or is determined to be responsible. 
(c)  The fire chief or his designees are hereby designated as the authorized city official to issue municipal civil infraction citations (directing alleged violators to appear in court) or municipal civil infraction violation notices (directing alleged violators to appear at the city municipal ordinance violations bureau) for violations under sections 3454 through 34-56 as provided by this Code. 
(Code 1976, § 3-7.2; Ord. No. 95-459, § 2, 3-14-95; Ord. No. 97-496, §§ 4, 5, 7-28-97; Ord. No. 03-503, § 2, 8-25-03; Ord. No. 06-549, § 4, 11-27-06) 
Sec. 34-57.1. - Municipal civil infraction. 
(a)  Responsible party; reimbursement of city. When the city fire department responds to a call for assistance involving an open burning that was conducted in (1) violation of subsections 34-55(d)(1), (d)(2), or (d)(3); or (2) the open burning spread from the original location of combustion due to the failure to comply with subsections 34-56(b)(1) or (b)(2) and such burning created a condition potentially or actually hazardous to persons or property ("unauthorized burning"), the person responsible for such open burning ("responsible party") shall be obligated, jointly and severally, to reimburse the city, its agents, contractors and employees for all costs of the city incurred in connection with the response to the incident and any mitigation of the situation. For purposes of this section, the costs incurred by the city for any response, mitigation, removal, cleanup, and/or restoration activities shall include, but not be limited to, the following: (i) per-hour charges for fire department vehicles as established by resolution of the city commission; (ii) the costs of personnel, supplies, and equipment of the city fire department (and any other department of the city) utilized in connection with the incident; and (iii) billing and collection costs, including attorneys' fees. 
(b)  Billing and collection. Following a response to an unauthorized burning, the fire chief shall prepare and transmit an invoice to the responsible party (or parties) for payment. The invoice shall demand full payment within 30 days of the date of the mailing of the bill. Any additional expenses that become known to the fire chief following transmittal of the bill to a responsible party shall be billed in the same manner on a subsequent bill. For any amounts due that remain unpaid after 30 days, the city shall impose a late charge of one percent per month, or fraction thereof. Failure to pay the invoice within 30 days of the date of mailing shall constitute a violation of this Code. 
(c)  Enforcement. If any responsible party fails to reimburse the city for the costs described in subsection (a), above, the city may bring an action in a court of competent jurisdiction, and may take any other lawful action, to collect such costs. In addition, if a responsible party who fails to reimburse the city for the costs described in subsection (a), above, is an owner or taxpayer of the property on which the unauthorized burning occurred, the city may add such costs to the tax roll as to such property and to levy and collect such costs in the same manner as provided for the levy and collection of real property taxes against such property. The recovery of costs imposed under this section does not limit or modify the liability of any responsible party under local ordinance, or state or federal law, rule or regulation. 
(Ord. No. 95-474, § 1, 12-12-95; Ord. No. 06-549, § 5, 11-27-06) 
Sec. 34-57.2. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 06-549, § 6, adopted Nov. 27, 2006, repealed § 34-57.2, which pertained to open burning response recovery costs and derived from Ord. No. 99-535, § 3, adopted April 12, 1999. 
Sec. 34-58. - Maximum density of air contaminants. 
    No person shall cause or permit to be discharged into the atmosphere from any single source of emission an air contaminant of a density equal to or darker than no. 2 of the smoke chart except: 
(1)  Smoke of a density equal to but not darker than no. 2 of the smoke chart may be emitted for not more than three minutes in any 30-minute period. 
(2)  Smoke of a density equal to but not darker than no. 3 of the smoke chart may be emitted for not more than three minutes in any 60-minute period, but such emission shall not be permitted on more than three occasions during any 24-hour period. 
(Code 1976, § 3-8) 
Sec. 34-59. - Devices for grading darkness of smoke. 
    Darkness of visible emissions of smoke shall be graded by using the Ringelmann smoke chart as published by the United States Bureau of Mines in Information Circular 7718, or by means of devices which result in measurements of equal or better accuracy. 
(Code 1976, § 3-9) 
Sec. 34-60. - Point of measuring density of smoke plume. 
    The density of a smoke plume shall be measured at the point of its emission, except that, when the point of emission cannot be readily observed, it may be measured at an observable point on the plume nearest the point of emission. 
(Code 1976, § 3-10) 
_____

Notes: 
(a) Fuel burning and refuse incineration limitations shall be calculated to 50 percent excess air. 
(b) Emission limitations for specific ratings are determined by linear interpolation between the ranges shown. 
(c) These emission limitations do not apply to domestic incinerators (defined as having not over five cubic feet of storage capacity). 
(d) Air cleaning equipment shall be designed for maximum emission of one-tenth pound per 1,000 pounds of gas. 
(e) Differentiation between jobbing and production foundries: 
Cupolas used in a jobbing foundry are the same as those used in a production foundry and will vary in size only according to the quantity of iron melted per hour. However, the cupolas in a jobbing foundry will be run intermittently for just long enough at one time to pour the molds that are ready on the foundry floor, job by job. This might be for a two-to-four-hour period per day for any number of days per week. 
Production foundry cupolas will melt continuously to pour a succession of molds that are constantly being prepared to receive this continuous flow of iron. This could become eight hours, 16 hours, or 24 hours per day for any number of days per week. 
(f) Where no water is available and an emission limit of three-tenths pound per 1,000 pounds of gas cannot otherwise be satisfied, the plant may be located as the center point of a buffer zone one mile in radius having no occupied residences or places of public assembly.
