Chapter 50 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Court, ch. 26; nuisances, § 34-26 et seq.; law enforcement, ch. 46; traffic and vehicles, ch. 82. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 50-1. - Definition; public place. 
    As used in this chapter, "public place" means any street, alley, park, sidewalk, public building, any place of business or assembly open to the public or frequented by the public or any portion thereof, and any other place which is open to public view or to which the public, or any portion thereof, has access. 
(Code 1976, § 10-1; Ord. No. 04-513, § 1, 6-28-04) 
State Law reference- Attempts, MCL 750.92. 
Sec. 50-1.1. - Aiding or abetting; attempt; conspiracy. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to aid and abet any other person in the commission of any unlawful act in the city. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to attempt to commit any offense prohibited by law if, in such attempt, any act is done towards the commission of such offense. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to conspire together with one or more persons to commit an offense prohibited by law. 
(Ord. No. 04-513, § 2, 6-28-04) 
Sec. 50-2. - Inducing commission of unlawful act. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to solicit or accost any person for the purpose of inducing the commission of any illegal or immoral act in the city. 
(Code 1976, § 10-2) 
Sec. 50-3. - Transporting persons to engage in unlawful act. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly transport any person to a place for the purpose of enabling such person to engage in any illegal or immoral act. 
(Code 1976, § 10-3) 
Sec. 50-4. - Abandoned refrigerators and other airtight containers. 
    No person shall have in his possession, either inside or outside of any building, structure or dwelling, in a place accessible to children, any abandoned, unattended or discarded icebox, refrigerator or any other similar airtight container of any kind large enough for a child to enter, which has a snap latch or other locking device thereon, without first removing the snap latch or other locking device, or the doors, from such icebox, refrigerator or other such airtight container. Any violation of this section is hereby declared to be a public nuisance. 
(Code 1976, § 10-6) 
Cross reference- Nuisances, § 34-26 et seq.; solid waste, ch. 62. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 750.493d. 
Sec. 50-5. - False report to police. 
    A person commits the crime of false reporting to law enforcement authorities if: 
(1)  He makes a report or intentionally causes the transmission of a report to law enforcement authorities of a crime or other incident within their concern when he knows that it did not occur; or 
(2)  He makes a report or purposely causes the transmission of a report to law enforcement authorities pretending to furnish information relating to a crime or other incident within their concern when he knows that he has no such information. 
(Code 1976, § 10-9) 
Cross reference- Law enforcement, ch. 46. 
State Law reference- False report of crime, MCL 750.411a. 
Sec. 50-6. - Obstructing police. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct, resist, hinder or oppose any member of the police force, or any peace officer, in the discharge of his duties as such. 
(Code 1976, § 10-10) 
Cross reference- Law enforcement, ch. 46. 
State Law reference- Obstruction of police officers, MCL 750.479. 
Sec. 50-7. - Assault. 
    No person shall commit an assault or assault and battery upon any person. 
(Code 1976, § 10-12; Ord. No. 13-620, § 1, 12-21-13 ) 
State Law reference- Assaults, MCL 750.81 et seq. 
Sec. 50-7.5. - Domestic assault and battery; arrest procedures. 
(a)  An individual who assaults or assaults and batters his/her spouse or former spouse, an individual with whom he or she has or has had a dating relationship, an individual with whom he/she has had a child in common, or a resident or former resident of his/her household, is guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by imprisonment for not more than 93 days or a fine of not more than $500.00, or both; except that an individual who has previously been convicted under this section or a local ordinance substantially corresponding to this section, or a violation of sections 81, 81a, 82, 83, 84, or 86 of Act 382 of Public Acts of 1931, as amended (being the Michigan Penal Code, MCL 750.81, 750.81a, 750.82, 750.83,750.84, or 750.86, respectively) may be punished under state law in accordance with the provisions of section 81 of Act 382 of Public Acts of 1931, as amended by Act 64 of Public Acts of 1994 (being MCL 750.81). 
(b)  A police officer may arrest an individual for violating subsection (a) regardless of whether the police officer has a warrant or whether the violation was committed in his or her presence, if the police officer has or receives positive information that another police officer has reasonable cause to believe both of the following: 
(1)  The violation occurred or is occurring. 
(2)  The individual has had a child in common with the victim, resides or has resided in the same household as the victim, has or has had a dating relationship with the victim, or is a spouse or former spouse of the victim. 
(c)  As used in this section, "dating relationship" means frequent, intimate associations primarily characterized by the expectation of affectional involvement. This term does not include a casual relationship or ordinary fraternization between two individuals in a business or social context. 
(Code 1976, § 10-59; Ord. No. 96-487, § 1, 9-10-96; Ord. No. 02-483, § 1, 2-11-02; Ord. No. 02-485, § 1, 3-25-02) 
Sec. 50-8. - Engaging in fights or quarrels. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in any disturbance, fight or quarrel in any place open to the public except in reasonable self-defense when attacked without reasonable provocation or in reasonable defense of another who was so attacked. 
(Code 1976, § 10-13; Ord. No. 10-589, § 1, 10-11-10) 
Sec. 50-9. - Disorderly person. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to be a disorderly person. 
(b)  A person is a disorderly person if the person is any of the following: 
(1)  A person of sufficient ability who refuses or neglects to support his family. 
(2)  A person who urinates in a public place. 
(3)  A person who engages in an illegal occupation or business. 
(4)  A person who is engaged in indecent or obscene conduct in a public place. 
(5)  A common prostitute. 
(6)  A vagrant. 
(7)  A person who unreasonably disturbs the public peace and quiet by loud, boisterous, or vulgar conduct or language. 
(8)  A person found loitering in a house of ill fame or prostitution or place where prostitution or lewdness is practiced, encouraged or allowed. 
(9)  A person who knowingly loiters in or about a place where an illegal occupation or business is being conducted. 
(10)  A person who loiters in or about a police station, police headquarters building, jail, hospital, court building, or other public building or place for the purpose of soliciting employment of legal services or of the services of sureties upon criminal recognizance. 
(11)  A person who is found jostling or roughly crowding people unnecessarily in a public place. 
(Code 1976, § 10-14; Ord. No. 13-620, § 2, 12-21-13 ) 
Sec. 50-9.5. - Disturbing by soliciting. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings provided in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Accosting means approaching or speaking to a person in such a manner as would cause a reasonable person to fear imminent bodily harm or the commission of a criminal act upon his person, or upon property in his immediate possession. 
    Ask or solicit mean and include, without limitation, the spoken, written or printed word or such other acts as are conducted in furtherance of the purpose of obtaining donations. 
    Forcing oneself upon the company of another means continuing to ask or solicit from a person after that person has made a negative response, blocking the passage of the individual addressed, or otherwise engaging in conduct which could reasonably be construed as intended to compel or force a person to accede to demands. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to solicit money or other things of value: 
(1)  On private property if the owner, tenant or lawful occupant has asked the person not to solicit on the property or has posted a sign clearly indicating that solicitations are not welcome on the property; 
(2)  Within 15 feet of the entrance to or exit from any public toilet facility; 
(3)  Within 15 feet of an automated teller machine, provided that when an automated teller machine is located within an automated teller machine facility, such distance shall be measured from the entrance or exit of the automated teller machine facility; 
(4)  Within 15 feet of any pay telephone, provided that when a pay telephone is located within a telephone booth or other facility, such distance shall be measured from the entrance or exit of the telephone booth or facility; 
(5)  Within any public transportation vehicle, or within 15 feet of any bus stop, taxi stand or rapid transit stop; 
(6)  From any operator of a motor vehicle that is in traffic on a public street; provided, however, that this subsection shall not apply to services rendered in connection with emergency repairs requested by the owner or passengers of such vehicle; 
(7)  From any person who is waiting in line for entry to any building, public or private, including, but not limited to, any residence, business or athletic facility; or 
(8)  Within 15 feet of the entrance or exit from a building, public or private, including, but not limited to, any residence, business or athletic facility. 
    Notwithstanding the foregoing, nothing herein shall be interpreted to prohibit related parties from soliciting money or other things of value from one another. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to solicit money or other things of value by: 
(1)  Accosting another; or 
(2)  Forcing oneself upon the company of another. 
( Ord. No. 13-620, § 3, 12-21-13 ) 
Sec. 50-10. - Disturbing persons by use of telephone. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, by means or use of a telephone, to disturb or tend to disturb the peace, quiet or right of privacy of any other person or family by repeated and continued anonymous or identified telephone messages intended to harass or disturb the person or family to whom the call is directed; or, by a single call or repeated calls, to use obscene, profane, indecent or offensive language, or suggest any lewd or lascivious act over or through a telephone in this city; or attempt to extort money or other thing of value from any person or family by means or use of the telephone; or to threaten any physical violence or harm to any person or family; or to repeatedly and continuously ring the telephone of any person or family with intent to disturb or harass them; provided, however, the normal use of the telephone for the purpose of requesting payment of debts or obligations or for other legitimate purposes shall not constitute a violation of this section. 
(Code 1976, § 10-16) 
Sec. 50-11. - Disturbing lawful assemblies. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to disturb any service of worship or any other assembly gathered for lawful purposes in the city. 
(Code 1976, § 10-17) 
Cross reference- Obscene conduct and displays prohibited at outdoor assemblies, § 10-69(2), (3). 
State Law reference- Disturbing meetings, MCL 750.169 et seq., MSA 28.366 et seq. 
Sec. 50-12. - Annoying other persons in public. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to accost, molest or otherwise annoy any person in any public place, either by word of mouth, whistle or by sign or motion. 
(Code 1976, § 10-18) 
Sec. 50-13. - Collecting in crowds for unlawful purposes. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to collect or stand in crowds or arrange, encourage or abet the collection of persons in crowds for illegal or mischievous purposes in any public place. 
(Code 1976, § 10-20) 
Sec. 50-14. - Curfew for minors. 
(a)  A minor under the age of 12 years shall not loiter, idle or congregate in or on any public street, highway, alley or park between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m., unless the minor is accompanied by a parent or guardian, or some adult delegated by the parent or guardian to accompany the child. 
(b)  A minor under the age of 16 years shall not loiter, idle or congregate in or on any public street, highway, alley or park between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m. immediately following, except where the minor is accompanied by a parent or guardian, or some adult delegated by the parent or guardian to accompany the minor child, or where the minor is upon an errand or other legitimate business directed by his parent or guardian. 
(c)  Any person of the age of 16 years or over assisting, aiding, abetting, allowing, permitting or encouraging any minor under the age of 16 years to violate the provisions of this section is guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(d)  Arrests and prosecution of minors under the age of 17 years for violation of this section shall be in accordance with section 13 and the other provisions of chapter XIIA of Act No. 288 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1939 (MCL 712A.1 et seq., MSA 27.3178(598.1) et seq.), as amended. 
(Code 1976, § 10-21) 
Sec. 50-15. - Protection of juveniles from certain detrimental activities. 
(a)  Title. This section shall be known as the Juvenile Protection Ordinance of the city. 
(b)  Purpose. The purpose of this section is to protect minors from exposure to or any inducement to engage in activities detrimental to their health, safety or welfare and to further promote the public health, safety and general welfare of the people of the city by prohibiting encouragement of or causing of or contribution to the delinquency of minors. 
(c)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
(1)  Minor means any individual who has not reached the age of 17 years. 
(2)  Delinquency of a minor means the participation or engagement of the minor in any of the following acts: 
a.  Acts which would constitute a violation of any city ordinance or state or federal law. 
b.  Deserting his home without sufficient cause. 
c.  Willful and repeated absence from school while being legally required to attend. 
(d)  Contributing to delinquency. 
(1)  No person shall, by any act or word, encourage, cause or tend to cause or contribute to the delinquency of a minor. 
(2)  No person shall permit a minor to be present in a vehicle, room, house, building or any other place in which an illegal activity is knowingly being conducted and which is owned, occupied or used by or under the control of such person. 
(e)  Penalties. Any person who violates the provisions of subsection (d) shall be punished by a fine of not more than $100.00 or by imprisonment in the county jail for not more than 90 days or both. 
(Code 1976, § 10-20.1) 
Cross reference- Sale or delivery of alcoholic beverages to persons under 21 years of age, § 6-17. 
Sec. 50-16. - Damaging, defacing, tampering with, etc., property generally. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully destroy, deface, tamper with or damage in any manner any property not his own, or without proper authority; to in any manner mar the walls of any building or any fence, tree or pole within the city; or to take or meddle with any property belonging to the city or remove property from the building or place where it may be kept, placed, standing or stored without authority from the official custodian of such property. 
(Code 1976, § 10-22) 
State Law reference- Malicious mischief, MCL 750.377 et seq., MSA 28.609 et seq. 
Sec. 50-17. - Disobeying validly posted signs. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to disobey any validly posted signs in any public park or other public place. 
(Code 1976, § 10-11) 
Cross reference- Sign regulations, § 94-406 et seq. 
Sec. 50-18. - Obstructing, damaging, etc., official notices or placards. 
    No person shall interfere with, obstruct, mutilate, conceal or tear down any official notice or placard posted by any city officer, unless permission is given by such officer to remove such notice. 
(Code 1976, § 10-25) 
Cross reference- Sign regulations, § 94-406 et seq. 
Sec. 50-19. - Unlawful posting of advertising matter, signs, etc., on public or private property. 
(a)  No person shall attach, place, paint, write, stamp or paste any sign, advertisement or other matter upon any lamppost, electric light, railway, telegraph or telephone pole, shade tree, fire hydrant, bridge, pavement, sidewalk, crosswalk or public building. This shall not be construed as preventing any public officer from doing any such act for any purpose authorized by the laws of the state or the Charter or ordinances of the city. 
(b)  No person shall attach, place, paint, write, stamp or paste any sign, advertisement or any other matter upon any house, wall, fence, gate, post, tree or treebox, without having first obtained the written permission of the owner, agent or occupants of the premises. 
(Code 1976, § 10-24) 
Cross reference- Sign regulations, § 94-406 et seq. 
Sec. 50-20. - Larceny. 
    Any person who shall commit the offense of larceny, by stealing, of the property of another, any money, goods or chattels, or any bank note, bank bill, bond, promissory note, due bill, bill of exchange or other bill, draft, order or certificate, or any book of accounts for or concerning money or goods due or to become due, or to be delivered, or any deed or writing containing a conveyance of land, or any other valuable contract in force, or any receipt, release or defeasance, or any writ, process or public record, or any person who shall aid and abet another in the commission thereof, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1976, § 10-26) 
State Law reference- Larceny, MCL 750.356 et seq., MSA 28.588. 
Sec. 50-20.5. - False pretenses; fraud. 
    No person shall obtain or attempt to obtain money, goods, property or services by fraud, trick or false pretenses. 
( Ord. No. 15-623, § 1, 2-9-15 ) 
Sec. 50-21. - Altering, removing, etc., merchandise tags. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to change, switch, remove, deface, replace, cover or otherwise alter any label, tag, mark or other identification which is intended to identify merchandise to be sold or to indicate the price of which any merchandise is to be sold, without the consent of the owner or vendor of such merchandise. 
(Code 1976, § 10-28) 
Sec. 50-22. - Retail fraud. 
    A person who does any of the following in a store or in its immediate vicinity is guilty of retail fraud, a misdemeanor: 
(1)  While a store is open to the public, alters, transfers, removes and replaces, conceals, or otherwise misrepresents the price at which property is offered for sale, with the intent not to pay for the property or to pay less than the price at which the property is offered for sale. 
(2)  While a store is open to the public, steals property of the store that is offered for sale. 
(3)  With intent to defraud, obtains or attempts to obtain money or property from the store as a refund or exchange for property that was not paid for and belongs to the store. 
(Code 1976, § 10-49) 
Sec. 50-23. - Prostitution. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in prostitution in the city. 
(Code 1976, § 10-30) 
Sec. 50-24. - Gambling and related offenses. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to: 
(1)  Keep or maintain or permit the use of a gambling room, table or equipment, or any policy or pool tickets, to be used for gambling on any premises occupied or controlled by him; 
(2)  Conduct or attend any cockfight or dogfight; or 
(3)  Place, receive or transmit any bet on the outcome of any race, contest or game of any kind whatsoever. 
(Code 1976, § 10-37) 
Sec. 50-25. - Frequenting, operating, etc., unlawful business. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to attend, frequent, operate or be an occupant or inmate of any place where prostitution, gambling, the illegal sale of intoxicating liquor or any other illegal or immoral business or occupation is permitted or conducted. 
(Code 1976, § 10-4) 
Cross reference- Alcoholic liquors, ch. 6. 
Sec. 50-26. - Obscene, blasphemous, etc., language. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to utter any vile, blasphemous, vulgar or obscene language in any public place or in such a way as to subject the public or any woman or child to such language. 
(Code 1976, § 10-31) 
State Law reference- Indecent language, MCL 750.103, 750.337, MSA 28.298, 28.569. 
Sec. 50-27. - Trespass. 
(a)  It shall be a trespass and unlawful for any person to willfully enter upon the lands or premises of another without lawful authority, after having been forbidden so to do by the owner, lessee, custodian or other person legally in possession thereof or his agent or servant, or for any person being upon the land or premises of another, upon being notified to depart therefrom by the owner, lessee, custodian or other person legally in possession thereof, or his agent or servant, without lawful authority to neglect or refuse to depart therefrom. The owner or lessee of any lands may erect a poster, sign or other form of notice to forbid entry thereon or any part, portion or area thereof, at a place or places where such poster, sign or other form of notice may reasonably be seen. 
(b)  It shall be a trespass and unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle, which term is defined to include a motorcycle, over or upon private property without the consent of the owner of such land or of a tenant or other person legally in occupancy or possession of such land. 
(c)  Unless the operator of a motor vehicle shall operate such motor vehicle upon private property for the purpose of a business or pleasure visit with a legal occupant of such private property, the operator shall secure a written permit from the owner or such tenant or person in legal possession of such land for the operation of such motor vehicle thereon. 
(d)  The operation of a motor vehicle over or upon privately owned land by one not entitled to possession of such land and not engaged in performing a duty or function prescribed by law or without the written permit required by this section shall be prima facie evidence of a trespass and of operation of the motor vehicle upon private property without proper authority. 
(Code 1976, § 10-27) 
Cross reference- Traffic and vehicles, ch. 82. 
State Law reference- Trespass, MCL 750.546 et seq., MSA 28.814 et seq. 
Sec. 50-28. - Window peeping. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in any window peeping in the city. 
(Code 1976, § 10-33) 
State Law reference- Person found window peeping defined as a disorderly person, MCL 750.167(1)(c), MSA 28.364(1)(c). 
Sec. 50-29. - Indecent exposure. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to make any immoral exhibition or indecent exposure of his person. 
(Code 1976, § 10-34) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 750.335a, MSA 28.567(1). 
Sec. 50-30. - Nude swimming or bathing. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to swim or bathe in the nude in any public place. 
(Code 1976, § 10-35) 
Cross reference- Parks and recreation, ch. 54. 
Sec. 50-31. - Swimming in unguarded waters. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to swim, bathe or wade in any unguarded creek, stream, pond, lake, pit or quarry located in any public park, other public place or on property other than one's own. "Unguarded" shall mean where a lifeguard or other adult reasonably capable of performing the functions of a lifeguard is not in attendance. 
(Code 1976, § 10-36) 
Cross reference- Parks and recreation, ch. 54. 
Sec. 50-32. - Fortunetelling, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to tell or pretend to tell fortunes for hire, gain, reward or profit, whether by means of cards, tokens, trances, inspection of the hands or skull, mindreading, consulting the movements of the heavenly bodies, or otherwise; or for hire, gain, reward or profit, pretend to enable another to recover lost or stolen property, pretend to give success in any business, enterprise, speculation or game of chance, or by improper means induce any person to dispose of property in favor of another. 
(Code 1976, § 10-38) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 750.267 et seq., MSA 28.478 et seq. 
Sec. 50-33. - False registration for overnight accommodations. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to register at any hotel, roominghouse, trailer camp, tourist home, motel or other place offering overnight accommodations to the public under an assumed name, or as the wife or husband of any person to whom he is not legally married. 
(Code 1976, § 10-39) 
Sec. 50-34. - Reserved.
