DIVISION 1. - GENERAL 

Sec. 54-1. - Purpose. 
    The parks of the city are valuable resources designed to provide public park and recreation opportunities. The purpose of this article is to protect the public health, safety and welfare by providing for the safe and efficient operation of city parks. 
(Ord. No. 04-522, § 1, 12-13-04) 
Sec. 54-2. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this article shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates another meaning: 
    City park means the entire area of Harmon Park, Community Park, English Hills Park, Alpine Estates Park, West Chesterfield Park, City Central Park, Lincoln Lawns Park, Orchard Ridge Park, and any other parks established by the city or otherwise designated by the city commission for use by the public for park purposes, including, but not limited to, parking lots and driveways providing access to public streets. 
    Motor vehicle means a motorized vehicle including, without limitation, automobiles, trucks, buses, tractors, motorcycles, mopeds, all-terrain vehicles, motor scooters, snowmobiles, and any other vehicle propelled by a motor except electric wheelchairs or other electrically powered vehicles designed to be operated at a speed of not more than five miles per hour. 
    Person means any individual, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind. 
    Wildlife means any living creature, not human, wild by nature, including mammals, birds, fish, amphibians, reptiles, crustaceans and mollusks. 
(Ord. No. 04-522, § 1, 12-13-04) 
DIVISION 2. - REGULATIONS 

Sec. 54-3. - Park hours. 
(a)  Except as provided in subsection (b), city parks shall be closed between one-half hour after sunset and 6:00 a.m. The city commission by resolution may close city parks or establish different closing hours provided that adequate notice of such closing or the revised park hours is posted. The mayor shall also have the authority to order the closing of a city park or any part thereof in the event of an emergency or disaster and such closing shall immediately be posted. 
(b)  Events sponsored by the city in a city park may proceed beyond one-half hour after sunset. In such cases, the city park shall be closed from one-half hour after completion of the event until 6:00 a.m. 
(c)  No person shall remain or enter a city park, or any part thereof, when the city park is closed pursuant to subsection (a) or subsection (b), whichever is applicable. This subsection shall not apply to law enforcement officers, firefighters, and other authorized city officers, agents, and employees performing city functions. 
(Ord. No. 04-522, § 1, 12-13-04) 
Sec. 54-4. - Preservation of real and personal property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to mark, deface, disfigure, injure, tamper with, displace, or remove any buildings (including restrooms), bridges, fountains, playground equipment, tables, benches, fireplaces, railings, paving, or paving materials, water lines or other utilities, signs, notices or placards, (whether temporary or permanent), monuments, stakes, posts or other boundary markers, or any other structures, equipment, facilities, appurtenances, or other real or personal property belonging to a city park or any other person or entity within a city park. This section shall not apply to law enforcement officers, firefighters, and other authorized city officers, agents, and employees performing city functions. 
(Ord. No. 04-522, § 1, 12-13-04) 
Sec. 54-5. - Preservation of natural features. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to damage, cut, carve, mark, transplant, destroy, or remove any plant or tree, injure or remove any bark or wood, pick flowers or harvest seed of any tree or plant, dig in or otherwise disturb or remove soil, sand, grass, rock, minerals, stones, ground cover, or other surface or subsurface materials, excavate any natural feature by tool, equipment or explosive, or in any other way injure the natural features of any area in a city park. This section shall not apply to law enforcement officers, firefighters, and other authorized city officers, agents, and employees performing city functions. 
(Ord. No. 04-522, § 1, 12-13-04) 
Sec. 54-6. - Preservation of wildlife. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to hunt, pursue with dogs, trap, or in any other way pursue, injure, tease, or feed any noxious substances to, or throw objects at, any wildlife, including the young or the habitat of any wildlife, found within the confines of a city park, or to attempt to do any of the above. Any wildlife killed, taken or in the possession of any person in a city park in violation of this section shall be considered contraband, and may be seized and confiscated by law enforcement officers or city officers and employees. This section shall not apply to law enforcement officers, firefighters, and other authorized city officers, agents, and employees performing city functions. 
(Ord. No. 04-522, § 1, 12-13-04) 
Sec. 54-7. - Horses; livestock. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to ride or bring a horse in a city park, or to bring any other livestock into a city park, without a special permit from the city manager or his or her designee pursuant to subsection 54-29(b) for a city-sponsored event. 
(Ord. No. 04-522, § 1, 12-13-04) 
Sec. 54-8. - Fishing. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to fish in a city park except for catch-and-release fishing in an area specifically posted for fishing or except as permitted at a city-sponsored event. 
(Ord. No. 04-522, § 1, 12-13-04) 
Sec. 54-9. - Swimming; boating. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to wade, swim, or enter the water in ponds or other bodies of water within a city park. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate, occupy, or use a boat or other watercraft in a pond or other body of water within a city park. This subsection shall not apply to law enforcement officers, fire fighters, and other authorized city officers, agents, or employees performing city functions. 
(Ord. No. 04-522, § 1, 12-13-04) 
Sec. 54-10. - Animal control; defecation. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to allow an animal in a city park without the animal being on a suitable leash not longer than six feet, or on a suitable physical restraint, within the immediate control of a competent person. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person owning or having custody or control of an animal to intentionally, or through failure to exercise due care, permit or allow the animal to defecate on property within a city park unless such person immediately collects all fecal matter deposited by the animal and deposits such matter in an appropriate receptacle designed for such purpose or carries such matter away from the park. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person owning or having custody or control of an animal to intentionally, or through failure to exercise due care, permit or allow the animal to create a nuisance by way of noise, odor, or other manner in a city park. 
(Ord. No. 04-522, § 1, 12-13-04) 
Sec. 54-11. - Fire. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully kindle, build, maintain or use a fire in any park, except for cooking fires in personal grills. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to leave a cooking fire unattended or fail to extinguish a cooking fire when not in use. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully drop, throw, or otherwise discard any burning fire-starting device, burning tobacco product, or other burning or inflammable material in a city park. 
(Ord. No. 04-522, § 1, 12-13-04) 
Sec. 54-12. - Littering; sanitation. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to dump, deposit, scatter, throw, leave, or cause or permit dumping, placing, throwing, or leaving of any litter, waste, yard waste, wastewater, glass, garbage, refuse, ashes, tobacco waste, sewage, noxious material, or any other material, solid or liquid, in a city park, or a city park building, except in receptacles provided for such purposes or in locations designated by posted notice. Where receptacles or locations are not provided, all such materials shall be carried away from the park by the person responsible for its presence. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to bring any hazardous waste, yard waste, household waste, solid or liquid waste, or any material described in subsection (a) above, into a city park with intent to dispose of said material in the park. 
(c)  This section shall not apply to temporary drop-off events or programs (such as yard waste or recycling drop-off programs) sponsored by the city. 
(Ord. No. 04-522, § 1, 12-13-04) 
Sec. 54-13. - Gambling. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct or participate in any form of gambling, lottery, or game of chance of any kind within a city park. This section shall not apply to raffles or other gambling activity for which a license or permit has been issued by the state and which is conducted by an organization permitted by state law to conduct such activity and held in conjunction with an event sponsored by the city. 
(Ord. No. 04-522, § 1, 12-13-04) 
Sec. 54-14. - Fireworks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to fire, discharge or have in possession any rocket, firecracker, sparkler, torpedo, squib or other fireworks or any substance of an explosive or dangerous nature within a city park, except pursuant to a fireworks permit issued by the city under chapter 38 of the City Code for a city-sponsored event. 
(Ord. No. 04-522, § 1, 12-13-04) 
Sec. 54-15. - Aircraft; radio-controlled airplanes. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to ascend or descend in any aircraft, hang glider, ultra light, hot air balloon, parachute, or other flying apparatus, within a city park without a special permit from the city manager or his or her designee pursuant to subsection 54-29(b) for a city-sponsored event. This section shall not apply to law enforcement officers performing police functions. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to fly or operate a radio-controlled airplane within a city park. 
(Ord. No. 04-522, § 1, 12-13-04) 
Sec. 54-16. - Construction. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to erect, construct, or maintain a building, structure or shelter of any kind, whether permanent or temporary, within a city park. This subsection shall not apply to authorized city officers, agents, or employees performing city functions. 
(Ord. No. 04-522, § 1, 12-13-04) 
Sec. 54-17. - Games; roller skating. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in games with roller skates, roller blades, or skateboards except in areas designated for such purposes. 
(Ord. No. 04-522, § 1, 12-13-04) 
Sec. 54-18. - Camping. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to stay or sleep overnight, or to erect a tent, shelter, or other temporary lodging, in a city park. 
(Ord. No. 04-522, § 1, 12-13-04) 
Sec. 54-19. - Motor vehicles. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, within a city park, to: 
(a)  Fail to comply with all applicable provisions of the Michigan Vehicle Code and the Uniform Traffic Code adopted by the city pursuant to chapter 82 of the City Code with respect to equipment and operation of vehicles together with such provisions as are contained in this article and other ordinances. 
(b)  Fail to obey all law enforcement officers and city employees, such persons being hereby authorized and instructed to direct traffic whenever and wherever needed in city parks on the highways, streets or roads immediately adjacent thereto. 
(c)  Fail to observe carefully all traffic signs indicating speed, direction, caution, stopping, or parking, and all other signs posted for proper control and to safeguard life and property. 
(d)  Operate or drive a motor vehicle at a rate of speed exceeding 15 miles an hour. 
(e)  Operate or drive a motor vehicle on any area other than on park roads designated for vehicular travel except for loading and unloading expressly authorized by a permit issued pursuant to this article. 
(f)  Park a motor vehicle in any area other than an established or designated parking area except for loading and unloading expressly authorized by a permit issued pursuant to this article. 
(g)  Fail to comply with section 54-31 of the City Code which prohibits the operation, driving, parking, placing or occupying of any motor vehicle on recreational trailways, as defined therein, including recreational trailways within city parks. 
(h)  Park or store any motor vehicle overnight within a city park. Law enforcement officers are hereby authorized to remove any vehicles so parked or stored. 
(i)  Operate or drive an all-terrain vehicle, three-wheel vehicle, snowmobile, dirt bike, or mini-bike on roads, in parking areas, or in any other location, in a city park. 
(j)  This section shall not apply to law enforcement, fire, or other emergency vehicles, or to vehicles of authorized city employees used in the performance of official duties. 
(Ord. No. 04-522, § 1, 12-13-04) 
Sec. 54-20. - Alcoholic beverages. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to possess, consume, or sell alcoholic beverages within a city park except as provided in subsection 6-2(b) of the City Code. 
Sec. 54-21. - Sound amplification. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to make any sound within a city park that may be heard by persons of normal sensitivity at a distance of more than 300 feet. However, this section shall not apply to city-sponsored events, to spectators and participants at events for which a permit has been issued pursuant to subsection 54-29(b) or subsection 54-29.1(a), or to the operation of park maintenance equipment by authorized city employees. 
(Ord. No. 04-522, § 1, 12-13-04) 
Sec. 54-22. - Golf; other games. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to play golf or practice golf shots within a city park except in conjunction with a city recreation department-sponsored or -approved program. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to participate in archery or the playing of any games with potentially dangerous propelled objects such as arrows, stones, javelins, or similar objects. 
(Ord. No. 04-522, § 1, 12-13-04) 
Sec. 54-23. - Climbing. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, other than authorized city officers, employees, and law enforcement officers, to climb any building, walkway, or bridge, or to stand or climb upon monuments, fountains, railings, fences, or upon any other property within a city park not designed or customarily used for such purposes. 
(Ord. No. 04-522, § 1, 12-13-04) 
Sec. 54-24. - Restriction of use. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, other than city officers, employees, and law enforcement officers, to attempt to prevent any other person from entering, leaving or making full use of a city park, by force, threats, unlawful fencing or any other means. 
(Ord. No. 04-522, § 1, 12-13-04) 
Sec. 54-25. - Admission charges for activities. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to charge admission for any activity within a city park without a special permit from the city manager or his or her designee pursuant to subsection 54-29(b) in connection with a city-sponsored event. 
(Ord. No. 04-522, § 1, 12-13-04) 
Sec. 54-26. - Commercial activities; fundraising. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to peddle or solicit business, or to sell, distribute, or display for sale, goods, material, services, or signs of a commercial nature. This section shall not apply to commercial activities or advertisements approved by the city manager or his or her designee as part of city-sponsored events or to picnics and social parties by commercial and private organizations, limited to their members, employees and families, subject to the requirements of this article. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in fundraising, or to solicit, display for sale, or sell goods or services, for a nonprofit organization without a special permit issued pursuant to subsection 54-29(b). 
(Ord. No. 04-522, § 1, 12-13-04) 
Sec. 54-27. - Ejection of violators. 
    Law enforcement officers and authorized city officers, agents, or employees shall have authority and power to eject any person from any city park when such person violates any of the provisions or requirements of this article, or violates other applicable laws, ordinances, or rules and regulations within a city park. The refusal or failure of any person to leave the city park when ordered so to do by law enforcement officers, or authorized city officers, agents, or employees, or the return to a city park by the person so ejected before the expiration of the period of ejection, shall be deemed to be a violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 04-522, § 1, 12-13-04) 
Sec. 54-28. - Rules and regulations. 
(a)  In addition to the provisions of this article, the city manager is authorized to promulgate supplemental rules and regulations applicable to city parks for the protection of the public health, safety and welfare and to provide for the safe and efficient use of city parks. Copies of the rules and regulations promulgated pursuant to this section shall be kept on file in the office of the city clerk. No rule or regulation, or any change in any rule or regulation, shall be effective until approved by resolution of the city commission. Upon promulgation and approval, the supplemental rules and regulations shall be posted in each city park. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to violate any supplemental rule or regulation approved by the city commission and posted pursuant to subsection (a). 
(Ord. No. 04-522, § 1, 12-13-04) 
DIVISION 3. - PERMITS AND ENFORCEMENT 

Sec. 54-29. - Park facilities; permits. 
(a)  The recreation department may issue permits for rental of city park facilities such as shelters, athletic fields and courts (including in-line skating rink), and concessions. The city commission may, by resolution, establish rental fees for such facilities. Permits shall not be issued without payment of the required rental fees. The recreation department may impose reasonable conditions on a permit to provide for the safe and efficient use of city parks and to avoid disruption of the public's use of city parks consistent with the intent of this article. The recreation department, with the approval of the city manager, shall establish policies and procedures for the application and issuance of permits. Such policies and procedures may include preferences for city residents in the reservation and use of park facilities. 
(b)  The city manager or his or her designee may issue special permits for certain activities as provided in this article if the city manager or his or her designee finds that the proposed activity shall not interfere with the safe and efficient use of a city park consistent with the intent of this article. The city commission may, by resolution, establish fees for special permits issued under this section. The city manager or his or her designee may establish reasonable conditions on a special permit to provide for the safe and efficient use of city parks and to avoid disruption of the public's use of city parks consistent with the intent of this article. 
(c)  A permittee or his or her designee shall be present for the entire specified use and shall have physical possession of the permit. It shall be unlawful for any person to fail to produce his or her permit upon request of an authorized city employee or a law enforcement officer. A permit may be revoked for good cause by the city manager or his or her designee, or by a law enforcement officer, upon violation of any provision of this article. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to violate the terms and conditions of a permit issued under this article. 
(e)  A permit shall not be issued for the exclusive use of any city park and it shall be unlawful for any permittee or person to exclude any member of the public from a city park. 
(f)  It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere with, prevent the use of, occupy, or loiter or remain in, a park facility within a city park for which a valid permit has been issued pursuant to this article. 
(g)  Park facilities for which a permit has not been issued pursuant to this section are available to any member of the public on a first-come, first-served basis. It shall be unlawful for any person to disrupt or prevent the use of a park facility within a city park by a person or group who is using the park facility on a first-come, first-served basis when no permit has been issued. 
(h)  It shall be unlawful for any person to fail to comply with the direction of a law enforcement officer or an authorized city employee for the regulation of park activities for the prevention of congestion and to secure the use of a park for the comfort and convenience of all persons. 
(Ord. No. 04-522, § 1, 12-13-04; Ord. No. 05-540, § 1, 12-12-05) 
Sec. 54-29.1. - Permits; large gatherings. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly advertise, publicize, organize, or participate in any event, activity, or gathering in a city park for which more than 50 persons are expected to or actually attend without first having received a permit from the city manager or his or her designee. The permit required by this section shall be in addition to permits, if any, obtained pursuant to section 54-29. The city commission may, by resolution, establish administrative fees for permits issued under this section. 
(b)  A permit pursuant to subsection (a) above shall be issued if the city manager or his or her designee determines that the proposed activity is consistent with purposes of city parks, adequate safety and sanitary precautions will be taken and the proposed activity will not be a hazard to the safety of the public or city employees, and the activity will not unreasonably interfere with the use of the park by the public. A permit pursuant to subsection (a) may impose reasonable conditions for the safe and efficient use of city parks consistent with the intent of this article. The city manager or his or her designee shall act upon a complete application for a permit under this section without unreasonable delay which shall in no event be longer than ten days. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly violate the terms and conditions of a permit issued under this section. 
(d)  For good cause shown, the city manager or his or her designee may waive the requirements of this section. 
(Ord. No. 04-522, § 1, 12-13-04; Ord. No. 05-540, § 2, 12-12-05) 
Sec. 54-29.2. - Authority to require bond for use of facilities. 
    Where there is risk of public injury or property damage, the city manager may require any person, group or organization desiring a permit under section 54-29 or section 54-29.1 to furnish security (such as deposits, bonds, insurance, or other financial mechanisms, as determined by the city manager or his or her designee) in amounts and types satisfactory to him or her, and to hold the city harmless from injuries or damage resulting from activities engaged in by such person, group or organization. 
(Ord. No. 04-522, § 1, 12-13-04) 
Sec. 54-29.3. - Penalties; sanctions; other code provisions. 
(a)  A person who violates sections 54-3, 54-4, 54-5, 54-6, 54-11, 54-13, 54-14, 54-20, 54-24, 54-27, 54-29(e), 54-29(f), 54-29(g), 54-29(h), and 54-29.1, of this article is guilty of a misdemeanor, and shall be punishable by a fine of not more than $500.00 or imprisonment for not more than 90 days, or both. 
(b)  A person who violates sections 54-7, 54-8, 54-9, 54-10, 54-12, 54-15, 54-16, 54-17, 54-18, 54-19 (except section 54-19(a)), 54-21, 54-22, 54-23, 54-25, 54-26, 54-28, 54-29(c), and 54-29(d) of this article is responsible for a municipal civil infraction in accordance with section 1-11 of this Code, and subject to payment of a civil fine of not less than $50.00, plus costs and other sanctions, for each infraction. Repeat offenses under such sections shall be subject to increased fines as provided by subsection 1-11(c)(2) of this Code. 
(c)  A person who violates subsection 54-19(a) of this article is either guilty of a misdemeanor or responsible for a municipal civil infraction in accordance with the applicable provision of the Michigan Vehicle Code or Uniform Traffic Code adopted pursuant to chapter 82. 
(d)  Nothing in this article shall be construed to repeal, abrogate, annul or in any way impair or interfere with other general provisions of the city code or laws, rules, or regulations that are otherwise applicable within city parks. Nothing in this article shall relieve any person from complying with all other provisions of the City Code or applicable laws, rules and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 04-522, § 1, 12-13-04) 
ARTICLE II. - RECREATIONAL TRAILWAYS 

Sec. 54-30. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article: 
    Motor vehicle means a motorized vehicle including, but not limited to, automobiles, trucks, buses, tractors, motorcycles, mopeds, all-terrain vehicles, motor scooters, snowmobiles, and any other vehicle propelled by a motor other than electric wheelchairs. 
    Recreational trailway means a trail, path or corridor that is: (a) outside of a street right-of-way, (b) owned or under the control of the city, and (c) designated by the city commission for use by the public for recreational purposes such as bicycling, walking, jogging, and similar nonmotorized uses. 
(Ord. No. 04-519, § 2, 9-27-04) 
Sec. 54-31. - Prohibition of motor vehicles. 
(a)  No person shall operate, drive, park, place, or occupy a motor vehicle, or permit the operation, driving, parking, placing or occupancy of any motor vehicle owned or possessed by him or her, upon a recreational trailway. 
(b)  Subsection (a) above shall not apply to emergency vehicles (such as fire vehicles, police vehicles, and ambulances) or to maintenance, construction or other vehicles expressly permitted by the city for operation upon a recreational trailway. 
(Ord. No. 04-519, § 2, 9-27-04) 
Sec. 54-32. - Posting. 
    This article shall be posted and maintained near each gate or principal entrance of each recreational trailway to which this article applies, as designated by the city commission, in accordance with section 4m of the Home Rule Cities Act (MCL 117.4m). 
(Ord. No. 04-519, § 2, 9-27-04) 
Sec. 54-33. - Trailway municipal civil infraction. 
(a)  A person who violates any provision of this article is responsible for a trailway municipal civil infraction, subject to payment of a civil fine of not less than $50.00, plus costs and other sanctions, for each infraction. Repeat offenses under this article shall be subject to increased fines as provided by subsection 1-11(c)(2) of this Code. A civil fine for a trailway municipal civil infraction shall not exceed $500.00. 
(b)  In addition, the provisions of section 48-4.2 of the Code shall apply to a recreational trailway municipal civil infraction. 
(Ord. No. 04-519, § 2, 9-27-04) 
Chapter 58 - PLANNING[1] 
Footnotes:

Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; soil redistribution, § 34-181 et seq.; erosion and sedimentation prevention, § 34-206 et seq.; floods, ch. 42; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 70; subdivisions, ch. 74; utilities, ch. 86; vegetation, ch. 90; zoning, ch. 94. 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate land use, MCL 125.581 et seq., MSA 5.2931 et seq.; municipal planning, MCL 125.31 et seq., MSA 5.2991 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 58-1-58-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PLANNING COMMISSION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; approval or disapproval of preliminary subdivision plats by planning commission, § 74-34; recommendation of amendments to zoning chapter by planning commission, § 94-6; review of preliminary plans for site condominium projects by planning commission, § 94-308; planning commission recommendations relative to site condominium projects, § 94-309. 

Sec. 58-26. - Created. 
    A city planning commission is hereby created under and pursuant to Act No. 285 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1931 (MCL 125.31 et seq., MSA 5.2991 et seq.), as amended. 
(Code 1976, § 2-16) 
Sec. 58-27. - Composition; appointment of members; compensation. 
    The planning commission shall consist of nine members, one of whom shall be a member of the city commission to be selected by the city commission to serve as a member ex officio, and eight of whom shall be appointed by the mayor. The appointments by the mayor shall be subject to approval by majority vote of the city commission. The eight members appointed by the mayor shall be representative, insofar as possible, of different professions or occupations. All appointed members of the planning commission may be compensated at a rate to be determined by the city commission. 
(Code 1976, § 2-17; Ord. No. 99-356, § 1, 5-24-99) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 125.33(2), MSA 5.2993(2). 
Sec. 58-28. - Terms of members. 
    The term of the ex officio member of the planning commission shall be determined by the city commission and stated in the resolution appointing the member, but shall not exceed the member's term of office on the city commission. The term of such appointed member shall be three years or until his successor takes office. 
(Code 1976, § 2-18; Ord. No. 99-356, § 2, 5-24-99) 
Sec. 58-29. - Members to hold no other city office; exception. 
    The appointed members of the planning commission, other than the ex officio member, shall hold no other municipal office except that one of such members may be a member of the zoning board of appeals. 
(Code 1976, § 2-19; Ord. No. 99-356, § 3, 5-24-99) 
Cross reference- Board of zoning appeals, § 94-56 et seq. 
Sec. 58-30. - Removal of members; filling of vacancies. 
    Members of the planning commission appointed by the mayor may be removed by the mayor for inefficiency, neglect of duty or malfeasance of office after a public hearing and subject to approval by a majority vote of the city commission. Vacancies for members of the planning commission appointed by the mayor occurring otherwise than through the expiration of terms shall be filled for the unexpired term by the mayor, subject to the approval by a majority vote of the city commission. The ex officio member of the planning commission may, after public hearing, be removed by the city commission for inefficiency, neglect of duty, or malfeasance in office. A vacancy in the ex officio member's position shall be filled by the city commission for the unexpired term. 
(Code 1976, § 2-20; Ord. No. 99-356, § 4, 5-24-99) 
Sec. 58-31. - Travel expenses of members. 
    Members of the planning commission, when duly authorized by such commission, may attend city planning conferences or meetings of city planning institutes, or hearings upon pending city planning legislation, and the city commission may, by resolution spread upon its minutes, pay the reasonable traveling expenses incident to such attendance. 
(Code 1976, § 2-21) 
Sec. 58-32. - Organization; meetings; records. 
    The planning commission shall elect its chairman from the appointed members and create and fill such other of its offices as it may determine. The term of chairman shall be one year, with eligibility for reelection. The commission shall hold at least one regular meeting in each month. It shall adopt rules for transaction of business and shall keep a record of its resolutions, transactions, findings and determinations, which shall be a public record. 
(Code 1976, § 2-22) 
Sec. 58-33. - General powers and duties. 
    The planning commission shall, from time to time, recommend to the appropriate public officials programs for public structures and improvements and for the financing thereof. It shall be part of its duties to consult and advise with public officials and agencies, public utility companies, civic, educational, professional and other organizations, and with citizens with relation to the protecting or carrying out of the master plan adopted pursuant to this article. The planning commission shall have the right to accept and use gifts for the exercise of its functions. All city officials and employees shall, upon request, furnish to the planning commission, within a reasonable time, such available information as it may require for its work. The planning commission, its members, officers and employees, in the performance of their functions, may enter upon any land and make examinations and surveys and place and maintain necessary monuments and marks thereon. In general, the planning commission shall have such powers as may be necessary to enable it to fulfill its functions, promote municipal planning, or carry out the purposes of this article. 
(Code 1976, § 2-23) 
Sec. 58-34. - Hiring of employees; contracting for special services; expenditures. 
    The planning commission may appoint such employees as it may deem necessary for its work, whose appointment, promotion, demotion and removal shall be subject to the same provisions of law as govern other corresponding civil employees of the city. The planning commission may also contract with city planners, engineers, architects and other consultants for such services as it may require. The expenditures of the planning commission, exclusive of gifts, shall be within the amounts appropriated for the purpose by the city commission, which shall provide for funds, equipment and accommodations necessary for the planning commission's work. 
(Code 1976, § 2-24) 
Sec. 58-35. - Adoption and contents of master plan; amendments to plan. 
(a)  It shall be the function and duty of the planning commission to make and adopt a master plan for the physical development of the city, including any areas outside of its boundaries which, in the commission's judgment, bear relation to the planning of the city and the adjacent areas. Such plan, with the accompanying maps, plats, charts and descriptive matter, shall show the planning commission's recommendations for the development of such territory, including, among other things, the general location, character and extent of streets, viaducts, subways, waterways, bridges, waterfronts, boulevards, parkways, playgrounds and open spaces; the general location of public buildings and other public property; and the general location and extent of public utilities and terminals, whether publicly or privately owned or operated, for water, light, sanitation, transportation, communication, power and other purposes; also the removal, relocation, widening, narrowing, vacating, abandonment, change of use or extension of any of the foregoing ways, grounds, open spaces, buildings, property, utilities or terminals; the general location, character, layout and extent of community centers and neighborhood units; and the general character, extent and layout of the replanning and redevelopment of blighted districts and slum areas. 
(b)  The planning commission may from time to time adopt and publish a part or parts of the proposed master plan, any such part to cover one or more major sections or divisions of the city or one or more of the aforesaid or other functional matters to be included in the plan. The planning commission may from time to time amend, extend or add to the plan. In the preparation of such plan, the planning commission shall make careful and comprehensive surveys and studies of present conditions and future growth of the city with due regard to its relation to the neighborhood or neighboring territory. The plan shall be made with the general purpose of guiding and accomplishing a coordinated, adjusted and harmonious development of the city and its environs which will, in accordance with the present and future needs of the city, best promote health, safety, morals, order, convenience, prosperity and general welfare, as well as efficiency and economy in the process of development; including, among other things, adequate provision for traffic, the promotion of safety from fire and other dangers, adequate provision for light and air, the promotion of the healthful and convenient distribution of population and promotion of good civic design and arrangement, wise and efficient expenditure of public funds and the adequate provision of public utilities and other public requirements. 
(c)  The planning commission may adopt the master plan of the city, including any areas outside of its boundaries which, in the commission's judgment, bear relation to the planning of the city, as a whole by a single resolution or by successive resolutions adopt successive parts of the plan, such parts corresponding with major geographical sections or divisions of the city and surrounding areas or with functional subdivisions of the subject matter of the plan, and may adopt any amendment or extension thereof or addition thereto. 
(d)  Before the adoption of the plan or any part, amendment, extension or addition thereof, the planning commission shall hold at least one public hearing thereon, notice of the time and place of which shall be given not less than 15 days prior to such hearing by one publication in a newspaper of general circulation in the city, and by registered United States mail to each public utility company and to each railroad company owning or operating any public utility or railroad within the geographical sections or divisions of the city. The adoption of the plan or of any such part, amendment, extension or addition shall be by resolution of the planning commission carried by the affirmative votes of not less than six members of the commission. The resolution shall expressly refer to the maps and descriptive and other matters intended by the commission to form the whole or part of the plan, and the action taken shall be recorded on the map and plan and descriptive matter by the identifying signature of the chairman or secretary of the commission. An attested copy of the plan or part thereof shall be certified to the city commission and to the county register of deeds. 
(Code 1976, § 2-25) 
Sec. 58-36. - Promotion of public interest in master plan. 
    The planning commission shall have the power to promote public interest in and understanding of the master plan and to that end may publish and distribute copies of the plan or of any report and may employ such other means of publicity and education as it may determine. 
(Code 1976, § 2-26) 
Sec. 58-37. - Approval of public works-Generally. 
    Whenever the planning commission shall have adopted the master plan of the city or of one or more major sections or districts thereof, no street, square, park or other public way, ground or open space or public building or structure shall be constructed or authorized in the city or in such planned section and district until the location, character and extent thereof shall have been submitted to and approved by the planning commission; provided that, in case of disapproval, the planning commission shall communicate its reasons to the city commission which shall have the power to overrule such disapproval by a recorded vote of not less than two-thirds of its entire membership. If the public way, ground, space, building, structure or utility is one, the authorizing or financing of which does not, under the law or Charter provisions governing same, fall within the province of the city commission, then the submission to the planning commission shall be by the board, commission or body having such jurisdiction, and the planning commission's disapproval may be overruled by such board, commission or body by a vote of not less than two-thirds of its membership. The failure of the planning commission to take final action within 60 days from and after the date of official submission to it shall be deemed approval. 
(Code 1976, § 2-27) 
Cross reference- Parks and recreation, ch. 50; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 70. 
Sec. 58-38. - Same-Rescission of action. 
    Whenever the city commission shall have taken final action for the opening, widening or extension of any street, avenue or boulevard, or whenever the city commission shall have taken final action ordering that proceedings be instituted for the acquisition or enlargement of any park, playground, playfield or other public open space in conformity with the master plan, such final action shall not be rescinded until after the matter has been referred back to the planning commission for a report and until after a public hearing shall have been held. The city commission shall have the power to overrule the recommendation of the planning commission by a vote of not less than two-thirds of its entire membership. 
(Code 1976, § 2-28) 
Sec. 58-39. - Plans for future development. 
    For the purpose of furthering the desirable future development of the city and adjacent areas under the master plan, the planning commission, after the adoption of the master plan, may prepare coordinated and comprehensive programs of public structures and improvements which shall be accompanied by a program for the financing thereof. The commission may annually prepare such a program for the ensuing six years, which program shall show those public structures and improvements in the general order of their priority, which in the commission's judgment will be needed or desirable and can be financed and undertaken within the six-year period. Such comprehensive coordinated programs shall be based upon the requirements of the city and the adjacent areas related thereto in the master plan for all types of public improvements, and to that end, each agency or governmental unit concerned with such improvements shall, upon request, furnish the commission with lists, plans and estimates of time and cost of public improvements within the purview of such agency or governmental unit. 
(Code 1976, § 2-29) 
Sec. 58-40. - Duty to assist city commission on problems of zoning and related matters. 
    When requested to do so by the city commission, it shall be the duty of the planning commission to consider and make informal suggestions to the city commission regarding any application, petition or proposal for changing the zoning of any parcel of land in the city or such other related problems as the city commission shall request the planning commission to consider. Except when the planning commission is acting in its capacity specified in this article for formal adoptions or recommendations, which necessitate public hearings and specific approval or disapproval by the city commission, such informal suggestions shall not require public hearings or approval or disapproval by the city commission but shall only assist the city commission in its determination regarding the application, petition, proposal or other related problem. 
(Code 1976, § 2-30) 
Cross reference- Zoning, ch. 94. 
Sec. 58-41. - Powers and duties with respect to subdivisions. 
(a)  Whenever the planning commission shall have adopted a master plan relating to the major street system of the territory within its subdivision jurisdiction or any part thereof, and shall have filed a certified copy of such plan in the office of the county register of deeds, no plat of a subdivision of land within such territory or part shall be filed or recorded until it shall have been approved by the planning commission and such approval entered in writing on the plat by the chairman or secretary of the commission. 
(b)  Before exercising the powers referred to in subsection (a), the planning commission shall adopt regulations governing the subdivision of land within its jurisdiction. Such regulations may provide for the proper arrangement of streets in relation to other existing or planned streets and to the master plan, for adequate and convenient open spaces for traffic, utilities, access for firefighting apparatus, recreation, light and air, and for the avoidance of congestion of population, including minimum width and area of lots. Such regulations may include provisions as to the extent to which streets and other ways shall be graded and improved and to which water and sewer and other utility mains, piping or other facilities shall be installed as a condition precedent to the approval of the plat. The regulations or practice of the planning commission may provide for a tentative approval of the plat previous to such installation, but any such tentative approval shall be revocable and shall not be entered on the plat. In lieu of the completion of such improvements and utilities prior to the final approval of the plat, the planning commission may accept a bond with surety to secure to the city the actual construction and installation of such improvements or utilities at a time and according to specifications fixed by or in accordance with the regulations of the planning commission. The city shall have the power to enforce such bond by all appropriate legal and equitable remedies. All such regulations shall be published as provided by law for the publication of ordinances, and before adoption, a public hearing shall be held thereon. A copy thereof shall be certified by the planning commission to the register of deeds of the county. 
(c)  The planning commission shall approve, modify or disapprove a plat within 60 days after the submission thereof to it; otherwise such plat shall be deemed to have been approved, and a certificate to that effect shall be issued by the planning commission on demand. The applicant for the planning commission's approval may waive this requirement and consent to an extension of such period. The ground of disapproval of any plat shall be stated upon the records of the planning commission. 
(d)  Any plat submitted to the planning commission shall contain the name and address of a person to whom notice of a hearing shall be sent, and no plat shall be acted on by the commission without affording a hearing thereon. Notice shall be sent to such address by registered mail of the time and place of such hearing, not less than five days before the date fixed therefor. Similar notice shall be mailed to the owners of land immediately adjoining the platted land, as their names appear upon the plats in the county auditor's office or as their addresses appear upon the records of the city in the directory of the city or on the tax records of the city. 
(e)  Every plat approved by the planning commission shall, by virtue of such approval, be deemed to be an amendment of or an addition to or a detail of the city plan and a part thereof. Approval of a plat shall not be deemed to constitute or effect an acceptance by the public of any street or other open space shown upon the plat. 
(f)  The planning commission may, from time to time, recommend to the city commission amendment of the zoning ordinance, included as chapter 94 of this Code, or map, or additions thereto, to conform to the planning commission's recommendations for the zoning regulations of the territory comprised within approved subdivisions. The planning commission shall have the power to agree with the applicant upon use, height, area or bulk requirements or restrictions governing buildings and premises within the subdivision, provided such requirements or restrictions do not authorize the violation of the then effective zoning ordinance. Such requirements or restrictions shall be stated upon the plat prior to the approval and recording thereof and shall have the same force of law and be enforceable in the same manner and with the same sanctions and penalties and subject to the same power of amendment or repeal as though set out as part of the zoning ordinance or map. 
(Code 1976, § 2-31) 
Cross reference- Subdivisions, ch. 74. 
Secs. 58-42-58-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DOWNTOWN DEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

Sec. 58-61. - Title. 
    This article shall be known and may be cited as the Downtown Development Authority Article. 
(Code 1976, § 61/2-11) 
Sec. 58-62. - Definitions. 
    The terms used in this article shall have the same meaning as given them in Act No. 197 or as in this section provided, unless the context clearly indicates to the contrary. As used in this article: 
    Act No. 197 means Act No. 197 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1975 (MCL 125.1651 et seq., MSA 5.3010(1) et seq.), as amended. 
    Authority means the downtown development authority of the city created by Ordinance No. 86-332. 
    Board or board of directors means the board of directors of the authority. 
    Downtown district means the downtown district designated in this article, as amended. 
(Code 1976, § 61/2-12) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 58-63. - Purpose and findings. 
    The city commission hereby determines and finds that it is in the best interests of the city to create a public body corporate in order to halt property value deterioration and increase property tax valuation where possible in the downtown district, eliminate the causes of that deterioration and promote economic growth pursuant to Act No. 197. 
(Code 1976, § 61/2-13) 
Sec. 58-64. - Created; general powers. 
    There is hereby created pursuant to Act No. 197 a downtown development authority for the city. The authority shall be a public body corporate and shall be known and exercise its powers under the title of "Downtown Development Authority of the City of Walker." The authority may adopt a seal, may sue and be sued in any court of this state, and shall possess all of the powers necessary to carry out the purpose of its incorporation as provided in this article and in Act No. 197. The enumeration of a power in this article or in Act No. 197 shall not be construed as a limitation upon the general powers of the authority. 
(Code 1976, § 61/2-14) 
Sec. 58-65. - Description of downtown district. 
(a)  The downtown district in which the authority shall exercise its powers as provided by Act No. 197 shall consist of the property in the city described on Exhibit A attached to Ordinance No. 86-332 and made a part thereof, subject to such changes as may be made pursuant to such ordinance and Act No. 197. 
(b)  Effective August 11, 1992, the boundaries of the downtown district shall consist of the property in the city described on Exhibit B attached to Ordinance No. 92-410 and made a part thereof, subject to such changes as may be made pursuant to this article and Act No. 197. 
(Code 1976, § 61/2-15; Ord. No. 92-410, § 1, 8-11-92) 
Sec. 58-66. - Board of directors. 
    The authority shall be under the supervision and control of a board of directors consisting of the city manager and eight members. The members shall be appointed by the mayor subject to approval by the commission. Eligibility for membership on the board and terms of office shall be as provided in Act No. 197. Each member shall hold office until the member's successor is appointed. 
(Code 1976, § 61/2-16) 
Sec. 58-67. - Powers of the authority. 
    The authority shall possess all of the powers necessary to carry out the purposes of its incorporation and shall have all powers provided by Act No. 197, except that the authority is prohibited from levying or from requesting the approval of the commission for the levy of any ad valorem property tax as set forth in section 12 of Act No. 197. This prohibition on the levy of an ad valorem property tax shall remain in effect for the duration of the authority itself. 
(Code 1976, § 61/2-17) 
Sec. 58-68. - Fiscal year; adoption of budget; reports; audits. 
(a)  The fiscal year of the authority shall begin on July 1 of each year and end on June 30 of the following year, or such other fiscal year as may be adopted by the city. 
(b)  The board shall annually prepare a budget and shall submit it to the city manager for submission to the commission. The board shall not finally adopt a budget for any fiscal year until the budget has been approved by the commission. The board may, however, temporarily adopt a budget in connection with the operation of any improvements which have been financed by revenue bonds where required to do so by the ordinance authorizing the revenue bonds. 
(c)  The authority shall be audited annually by the same independent auditors auditing the city, and copies of the audit report shall be filed with the commission. 
(Code 1976, § 61/2-18) 
Cross reference- Finance, § 2-81 et seq. 
Sec. 58-69. - Termination. 
    Upon completion of its purposes, the authority may be dissolved by an ordinance duly adopted by the commission. The property and assets of the authority, after dissolution and satisfaction of its obligations, shall revert to the city. 
(Code 1976, § 61/2-19) 
Secs. 58-70-58-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - DOWNTOWN REDEVELOPMENT MANAGEMENT BOARD[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

Sec. 58-91. - Title. 
    This article shall be known and may be cited as the Downtown Redevelopment Management Article. 
(Code 1976, § 61/2-30) 
Sec. 58-92. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Downtown development authority board means the board of directors of the downtown development authority of the city appointed and serving pursuant to article III of this chapter. 
    Principal shopping area means the portion of the city described in section 58-99 of this article. 
(Code 1976, § 61/2-31) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 58-93. - Established; purpose. 
    Pursuant to Act No. 120 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1961 (MCL 125.981 et seq., MSA 5.3533(1) et seq.), as amended, the city hereby establishes the downtown redevelopment management board for the management of the ongoing maintenance, promotion, security, and continued operation of redevelopment projects within the principal shopping area. The downtown redevelopment management board shall be a public body corporate which may sue and be sued. 
(Code 1976, § 61/2-32) 
Sec. 58-94. - Members of board. 
    The downtown redevelopment management board shall consist of the nine members of the downtown development authority board appointed and serving pursuant to article III of this chapter. The terms of office of each member of the downtown redevelopment management board shall correspond to that member's term of office on the downtown development authority board. Members of the downtown redevelopment management board shall serve without compensation, but may be reimbursed for actual and necessary expenses. 
(Code 1976, § 61/2-33) 
Sec. 58-95. - Powers of board. 
    The downtown redevelopment management board shall be responsible for managing the ongoing maintenance, security, promotion, and continued operation of redevelopment projects within the principal shopping area. In furtherance of these objectives, the board shall have the following powers: 
(1)  Subject to the prior approval of the city commission, to enter into and administer contracts for the ongoing maintenance, promotion, security, and continued operation of redevelopment projects within the principal shopping area. 
(2)  To recommend special assessments to the city commission to defray the cost of the ongoing maintenance, promotion, security, and continued operation of redevelopment projects within the principal shopping area. 
(3)  To receive from the city funds appropriated from special assessments levied against real property in the principal shopping area, or a portion thereof, and to receive other funds appropriated by the city, if any, to defray the costs of maintenance, security, promotion, and continued operation of redevelopment projects within the principal shopping area. 
(4)  To accept grants, gifts or donations of property, labor, or other things of value from a public or private source. 
(5)  To perform any act necessary or incidental to the exercise of its powers set forth in this section. 
(Code 1976, § 61/2-34) 
Sec. 58-96. - Budget. 
(a)  The fiscal year of the downtown redevelopment management board shall correspond to the fiscal year of the city. 
(b)  The downtown redevelopment management board shall annually prepare and adopt a budget for the ensuing fiscal year, subject to the prior approval of the budget by the city commission. The city commission reserves the sole and absolute right to determine the amount of special assessments, if any, to be levied on property within the principal shopping area and the amount, if any, appropriated to the board from such special assessments or from other city funds. 
(Code 1976, § 61/2-35) 
Cross reference- Finance, § 2-81 et seq. 
Sec. 58-97. - Meetings; rules of procedure. 
    The business which the downtown redevelopment management board may perform shall be conducted at a meeting held in compliance with Act No. 267 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1976 (MCL 15.261 et seq., MSA 4.1800(11) et seq.), as amended (open meetings act). The downtown redevelopment management board shall adopt such rules of procedure as it deems appropriate, provided that such rules are consistent with this article and Act No. 267 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1976, as amended. 
(Code 1976, § 61/2-36) 
Sec. 58-98. - Termination. 
    The downtown redevelopment management board may be dissolved at the sole discretion of the city commission. Upon dissolution, all assets of the board remaining after the satisfaction of the obligations of the board shall become the sole property of the city. 
(Code 1976, § 61/2-37) 
Sec. 58-99. - Principal shopping area. 
    For purposes of this article, the principal shopping area shall consist of those properties included in the downtown district for the Downtown Development Authority of the City of Walker, as amended from time to time. 
(Code 1976, § 61/2-38; Ord. No. 93-418, § 1, 4-27-93; Ord. No. 07-552, § 1, 10-8-07) 
Chapter 62 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Solid waste disposal at outdoor assemblies, § 10-80; environment, ch. 34; nuisances, § 34-26 et seq.; abandoned refrigerators and other airtight containers, § 50-4; utilities, ch. 86. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 62-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in articles I and II, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Approved incinerator and approved garbage grinder mean incinerators and garbage grinders, respectively, which conform with all city ordinance requirements, are used exclusively to dispose of solid waste generated by the occupant of the site of generation on which they are located, and are consistent with the county solid waste management plan. 
    Ashes means the residue from the burning of wood, coal, coke, refuse, wastewater sludge, or other combustible materials. 
    Board of public works means the county board of public works established pursuant to the provisions of Act No. 185 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1957 (MCL 123.731 et seq.), as amended. 
    Combustible waste means solid waste that is combustible in the MBI as shall be determined solely by the board of public works. "Combustible waste" shall include: 
(1)  Garbage; 
(2)  Combustible rubbish, such as paper, cardboard, cartons, wood, boxes, rags, cloth, bedding, leather, grass, leaves and brush, yard trimmings, tree limbs, timber, logs, stumps six inches in diameter or less, carpeting, and combustible construction and demolition debris; and 
(3)  Any other solid waste that is combustible in the MBI as shall be determined solely by the board of public works. 
    "Combustible waste" shall exclude: 
(1)  Noncombustible solid waste, such as ashes, noncombustible rubbish, incinerator ash, incinerator residue, municipal and industrial sludges, animal waste, pathological and biological waste, asbestos and asbestos waste products, explosives, radioactive materials, appliances, concrete rubble, noncombustible construction and demolition debris, rock, gravel and earth materials, automobiles, trailers, equipment wire and cable; 
(2)  All waste other than solid waste, such as hazardous waste, site-separated materials, and source-separated materials; and 
(3)  Any other type of waste that is noncombustible in the MBI, as shall be determined solely by the board of public works. 
    Commercial operation date means the date when the MBI has been completed and tested and is, in the sole opinion of the county, ready for full commercial operation. 
    County means the County of Kent, Michigan, acting by and through its board of commissioners or its department of public works. 
    County solid waste management plan means the county solid waste management plan approved by the city, the county board of commissioners, and by the director of the department of natural resources (or other state official as required by state law), pursuant to the provisions and requirements of the state Solid Waste Management Act, and any amendments to the plan adopted in accordance with that Act. 
    Disposal site means any of the following: 
(1)  A solid waste transfer facility; 
(2)  A single incinerator having an average daily design capacity exceeding 50 tons of solid waste per day or two or more incinerators located at one site under the control of one person and having an aggregate average daily design capacity exceeding 150 tons of solid waste per day; 
(3)  A sanitary landfill; 
(4)  A solid waste processing plant; or 
(5)  Any other solid waste handling or disposal facility utilized in the disposal of solid waste. 
    Garbage means rejected food wastes, including waste accumulations of animal, fruit or vegetable matter used or intended for food or that attends the preparation, use, cooking, dealing in or storing of meat, fish, fowl, fruit or vegetables. 
    Hazardous waste means hazardous waste as defined in the state Hazardous Waste Management Act (part 111 of Act 451 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1994, as amended; MCL 324.11101 et seq., as amended (formerly Act No. 64 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1979, as amended)). 
    MBI means the mass-burn steam energy-generating incinerator to be constructed by or on behalf of, or available by contract or lease with, the county within the City of Grand Rapids in accordance with the county solid waste management plan. 
    Premises means any enclosed area used for residential, commercial or industrial purposes, separately or in combination, to which a separate street address, postal address or box, tax roll description, or other similar identification has been assigned or is in use by a person having control of the area. 
    Rubbish means nonputrescible solid waste, excluding ashes, consisting of combustible and noncombustible waste, including paper, cardboard, metal containers, yard clippings, wood, glass, bedding, crockery, demolished building materials, or litter of any kind that may be a detriment to the public health and safety. 
    Site of generation means any premises in or on which solid waste is generated by any person. 
    Site-separated materials means recyclable materials (including, but not limited to, bottles, cans, newspapers, corrugated containers, metals, grass, leaves, brush and yard trimmings) that are separated from solid waste after collection from a site of generation by either a waste hauler or by the operators of a disposal site to which it is delivered. 
    Solid waste means garbage, rubbish, ashes, incinerator ash, incinerator residue, street cleanings, municipal and industrial sludges, solid commercial and solid industrial waste and animal waste; provided, however, that this definition shall not include hazardous waste, site-separated materials, source-separated materials, human body waste, liquid or other waste regulated by statute, ferrous or nonferrous scrap directed to a scrap metal processor or to a reuser of ferrous or nonferrous products, and slag or slag products directed to a slag processor or to a reuser of slag or slag products. 
    Source-separated materials means recyclable materials (including, but not limited to, bottles, cans, newspapers, corrugated containers, metals, grass, leaves, brush, and yard trimmings) that are separated from solid waste prior to the collection of solid waste from a site of generation. 
    State Solid Waste Management Act means part 115 of Act 451 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1994, as amended; MCL 324.11501 et seq., as amended (formerly Act No. 641 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1978, as amended). 
    Tipping fee means the fee established by the board of public works to be charged upon delivery of combustible waste to the MBI. 
    Transporting vehicle means any vehicle used for the purpose of collecting, transporting, delivering or disposing of solid waste. 
    Waste hauler means any person engaged, in whole or in part, in the business of collecting, transporting, delivering or disposing of solid waste within the city. 
(Code 1976, § 8-1; Ord. No. 95-470, § 11, 10-24-9; Ord. No. 10-585, § 1, 5-24-10) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 62-2. - Use of solid waste containers. 
(a)  Subject to the provisions of this article, every person shall keep, within the lot line of his premises, a suitable and properly sealed solid waste container for depositing solid waste and shall not litter or permit the littering of his premises with any solid waste. No solid waste shall be kept outdoors except in a solid waste container. 
(b)  The occupant of any premises or the person responsible for any premises within the city in which any solid waste is accumulated, which solid waste is not disposed of by an approved incinerator or an approved garbage grinder, shall maintain on the premises one or more solid waste containers with suitable tightly fitted covers, which shall be kept in a reasonably clean and sanitary condition, shall be rodent proof, and shall, subject to the provisions of this article, be located in a convenient place to facilitate the proper collection of solid waste. 
(c)  A solid waste container, of whatever size, which contains organic material shall be emptied of such material and the material shall be removed from the premises not less frequently than once a week. 
(d)  A solid waste container may not be stored or located in the front yard of any premises in the city except during the 24 hours immediately before it is removed or emptied. For purposes of this subsection, "front yard" shall have the same meaning as contained in chapter 94 of the City Code of Ordinances. 
(Code 1976, § 8-2; Ord. No. 10-585, § 2, 5-24-10; Ord. No. 11-600, § 1, 7-27-11) 
Sec. 62-3. - Identification of solid waste containers. 
(a)  A solid waste container having a capacity of at least one-half cubic yard shall be plainly marked with the name and current street address or the name and current telephone number of the waste hauler which collects solid waste from or transports solid waste within the solid waste container. The name and current street address or the name and current telephone number of the waste hauler shall be plainly marked in letters and figures not less than three inches in height. 
(b)  The waste hauler collecting solid waste from or transporting the solid waste container having a capacity of at least one-half cubic yard shall be responsible for complying with this article. It shall be a violation of this section for any waste hauler to collect solid waste from or to transport such a solid waste container unless the solid waste container has been marked in compliance with this section. 
(c)  For purposes of this section and section 62-2, "solid waste container" means a container or receptacle designed or used for depositing, storing, or accumulating solid waste for collection or transportation by a waste hauler. Without limitation, this definition shall include dumpsters, packer boxes, and roll-offs or other receptacles designed or used to store solid waste or to transport solid waste from a site of generation. 
(Code 1976, § 8-2.1; Ord. No. 10-585, § 3, 5-24-10; Ord. No. 11-600, § 2, 7-27-11) 
Sec. 62-4. - Littering. 
(a)  No person shall place, deposit, throw, scatter or leave in any street, highway, lane, alley, public place or square, or on the private property of another, any solid waste, dead animals or other noxious or unsightly materials. 
(b)  No person shall place, deposit, throw, scatter or leave in any street, alley or public place any tacks, screws, nails, glass, metal scraps, metal shavings or other sharp or dangerous materials. No person shall convey or transport junk, broken glass, scrap metal, metal shavings or other sharp or dangerous material in any form over the public streets or alleys of the city, unless the same shall be contained in a box or other receptacle so constructed that such junk, glass, metal or other material cannot fall through the receptacle or over the sides of such receptacle onto the public streets or alleys of the city. 
(c)  No person shall transport or dump any solid waste in such a manner as to cause the littering of any stream, public way or public place, or the private property of another, or to cause the obstruction of any ditch, drain, culvert or gutter. 
(d)  No person shall place, deposit, drop, throw, track or leave or cause to be placed, deposited, thrown, dropped, tracked or left on any street, highway, lane, alley or sidewalk any clay, dirt, sand, gravel, rock, or other substance in such a manner which will cause, tend to cause, contribute to, or be likely to contribute to the injury or danger of injury to any person, animal or vehicle or to cause any other unsafe condition on any highway, lane, alley, or sidewalk within the city. No person who places, deposits, drops, throws, tracks or leaves any clay, dirt, sand, gravel, rock, or any other substance or causes the same to be placed, deposited, dropped, thrown, tracked or left on any street, highway, lane, alley or sidewalk in violation of this subsection shall fail to immediately remove the same or cause it to be removed. 
(Code 1976, § 8-3; Ord. No. 10-585, § 4, 5-24-10) 
Secs. 62-5-62-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - TRANSPORTING VEHICLES AND WASTE HAULERS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Traffic and vehicles, ch. 82. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 62-31. - Compliance with article. 
    No person shall use any transporting vehicle within the city except in compliance with the provisions of this article; provided, however, that a vehicle used by an individual to transport solid waste from his household and not for hire need not comply with the provisions of sections 62-34, 62-35 and 62-36, but such person shall be required to tightly cover and secure the load, so that no part thereof shall be lost, and the load shall not be emptied in the city except as provided in sections 62-42 and 62-43. 
(Code 1976, § 8-4; Ord. No. 10-585, § 5, 5-24-10) 
Sec. 62-32. - Compliance with laws, rules and regulations. 
    Waste haulers shall comply with the county solid waste management plan and all applicable federal, state, and local laws, statutes, ordinances, rules and regulations (including, but not limited to, the state Solid Waste Management Act and administrative rules promulgated pursuant to the Act) in the collection, transportation, delivery and disposal of combustible waste. Waste haulers shall also comply with all rules and regulations of the board of public works for the administration and operation of the MBI (including, without limitation, rules and regulations prohibiting delivery of loads consisting primarily of unacceptable waste as solely determined by the board of public works acting through its designated representatives) and other disposal sites of the county refuse system. To the extent of any conflict between these laws, statutes, ordinances, rules and regulations, the more restrictive shall be deemed to control. 
(Code 1976, § 8-19; Ord. No. 95-470, § 12, 10-24-95; Ord. No. 10-585, § 6, 5-24-10) 
Sec. 62-33. - Municipal civil infractions. 
    A violation of any provision of this article or article I is a municipal civil infraction. The civil fine for a violation of sections 62-42 or 62-43 shall be as follows: 
First offense Not less than $2,000.00 (plus costs) First repeat offense Not less than $5,000.00 (plus costs) Second or any subsequent repeat offense Not less than $10,000.00 (plus costs)  
    The civil fines for all other violations of this article or article I shall be as follows: 
First offense Not less than $100.00 (plus costs) First repeat offense Not less than $500.00 (plus costs) Second or any subsequent repeat offense Not less than $1,000.00 (plus costs)  
    For purposes of this article and article I, a "repeat offense" means a second (or subsequent) municipal civil infraction violation of the same requirement or provision: 
(1)  Committed by a person within any five-year period, and 
(2)  For which the person admits responsibility or is determined to be responsible. 
    Each day that a violation occurs shall be deemed a separate offense and shall be subject to sanctions as a separate offense. In addition to municipal civil infractions and any other remedies available at law, the city may bring an action for an injunction or other process against a person to restrain, prevent, or abate any violation of this chapter. In addition, a violation of any provision of this article or article I shall be cause for revocation of a waste hauler license. 
(Ord. No. 97-504, § 2, 12-8-97; Ord. No. 10-585, § 7, 5-24-10) 
Cross reference- General penalty for violations of Code and ordinances, § 1-11. 
Sec. 62-34. - Required markings on vehicles. 
    Any transporting vehicle shall have the name of the waste hauler and its address and telephone number plainly marked upon both sides of the vehicle, in letters and figures three inches or more high. 
(Code 1976, § 8-5; Ord. No. 10-585, § 8, 5-24-10) 
Sec. 62-35. - Construction requirements for vehicles with compaction units. 
    Transporting vehicles with compaction units must meet the following requirements: 
(1)  The load carrying portion of the vehicle shall be equipped with a unit for compacting, and shall be totally and permanently enclosed and of welded steel construction. Articulated units need not provide compacting devices in those instances where the portion of the vehicle designed to hold or contain the solid waste is an independent transportable unit designed to be replaced rather than emptied at the premises. 
(2)  Such vehicles shall be of tight fitting construction and of a design to form a totally enclosed body or unit. 
(3)  Such vehicles shall be equipped so that all loading and unloading openings on the body have tight fitting doors or covers fitted with latches or clamps and rubber or other suitable gaskets to form a spill proof, leak proof and dust proof enclosed body or unit. 
(4)  All vehicles used in the transportation of solid waste shall comply at all times with any applicable federal or state transportation or safety laws (e.g., Department of Transportation, etc.). 
(Code 1976, § 8-6; Ord. No. 10-585, § 9, 5-24-10) 
Sec. 62-36. - Construction requirements for open body vehicles. 
    The solid waste carrying portion of all open body transporting vehicles shall be of steel construction to a minimum height of two feet and designed to prevent the accidental discharge of its contents. Built-up walls of open body transporting vehicles shall be free of any gaps or spaces, and shall be of steel construction. Any such unit or vehicle shall have a suitable cover which prevents the loss of the vehicle's contents and which is not easily torn, shredded, or broken under normal use. All vehicles used in the transportation of solid waste shall comply at all times with any applicable federal or state transportation or safety laws (e.g., Department of Transportation, etc.). 
(Code 1976, § 8-7; Ord. No. 10-585, § 10, 5-24-10) 
Sec. 62-37. - Cleaning of vehicles. 
    A transporting vehicle shall be cleaned at intervals frequent enough to maintain it in a sanitary condition and free from disagreeable odor and to prevent a nuisance or vermin attraction. 
(Code 1976, § 8-8; Ord. No. 10-585, § 11, 5-24-10) 
Sec. 62-38. - Parking and storing restrictions for vehicles. 
    A transporting vehicle shall not be parked in an AA, A, A-2, SA, S, ARM, ARM District One or RMT zoning district longer than necessary to collect solid waste and shall not be parked, stored or established at any location so as to cause a nuisance or hazard or in violation of chapter 94. 
(Code 1976, § 8-9; Ord. No. 10-585, § 12, 5-24-10) 
Sec. 62-39. - Openings to be closed and covers secured on vehicles; special covers. 
    A transporting vehicle shall have all openings closed and all doors or covers secured by an adequate latch or restraining mechanism to keep them closed while transporting solid waste. It shall be the responsibility of the driver of the transporting vehicle and the waste hauler (if different) to ensure that the available cover is in the proper position. Special covering shall be used where conditions require control of odor, vermin, liquids, dust or smoke. 
(Code 1976, § 8-10; Ord. No. 10-585, § 13, 5-24-10; Ord. No. 10-585, § 13 5-24-10) 
Sec. 62-40. - Overloading of vehicles prohibited. 
    The solid waste carrying part of any transporting vehicle shall not be filled beyond its capacity and such vehicles shall otherwise be loaded in a manner to minimize the spillage of materials. 
(Code 1976, § 8-11; Ord. No. 10-585, § 14, 5-24-10) 
Sec. 62-41. - Duty of driver in case of spillage or intentional dumping of load. 
(a)  Where spillage occurs from any transporting vehicle, the material shall be picked up immediately, and the area suitably cleaned. 
(b)  Where solid waste is purposely dumped from a transporting vehicle due to hot load or fire, the fire shall be immediately extinguished by the most effective means and the area properly cleaned as soon as reasonably possible. 
(c)  It shall be the responsibility of the driver or person in charge of a transporting vehicle to comply with the provisions of this section. 
(Code 1976, § 8-12; Ord. No. 10-585, § 15, 5-24-10) 
Sec. 62-42. - Disposal of solid waste and combustible waste. 
(a)  No person shall dispose of solid waste other than by means of an approved incinerator or approved garbage grinder, or by collection by a licensed waste hauler; provided, however, that any individual may dispose of solid waste from his own household: 
(1)  Upon the individual's own land, so long as the disposal does not create a nuisance or hazard to health, in accordance with section 11520(2) of the state Solid Waste Management Act (MCL 324.11520(2)); or 
(2)  By personally transporting the solid waste to an approved sanitary landfill, but only in accordance with rules and regulations pertaining thereto and the county solid waste management plan. No individual transporting any solid waste in accordance with this section shall fail to securely cover and secure the load so that no part of such load shall be lost while being transported.
