(7)  On the frozen surface of public waters within 100 feet of a person not in or upon a vehicle, or within 100 feet of a fishing shanty or shelter or an area which is cleared of snow for skating purposes, except at the minimum speed required to maintain controlled forward movement of the vehicle, or as may be authorized by permit in special events. 
(8)  Unless the vehicle is equipped with a spark arrester-type muffler, in good working order and in constant operation. Noise emission under full throttle, at 50 feet at right angles from the vehicle path, shall not exceed 90 db(A) on a vehicle manufactured or assembled prior to January 1, 1973; 88 db(A) on a vehicle manufactured or assembled after January 1, 1973; or 86 db(A) on a vehicle manufactured or assembled after January 1, 1975, as measured on a sound level meter which meets the requirements of ANSI S1.4 1971, using the procedure and ancillary equipment therein described. A vehicle subject to this section, manufactured or assembled after February 1, 1976, and used, sold or offered for sale in this state shall conform to the noise emission levels established by the Environmental Protection Agency under the federal noise control act of 1972, except in an officially authorized special event. 
(9)  Within 100 feet of a dwelling at a speed greater than the minimum required to maintain controlled forward movement of the vehicle, except on property owned or under the operator's control or on which the operator is an invited guest, or on a roadway, forest road or forest trail under the jurisdiction of the department of natural resources and where permitted by such department, or on an ORV access route as authorized by local ordinance. 
(10)  In or upon private property without consent of the owner or lessee of the land. The operator of the vehicle is liable for damage to private property, including but not limited to damage to trees, shrubs, or growing crops, injury to living creatures, or damage caused through vehicle operation in a manner so as to create erosive or other ecological damage to private property. The owner of the private property may recover from the person responsible nominal damages of not less than the amount of damage or injury. Failure to post private property or fence or otherwise enclose property in a manner to exclude intruders, or for the private property owner or other authorized person to personally communicate against trespass, shall not imply consent to ORV use. 
(11)  While transporting thereon a bow unless unstrung or encased, or a firearm unless unloaded and securely encased, or equipped with and made inoperative by a manufactured key-locked trigger housing mechanism. 
(12)  On or across a cemetery or burial ground, or land used as an airport. 
(13)  Within 100 feet of a slide, ski or skating area, unless the vehicle is being used for the purpose of servicing the area. 
(14)  On an operating or nonabandoned railroad or railroad right-of-way, other than for the purpose of crossing at a clearly established site intended for vehicular traffic, except railroad, public utility or law enforcement personnel while in performance of their duties. 
(15)  In or upon the waters of any stream, except for the purpose of crossing the stream over a bridge, culvert, or similar structure, or by operating the vehicle at the minimum speed required to maintain controlled forward movement of the vehicle and crossing in the most direct manner from and to an established trail so as to negate erosive damage to the bed and banks of the stream or river, or as may otherwise be authorized by the director of the department of natural resources on state-owned land; or to travel upstream or downstream in any river or stream unless of a water depth sufficient to permit flotation of the vehicle at all times. 
(16)  To hunt, pursue, worry, kill, or attempt such action toward a bird or animal, wild or domesticated. 
(17)  In a manner so as to leave behind litter or other debris. 
(Code 1976, § 11-43) 
Cross reference- Noise, § 34-126 et seq. 
Sec. 82-69. - Willful failure to obey an officer's direction. 
(a)  An operator of an ORV who is given by hand, voice, emergency light or siren a visual or audible signal by a law enforcement officer acting in the lawful performance of his duty, directing the operator to bring the vehicle to a stop, and who willfully fails to obey the signal by increasing speed, extinguishing lights, or otherwise attempting to flee or elude the officer is guilty of a misdemeanor. The officer giving the signal shall be in uniform, and the officer's vehicle shall be easily identifiable as an official law enforcement vehicle. 
(b)  The operator of a vehicle on the private premises of another, when visibly hailed by the owner or the owner's authorized agent, shall bring the vehicle to an immediate stop and provide personal identification. Refusal to obey such a request to stop or subsequent escape or attempt to escape is a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1976, § 11-44) 
Sec. 82-70. - Operation on highway or right-of-way; crossing highway; special event on street, highway or frozen surface. 
    A person shall not operate an ORV which is not registered under Act No. 300 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1949 (MCL 257.1 et seq., MSA 9.1801 et seq.), as amended, upon a public highway, street or right-of-way thereof, except under the following conditions and circumstances: 
(1)  The operator of a vehicle may cross a public street or highway, other than a limited access highway, at right angles, for the purpose of getting from one area to another, when the operation can be done in safety. The operator shall bring the vehicle to a complete stop before proceeding across a public street or highway, and shall yield the right-of-way to oncoming traffic. 
(2)  A vehicle may be operated on a street or highway for a special event of limited duration, conducted according to a prearranged schedule, only under permit from the city. A special event involving ORVs may be conducted on the frozen surface of public waters only under permit from the department of natural resources. 
(Code 1976, § 11-46) 
Sec. 82-71. - Compliance with other ordinances and laws. 
    Compliance with the provisions of this article does not relieve any person from the necessity to comply with all other applicable provisions of any other ordinance or regulation of the city, or statute or regulation of the state or federal government. 
(Code 1976, § 11-45) 
Secs. 82-72-82-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - INOPERABLE MOTOR VEHICLES 

Sec. 82-91. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Inoperable motor vehicles means motor vehicles which do not bear valid registration plates as required by the state vehicle code, Act No. 300 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1949 (MCL 257.1 et seq., MSA 9.1801 et seq.), or which, by reason of dismantling, disrepair or other cause, are incapable of being propelled under their own power, or are unsafe for operation on the streets and highways of this state, because of inability to comply with the state vehicle code. 
    Motor vehicles means any wheeled vehicles which are or are intended to be operable as self-propelled vehicles. 
(Code 1976, § 11-29) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 82-92. - Article supplementary to other ordinances and state statutes. 
    This article shall not be construed as repealing any ordinance relating to the keeping of rubbish, litter, garbage, refuse, trash or junk, but shall be construed as supplementary to any such ordinance as well as to any statutes of the state relating thereto. 
(Code 1976, § 11-30) 
Sec. 82-93. - To be stored in enclosed structure; exceptions. 
    It is hereby declared to be unlawful for any person to store, place or permit to be stored or placed any inoperable motor vehicle or any part or parts of a motor vehicle on land located in the city, except as such storage or placement may be permitted under the provisions of the zoning chapter or the provisions of section 82-94, unless such inoperable motor vehicle or part or parts of a motor vehicle are kept in a wholly enclosed garage or other wholly enclosed structure. 
(Code 1976, § 11-32) 
Sec. 82-94. - Temporary open storage on private property. 
(a)  Any owner or occupant of land may store or permit to be stored on such land one inoperable motor vehicle, for a period of not to exceed 48 hours, if such motor vehicle is registered in his name. In the event of hardship, such owner or occupant may apply to the building official for a permit to extend such period of 48 hours for an additional period of not to exceed one week. 
(b)  Upon application duly made and upon a showing of hardship, which hardship can be eliminated by an extension of time for the storage of the inoperable motor vehicle, the building official is hereby authorized to issue the permit referred to in subsection (a). No such permit shall be granted for successive weeks for any one motor vehicle. A fee of $1.00 shall be collected for each such permit so issued and shall be paid into the general fund. 
(c)  Nothing in this section or any permit issued under this section shall be construed to authorize the parking, placing or storage of an inoperable motor vehicle in any front yard, as defined in chapter 94, pertaining to zoning, and such parking, placing or storage is hereby prohibited. 
(Code 1976, § 11-33) 
Sec. 82-95. - Parking on streets prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park or place any inoperable motor vehicle on any street area in the city. 
(Code 1976, § 11-34) 
Sec. 82-96. - Violation of article declared public nuisance. 
    The presence of an inoperable motor vehicle or parts of a motor vehicle in violation of the terms of this article is hereby declared to be a public nuisance. 
(Code 1976, § 11-31) 
Cross reference- Nuisances, § 34-26 et seq. 
Sec. 82-97. - Municipal civil infraction. 
(a)  A person who violates any provision of this article (article V) is responsible for a municipal civil infraction, subject to payment of a civil fine of not less than $50.00, plus costs and other sanctions, for each infraction. 
(b)  Repeat offenses shall be subject to increased as provided by section 1-11(c)(2) of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 94-453, § 1, 10-25-94) 
Secs. 82-98, 82-99. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - REGULATION OF PUBLIC PARKING LOTS 

Sec. 82-100. - Purpose. 
    Under the authority of Public Act No. 235 of the Public Acts of 1969, as amended, and upon request of the downtown development authority, the city hereby regulates the movement of vehicles and pedestrians and the stopping, standing, or parking of vehicles in public parking lots within the city. 
(Ord. No. 93-426, § 1, 11-23-93) 
Sec. 82-101. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this article, the following definitions shall apply: 
    Public parking lots means the public parking lots and related access drives for which public easements have been granted to the city downtown development authority. 
    Traffic control devices means signs, signals, markings, and devices placed or erected under the direction of the chief of police for the purpose of regulating the movement of vehicles and pedestrians and the stopping, standing, or parking of vehicles in public parking lots. 
    Uniform Traffic Code means the Uniform Traffic Code for Cities, Townships, and Villages, as amended, and adopted by reference in article II of chapter 82. 
(Ord. No. 93-426, § 1, 11-23-93) 
Sec. 82-102. - Regulation of public parking lots; tow-away zones. 
(a)  The chief of police may determine controls of the movement of vehicles and pedestrians and the stopping, standing, or parking of vehicles in public parking lots including, without limitation, the designation of tow-away zones where parking is restricted or prohibited. The chief of police shall direct the placement and maintenance of whatever traffic-control devices are necessary to give notice of the controls determined to be necessary. 
(b)  Tow-away zones may be designated by the chief of police in public parking lots by posting signs which read "tow-away zone". Such signs shall be posted independently or as an extra panel attached below the posted signs which prohibit or restrict parking at the location. 
(c)  A police officer may immediately remove a vehicle from a public parking lot and impound the vehicle if a vehicle is found parked in violation of a traffic-control device in a tow-away zone designated by the chief of police under this article. A police officer who impounds a vehicle under this section shall follow the same procedures for impounding a vehicle parked in a tow-away zone under the Uniform Traffic Code. 
(Ord. No. 93-426, § 1, 11-23-93; Ord. No. 10-586, § 1, 5-24-10) 
Sec. 82-103. - Prima facie responsibility of registered owner; operator. 
    If a vehicle is parked in a public parking lot in violation of the directions of a traffic-control device, the person in whose name the vehicle is registered in this state or another state at the time of the violation is prima facie responsible for that violation and subject to section 82-104. A police officer who issues a citation for a vehicle that is stopped, standing, or parked in violation of the directions of a traffic-control device in a public parking lot may issue the citation to the operator of the vehicle if the operator is present at the time of violation. 
(Ord. No. 93-426, § 1, 11-23-93) 
Sec. 82-104. - Violations; civil infraction. 
    A person who fails to comply with the directions of a traffic-control device in a public parking lot is responsible for a civil infraction. A civil infraction under this article shall be processed in the same manner as a civil infraction under the Uniform Traffic Code. 
(Ord. No. 93-426, § 1, 11-23-93) 
Secs. 82-105-82-119. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - PARKING[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 02-494, §§ 3, 4, repealed art. VII in its entirety and enacted new provisions as set out herein. The former art. VII pertained to traffic engineer; traffic control orders; procedures and derived from Ord. No. 00-459, § 3, adopted Jul 24, 2000. 

Sec. 82-120. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this article, commercial vehicle, commercial motor vehicle, and motor home shall have the meaning as those terms are defined in the Michigan Vehicle Code (Act No. 300 of the Public Acts of 1949, as amended; MCL 257.1 et seq.), as amended, and "major recreational equipment" shall have the meaning as that term is defined in section 94-470 of the City Code. 
(Ord. No. 02-486, §§ 3, 4, 4-8-02) 
Sec. 82-121. - Weight restrictions on parking. 
(a)  No commercial vehicle, commercial motor vehicle, motor home, or major recreational equipment shall be parked for longer than six hours on any road or street anywhere in the city. For purposes of this article, commercial vehicle, commercial motor vehicle, and motor home shall have the same meaning as those terms are defined in the Michigan Vehicle Code (Act No. 300 of the Public Acts of 1949, as amended; MCL 257.1 et seq.), as amended, and major recreational equipment shall have the same meaning as that term is defined in section 94-470 of the City Code. 
(b)  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Ord. No. 02-486, §§ 3, 4, 4-8-02) 
Sec. 82-122. - Restrictions on angle parking for commercial vehicles. 
(a)  No commercial vehicle or commercial motor vehicle shall be allowed to stand at an angle to the side of the roadway and projecting into such roadway for longer than four hours. 
(b)  Under no circumstances shall such angle parking be permitted where the free flow of traffic would be curtailed, except upon written permission from the chief of police, and then only upon showing to the chief of police of the need for such angle parking and the length of time required for such angle parking, which length of time shall be reasonable with reference to traffic conditions at the location to which the request relates. This section shall not apply to a vehicle which has become inoperable because of an unforeseen circumstance, and such vehicle may remain on the road or street as long as reasonably necessary to make it operable or obtain a means of removing it, whichever shall be the shorter period. 
(c)  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Ord. No. 02-486, §§ 3, 4, 4-8-02) 
Sec. 82-123. - Restrictions on parking of unattached trailers; penalties. 
(a)  No unattached trailer of any type shall be parked on a roadway in the city at any time except as may be necessary to temporarily disconnect it for purposes of loading or unloading, and then for no longer than two hours at any time. 
(b)  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Ord. No. 02-486, §§ 3, 4, 4-8-02) 
Sec. 82-124. - Moved vehicles deemed stationary. 
    For purposes of this article, any vehicle which has been moved less than 100 feet shall be considered stationary and as if it were still parked in the location immediately preceding the move. 
(Ord. No. 02-486, §§ 3, 4, 4-8-02) 
Sec. 82-125. - Restrictions on parking of commercial vehicles in residentially zoned districts; penalties. 
(a)  No commercial vehicle or commercial motor vehicle, other than trucks three-fourths of a ton or smaller, shall be parked in any public street or highway located within a residentially zoned district, unless such vehicle is parked in that location in connection with services being performed on, for, or related to property within 100 feet of the place where such vehicle is parked. Such services shall include, as example and not by way of limitation, excavation and construction, repair of buildings or equipment, and pickup or delivery of items. No commercial vehicle or commercial motor vehicle shall be parked in the manner specified in this section for any period of time longer than is reasonably necessary to perform the function for which that vehicle is being used. 
(b)  A person who violates this section is responsible for a civil infraction. 
(Ord. No. 02-486, §§ 3, 4, 4-8-02) 
Secs. 82-126-82-129. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - VEHICLES[4]

(a)  A person shall not knowingly authorize or permit a motor vehicle owned by him or her [or] under his or her control to be driven by any person who is unlicensed to drive such vehicle. 
(b)  A violation of this section is punishable as a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 02-494, §§ 3, 5, 12-23-02)

ARTICLE IX. - TRUCK ROUTES 

Sec. 82-200. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to regulate the orderly operation of trucks on the streets of the city. The primary objectives are to facilitate the transfer of goods and services by trucks to businesses and to preserve the quality of life of neighborhoods. Prime considerations involved with the purpose of this article are: 
(a)  The safety of our citizens; 
(b)  Avoidance of unreasonable or unnecessary disturbance or reduction in property values due to truck noise, vibrations, and/or air pollution; 
(c)  Protection against the deterioration of those streets not designated for truck traffic; and 
(d)  Adequate truck service to businesses and residences in an expeditious manner, having due regard for economical vehicle operation. 
(Ord. No. 04-523, § 1, 12-27-04) 
Sec. 82-201. - Traffic control signs. 
    Where density of traffic, protection of life and property, construction and condition of the roadway, or any hazardous condition make it advisable, the direction of traffic flow, and routing of buses, trucks, and heavy vehicles, will be made by this article by duly posting traffic control signs and it shall be unlawful to drive or cause to be driven, any vehicle in violation of such direction and routing. 
(Ord. No. 04-523, § 1, 12-27-04) 
Sec. 82-202. - Truck route map. 
    The streets designated as forming the truck route system are indicated upon the truck route map attached as appendix A and the map, and all notations, references or other information located thereon, are made a part of this article and shall have the same force and effect as if there were fully set forth or described herein. The map shall be properly attested by the chief of police and shall be on file with the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 04-523, § 1, 12-27-04) 
Sec. 82-203. - Street designations. 
    The streets of the city are hereby designated for purposes of this article as follows: 
(a)  Truck routes. Those streets or portions of streets specifically designated as truck routes in section 82-204. 
(b)  Major streets. Those streets or portions of streets that are certified by the Michigan Department of Transportation as major streets in the city, excluding those streets or portions of streets designated as truck routes in section 82-204. For purposes of this article, major streets are only those streets or portions of streets designated in section 82-205. 
(c)  Local streets. All streets not designated in this article as truck routes or major streets. 
(Ord. No. 04-523, § 1, 12-27-04)

    The following roadways, or portions of roadways, in the city are hereby designated as truck routes for purposes of this article:

    The following roadways, or portions of roadways, in the City of Walker, are hereby designated as major streets for purposes of this article:

(Ord. No. 04-523, § 1, 12-27-04) 
Sec. 82-206. - Motor vehicles of restricted class. 
    Motor vehicles of the restricted class as used in this article are defined as all motor vehicles having a weight of 10,000 pounds or more including the load therein, except vehicles carrying or designated to carry passengers, all governmentally-owned or leased vehicles, public utility vehicles and vehicles used for private refuse handling. 
(Ord. No. 04-523, § 1, 12-27-04) 
Sec. 82-207. - Travel into or out of city. 
    Motor vehicles of the restricted class, which do not have a pick-up, delivery, or service within the city, shall enter and exit the city on truck routes only. 
(Ord. No. 04-523, § 1, 12-27-04) 
Sec. 82-208. - Travel within the city; truck routes; exceptions. 
    Motor vehicles of the restricted class, while in the city, shall travel on truck routes only, except as follows: 
(a)  The operation of authorized emergency vehicles may occur on any roadway in the city. 
(b)  The operation of recreational vehicles as defined by state law, which are of the restricted class, may use any roadway in the city. 
(c)  The operation of motor vehicles of the restricted class is permitted on any roadway in the city for pick-up, delivery, or service where the destination is not on a truck route, provided that ingress and egress thereto or therefrom is accomplished in the following manner: 
1.  Vehicles of the restricted class shall utilize designated truck routes to the point closest to delivery, pick-up or service, subject to the requirement of subsection (2) to follow major streets whenever possible when leaving or returning to truck routes. 
2.  Upon leaving or returning to the truck route, vehicles of the restricted class shall utilize the shortest route available except that when leaving or returning to truck routes, such vehicles shall follow major streets whenever possible to travel to and from local streets and then utilize local streets only when necessary for the completion of the pick-up, delivery, or service. 
3.  In making consecutive deliveries, pick-ups or services to destinations not on truck routes, motor vehicles of the restricted class shall proceed on roadways other than truck routes only if the distance traveled on nontruck routes as a result of this routing would be less than the distance traveled on nontruck routes if the vehicle had returned to a truck route as in (2) above and then proceeded to the next delivery points in (1) and (2) above. 
(d)  The roadways designated as truck routes in section 82-204 shall be posted with signs at appropriate intervals. Such signs shall consist of the words "truck route" below which shall be placed an arrow indicating the direction of the truck route. 
(e)  Nontruck route streets may be posted with signs at appropriate intervals. Such signs shall indicate "no trucks" or "not a truck route". 
(f)  It shall be the duty of any person driving or in charge or control of any buses, trucks, or heavy vehicles, other than vehicles carrying or designed by carry passengers upon any roadway not a designated truck route upon the request of a police officer to stop and answer any questions regarding the weight of the truck, its designation, and its point of origin; and such persons shall also present log book, weight slips, delivery slips, and other written evidence of destination or point of origin, for the officer's examination. 
(g)  If any designated truck route or portion thereof, shall be under repair or otherwise temporarily out of use, motor vehicles of the restricted class shall use such other temporary truck routes as may be designated by the department of public works director, the city engineer, or their respective designees. 
(h)  In case of emergency, a temporary permit allowing exceptions to this article may be issued by the department of public works director, the city engineer, or their respective designees. 
(Ord. No. 04-523, § 1, 12-27-04) 
Sec. 82-209. - Municipal civil infraction. 
(a)  A person who violates any provision of this article is responsible for a municipal civil infraction, subject to payment of a civil fine of not less than $50.00, plus costs and other sanctions, for each infraction. 
(b)  Repeat offenses shall be subject to increased civil fines as provided by section 1-11(c)(2) of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 04-523, § 1, 12-27-04) 
Secs. 82-210-82-219. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION FARE 

Sec. 82-220. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, the following definitions shall apply: 
    Proof of fare payment means: 
(1)  A transit pass valid for the day and time of use; or 
(2)  A receipt showing payment of the applicable fare for use of the public transportation vehicle during the day and time specified in the receipt. 
    Public transportation authority means a public authority or other entity authorized to provide public transportation services under the laws of the State of Michigan. 
    Public transportation entity means any legal or administrative entity authorized under the laws of the State of Michigan to enforce the provisions of this article, including the City of Walker and such other entities that may be created with the authority to enforce this article. 
    Public transportation vehicle means a bus, train, or other vehicle used by a public transportation authority to provide public transportation services. 
    Transit pass means any pass, coupon, card, identification, token, ticket or other document used to obtain public transportation services. 
(Ord. No. 16-629, § 1, 6-27-2016) 
Sec. 82-221. - Fare evasion. 
    No person shall occupy, ride in, or use a public transportation vehicle without paying the fare established by the public transportation authority. All persons who occupy, ride in, or use a public transportation vehicle must possess proof of fare payment and shall present such proof upon the demand of a police officer, security officer, or fare inspector as authorized in accordance with this article. A violation of this section shall constitute a municipal civil infraction, as provided for in chapter 48 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 16-629, § 1, 6-27-2016) 
Sec. 82-222. - Fare inspectors. 
(1)  A public transportation entity may appoint or employ fare inspectors as necessary to enforce the provisions of this article. The appointing or employing public transportation entity shall determine the requirements for appointment or employment as a fare inspector. 
(2)  A fare inspector that is appointed or employed in accordance with this section is authorized to enforce the provisions of this article while acting within the scope of his or her authority and in the performance of his or her duties. 
(Ord. No. 16-629, § 1, 6-27-2016) 
Sec. 82-223. - Penalties for fare evasion. 
    Violation of the fare evasion provisions of this article shall be a municipal civil infraction as provided for in chapter 48 with the following penalties plus any statutory justice system assessment (or similar statutory assessment): 
Initial offense ..... $65.00 
Repeat offense ..... $130.00 
Subsequent repeat offense ..... $250.00 
(Ord. No. 16-629, § 1, 6-27-2016)

ARTICLE II. - WATER[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Provision of water at outdoor assemblies, § 10-77. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 86-21-86-25. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - GRAND RAPIDS WATER SYSTEM 

Sec. 86-26. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Commercial user means a person whose premises are used to offer services and/or products, including but not limited to retail and wholesale stores, gasoline stations, restaurants, schools, churches, hotels, motels, nursing homes, private clubs, theaters and governmental buildings. 
    Commodity charge means a variable unit charge payable by a user based on the actual water consumption as determined in this article. 
    Domestic user means a person whose premises are domiciles for single- or multiple-family use. 
    Industrial user means a person who operates a manufacturing or process facility which is engaged in producing a product. 
    Premises means each lot or parcel of land or building having any connection to the water system. 
    Service charge means a fixed charge payable by a user based on the size of his water meter. 
    User means a domestic, commercial or industrial user. 
    Water service means the retail sale of water by the City of Grand Rapids pursuant to the contract between the City of Grand Rapids and the City of Walker referred to in section 86-27. In the event of the termination of such Grand Rapids contract, "water service" shall refer to the water service furnished by the city. 
    Water system or system means the water system as constructed by the City of Grand Rapids and by or for the City of Walker pursuant to the contract referred to in section 86-27. In the event of termination of such Grand Rapids contract, "water system" or "system" shall refer to the water system of the city. 
(Code 1976, § 20-11) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 86-27. - Contracts with City of Grand Rapids and Kent County for construction of system and sale of water. 
(a)  By a contract between the City of Walker and the City of Grand Rapids, dated December 20, 1966, amended on January 3, 1978, and subsequently amended, the City of Grand Rapids is given the exclusive right and duty to sell water on a retail basis within the city and provision is made therein for the construction of mains and the rendering of services by the City of Grand Rapids within the city and for the construction by the City of Walker, upon a special assessment or other basis, of certain local distribution systems. 
(b)  By contract between the County of Kent, the City of Walker and the City of Grand Rapids, dated November 1, 1967, the county undertakes construction of the Walker sewage disposal and water supply system, under the provisions of Act No. 185 of the Public Acts of Michigan of 1957 (MCL 123.731 et seq., MSA 5.570(1) et seq.), as amended. 
(Code 1976, § 20-12) 
Sec. 86-28. - Applicants for service to agree to comply with ordinances, rules and regulations. 
    No connection shall be made to the water system unless each applicant for water service shall execute a written consent agreeing to comply with the ordinances, rules and regulations of the city and, so long as the City of Grand Rapids shall furnish water service in the city pursuant to the contract referred to in section 86-27, of the City of Grand Rapids with respect to the system. 
(Code 1976, § 20-13) 
Sec. 86-29. - Mingling of water from other sources. 
    Water from any other source or supply shall not be introduced into any part of the water system or mixed or mingled with the water system, without prior written approval of the city and, so long as the City of Grand Rapids shall furnish water services in the city pursuant to the contract referred to in section 86-27, the approval of the City of Grand Rapids. 
(Code 1976, § 20-14) 
Sec. 86-30. - Service laterals as prerequisite to issuance of improvement permits and approval of plats. 
    Permits to improve platted or unplatted premises shall not be issued and plats shall not be approved when the property lies within a part of the city served by the water system, unless laterals to serve all of the premises as subdivided or to be improved are provided; unless the city commission shall determine, by resolution, that compliance with this section would work an unreasonable hardship upon the owner of the premises involved. 
(Code 1976, § 20-15) 
Cross reference- Subdivisions, ch. 74. 
Sec. 86-31. - Connection permit. 
    Prior to the connection of any premises to the water system, a permit shall be secured from the treasurer of the city. The application for such permit shall be accompanied by such fee as shall be fixed from time to time by resolution of the city commission. 
(Code 1976, § 20-16) 
Sec. 86-32. - Charges for installation of local distribution mains; frontage charges. 
    Frontage and other charges for the water system shall be paid as follows: 
(1)  The cost of installing local distribution mains by the city or by the county department of public works for the city shall be borne, in whole or in part, by the property benefited by special assessments according to the benefit to each parcel or otherwise as provided by the city commission. As to any property not subject to assessment or not assessed, a comparable charge shall be paid for the privilege of connection. 
(2)  Users who request or are required to directly connect to a water line installed at the expense of the water system shall pay for the current cost of installations. This charge shall be known as the front foot charge and all references in this section to frontage charges shall be deemed to mean front foot charges. The front foot charge shall be determined by multiplying the front foot rate by the number of feet for which the property would be specially assessed under the special assessment district. At the time an applicant obtains a permit from the city, the city will determine the applicable front footage and specify it on the permit. The charge will be computed and collected by Grand Rapids before issuance of its permit. The front foot rates shall be as follows: 
a.  Domestic user: 
Current cost of installation ..... $28.20 
b.  Commercial or industrial user: 
1.  The same as a domestic user if the connection is made to a line eight inches or less in diameter. 
2.  For a line larger than eight inches: 
Current cost of installation ..... $38.40 
The front foot rates set out in this section shall remain in effect unless and until modified by resolution of the city commission. 
(3)  Where connection to a water main installed by the City of Grand Rapids is made with respect to one portion of a large undeveloped parcel of land under single ownership and service for the entire parcel is not requested, the frontage charge shall be based upon the average building parcel size, which shall be deemed to be 125 feet of frontage by 150 feet in depth, unless the parcel to be effectively serviced shall be of larger or smaller frontage, in which case that frontage shall be used to determine the frontage charge for the purposes of subsection (2). If the original parcel is subsequently subdivided and connections are made with respect to additional portions thereof, frontage charges with respect thereto shall be paid upon the same basis. 
(4)  Frontage charges payable in accordance with the provisions of subsection (2) may be paid in up to ten equal annual installments with interest at the rate of six percent per annum on the unpaid balance commencing with the due date of the first installment and computed to the due date of each installment, with the privilege of payment in full at any time subject to the payment of interest to the next installment due date. If any installment shall not be paid within one month from the due date thereof, a penalty shall be charged and added to the past due installment as follows: one percent of the principal amount of the installment due per month for each month or fraction thereof for the first three months of delinquency; two-thirds of one percent per month for each month or fraction thereof for the next nine months; three-quarters of one percent per month for each month or fraction thereof after 12 months. 
(Code 1976, § 20-17) 
Sec. 86-33. - Connection charge. 
(a)  If a property owner requests to connect to an existing water line, the following connection charges shall be paid to the City of Grand Rapids prior to connection based upon the water meter size in accordance with the following table: 
Water meter 
  size Charge  3/4-inch or less $   900.00 1-inch 1,500.00 11/2-inch 3,000.00 2-inch 4,800.00 3-inch 10,500.00 4-inch 18,900.00 6-inch or more 42,000.00  
The connection charges set forth in this section shall remain in effect unless and until modified by resolution of the city commission. 
(b)  If existing users apply for a meter size larger than the existing meter, they shall be required to pay the difference between the charge for the meter size applied for and the existing meter, based on the rates in effect at the time of application. No credit or rebate shall be given to any customer who applies for a meter of a smaller size than the existing meter. 
(c)  Permits issued by the Grand Rapids inspection services office for installation of water connections shall expire six months from the date of application. Fees paid for installation permits are nonrefundable upon expiration of the permit. 
(Code 1976, § 20-18) 
Sec. 86-34. - Service stub charge. 
(a)  Owners of property within the city, for which property one or more service stubs are provided, running from the water main to the lot or property line, shall pay a service stub charge, per service stub provided, in the following amounts: 
(1)  Two hundred ten dollars per one-inch connection. 
(2)  Two hundred sixty dollars per 11/2-inch connection. 
(3)  Three hundred twenty dollars per two-inch connection. 
(4)  Three hundred fifty dollars per four-inch connection. 
(b)  The charge provided for in this section may be paid in cash, in full or in part, and the balance shall be paid in ten equal annual installments, with interest on the unpaid balance at the rate of six percent per annum, and with the privilege of payment in full at any time subject to the payment of interest to the next installment due date. 
(Code 1976, § 20-19) 
Sec. 86-35. - Service charges. 
    The following rates and charges for water service shall apply to users within the city: 
Commodity Charge 
Domestic, per 100 cubic feet       $ 0.66 
Commercial, per 100 cubic feet       0.66 
Industrial, per 100 cubic feet       0.66 
Monthly Service Charge 
Meter size Charge  
 3/4-inch or less       $  4.76 
1-inch       7.79 
11/4-inch       11.69 
11/2-inch       16.46 
2-inch       28.59 
3-inch       63.26
